column2: Prime Minister Wilson paid a surprise visit to Northern Ireland today and warned terrorists that they would achieve nothing by violence.
Robert W. Stock was names yesterday by Max Frankel, Sun day editor of The New York Times, as editor of the paper', Sunday travel and resorts section. Mr. Stock, who is 44 years old,
SAN FRANCISCO, April 18Randolph A. Hearst today denounced Attorney General William B. Saxbe for referring to his kidnapped daughter, Patricia Hearst, as a common criminal.

Typographical Union No. 6 began a slowdown at The Daily News yesterday after being released from two court injunctions that had enjoined the local from interfering with operations at The News or The New York Times.

Miss Joan Blumenfeld, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Blumenfeld of West Orange, N.J., was married last evening to John H. Bess, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Bess of South Orange, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Ely E. Pilchik,.
- Claudius Roberts, mother of Oral Roberts, the evangelist, died yesterday at the infirmary of University Village, where she was a resident.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (Reuters)-Several industries including textiles, glass, metal cans, soap, detergents and cosmetics were exempted today from Phase 4 wage and price controls. The Cost of Living Council announced lifting of controls on companies in these areas and said wholesale trade relating to them also was being decontrolled.

The National Book Awards were given to 14 authors last night and burlesqued at the same time by a stand-up comic who accepted the prize for Thomas Pynchon, the novelist, and a naked man who jogged through Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center shouting: "Read books!

ALBANY, April 18-The Assembly, after a vigorous debate, killed the reciprocal banking bill that would have allowed out-of-state bank-holding companies to acquire branches in New York and New York banks to operate in other states.
Six men and women were tied up and stabbed after surprising three burglars at the apartment where two of the victims lived, the police disclosed today.
President Nixon nominated a collegee official today as the first woman to be the Government's highest education ofticer.

Civil Court Judge Fred Moritt was indicted and arrested yesterday on charges of conspiracy,perjury, grand larceny and witness-tampering in what the 68-year-old judge condemned as "a vile conspiracy" by the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadiari.

Mrs. Kitty Panzer, a blonde, 65-year-old Queens housewife, 'strolled down Fifth Avenue the other day, cigarette in hand. In fact, she has spent much of the last 30 years of her life with a cigarette in her yellow-stained hand. Mrs. Panzer is among the estimated 30 per cent of adult American women who are addicted to cigarettes.
The Secretary General or the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries predicted today that there would be a significant cutback in oil production by the group's member countries.

The move to a 10 1/4 per cent prime rate-the interest charged top corporate borrowers-gained further ground yesterday with three of the nation's 20 largest banks lifting their interest cost to that level from Credit the 10 per cent Markets rate that went into effect generally only a little more than a week ago.

The State Senate is considering a bill that would require medical insurers to underwrite part of the losses sustained by voluntary hospitals in the operation of their emergency and outpatient facilities. Since it appears that Federal law will not permit charging of such costs to Medicaid, the task would essentially fall toBlue Cross.

Two former political rivals of Representative John J Rooney of Brooklyn filed separate civil suits yesterday, charging that he had used illegally derogatory information supplied by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to defeat them in Democratic primary elections.

Senstor Edward M. Kennedy arrived tonight and' asserted that Soviet eladers should understand that American institutions would emerge stronger from the Watergate, affair and that regardless of political

District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan yesterday promoted two long-time members of his office. He named John F. Keenan, who has been on the staff since 1956, as chief assistant district attorney.
A pleasant blend of the old and not-so-old, with collector's items in both groups, characterizes the annual antiques, show that opened

WASHINGTON, April 18-The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroad during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.1 billion ton-miles, 1.6 per cent below the corresponding week of a year ago.

Avis, Inc., reported yesterday a loss of $582,000 for the first quarter, in contract to a gain of $2-million, or 33 cents a share, for the 1973 period. On Wednesday, the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, which owns 52 per cent of Avis's six-million shares,

The Franklin New York Corporation, parent of the Franklin National Bank, announced yesterday that in the first quarter of this year its net income before securities transactions was $77,000, or 2 cents a share,
Echoes of Watergate are being heard as the annual stockholder meeting season unfolds. At least 29 corporations have received share. holder resolutions that would limit political activities.

(UPI)-A Warren, R. I,, man fell 140 feet from a bridge into the Taunton Rivertoday and sur vived. The police Identified him as Carl Casala, 50 years old. He told the police that he had felt sick and had been leaning over a railing on the Braga Bridge when he fell. He was taken to St. Ann's Hospital,

LAS ANGELES, April 18-A group that took over control of the Pacific Holding Corporation about two years ago was deposed today by dissidents led by David H. Murdock, a Los Angeles real-estate developer.

Time Inc. announced a 23 per cent increase in its firstquarter earnings at its annual meeting here yesterday, as strong performances by the publishing and forest products divisions pushed profits to a record $10.4-million, or $1.01 per share.

The Rev, William W. Lindgren, director of television and radio for the Paterson (N. J.) Roman Catholic Diocesan communications center at Morristown, died April 11 of a heart ailment aboard the liner Rotterdam, on a cruise to Puerto Rico. His age was 47.

TORONTO-While many Western journalists have diligently attempted to report recent developments in relations between China and the United States and the Chinese domestic campaign against Lin Piao and Confucius, the esoterica to which attention has been paid has often seemed ludicrous.

About 5 per cent of the welfare cases in the category of aid to families with. dependent children, the biggest component of the city's welfare case load, are being dropped because of failure to prove eligibility, state and city officials said yesterday.

Several hundred thousand pounds of vegetable and animal oils, intended for mixing with the feed of chickens and other animals but contaminated with the insecticide dieldrin, have been recalled from sale by dealers in Mississippi and Arkansas, spokesmen for the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday.
A man was convicted today of murdering a Morris Township liquor store clerk during a holdup attempt in 1969. His co-defendant was acquitted.

Friends of Harold Geneen may rest assured that he will be able to get by. Last year he got a $19 a week increase. If he had been paid at the Federal minimum wage rate, he would have been getting, for forty hours, $64. A $19 increase would then have meant a boost of 30 per cent.

Bizarre Plants - Magical, Monstrous, Mythical, by William A. Emboden (Macmillan, $10.95). An illustrated history. Blood of My Blood: The Dilemma of the Italian-Americans, by Richard Gambino (Doubleday, $7.95).

--Rafael Misas Bravo is a 50year-old mechanic who has voted with this nation's political Establishinent all his life. But' he is planning to cast his ballot for the anti-Establishment opposition in next Sunday's presidential election because he feels the country needs a change.

Erik Satie will be dead half a century next year, but he refuses to lie down and be immortalized. The French composer's peculiar artistic personality, which mixes humor with solemnity, secular banality with muddled mysticism and naivete with sophistication, continues to keep him from being a truly popular composer, and therefore perhaps has enshrined him as an idol of the John Cage wing of the avant-garde.

THE RACHEL PAPERS. By Martin Amis. 228 pages. Knopf. $5.95. "Pure beauty drives those who are willing and able enough for its reception back into the depths of their inner self. It supersedes all their other interests, isolates them and makes them feel sad.
The executive vice president of the American Ship Building Company pleaded guilty today to concealing an illegal $25,000 contribution to President Nixon's re-election campaign.

- Strikes by postal workers and airport firemen spread across Canada today, disrupting mail deliveries and air traffic. Meanwhile, air traffic controllers threatened a strike that would virtually paralyze commercial air travel in Canada.
JAZZ Two of the longest-running regular jazz series in town do their jamming from noon to 3 every Friday. Jazz at Noon, which turns loose in the Rough Rider Room of the Hotel Roosevelt,

ATHENS, April 18--Along with Zeus, Hermes and the rest of the crowd from Olympus, one of the great figures of Greek mythology is an Englishman who died here 150 years ago tommorowGeorge Gordon, Lord Byron.

Key short-term interest rates have moved up again and business loan demand continues strong, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday, increasing the pressure on the banking industry to make the 10 1/4 prime rate initiated by the North Carolina Naional Bank last Thursday industry-wide.
The nation's two largest telephone companies filed plans yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission to operate jointly a domestic satellite system.

Rapid changes in the urban environment may sometimes depress and disorient the average citizen, but there is one class of citiZens for whom such changes have unquestionably served as a fecund source of esthetic inspiration: the photographers.

Stagehands put out a small backstage electrical fire during last night's performance of "Over Herel" at the Shubert Theater on West 44th Street. The musical, starring the Andrews Sisters, was not interrupted and there was no

In general, it was the orthodox yesterday who opposed a bill to prohibit discrimination against homosexuals, and the unorthodox who did not. Still, the lines were blurred, and the testimony everyone gave was not always edifying. Sometimes, in fact, it was arcane.

George J. Lent, who retired last year as a spokesman for the Board of Education, died yesterday in St. Anthony's Hospital, Warwick, N. Y., after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived at Greenwood Lake, N. Y.

YAPHANK, L.I.-The baby pigs looked just adorable and Pamela Murtaugh crouched to ??paress them when one suddenly snapped at her leg and bit her. Most people would have howled at the pain, but Miss Murtaugh simply shrugged and walked away.

Body searches were put into effect for all inmates' visitors at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men yesterday as the police hunted two men and two women who tried to free three prisoners Wednesday night with an acetylene torch. Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm conceded that except in rare suspicious cases "we have not been conducting searches" because "they weren't necessary before."

The nation's total output of goods and services dropped in the first quarter of this year ,by the largest amount since the recession of 1958, the Commerce Department reported today. The decline was at an annual rate of 5.8 per centsomewhat more than had been generally forecast at the beginWing of the year.
versity team broke the world record- for the seldom-run one-mile intermediate hurdies relay with a time of 3 minutes 37.8 seconds. The old mark was 3:40.5, set two weeks ago by Occidental College.

After a three-and-a-half-year battle, a bill to ban discrimination against homosexuals in employment, housing and public accommodations was voted out of the City Council's General Welfare Committee yesterday evening.

heartbreak kid of a year ago, put together a five-under-par 66 today for the first-round lead in the $150,000 Monsanto open. Fezler held a one-stroke-advantage over Lee Elde, Chuck Courtney and Chris Blocker, who were tied at 67.

Four executives and broadcasters of the National Broadcasting Company will address a memorial service at 1 P.M. today for Frank McGee, at Fran E. Campbell's Madison Avenue at 81st Street. They are Julian Goodman, chairman of the board; Stuart Schulberg,

Japan anti China will sign a civil aviation agreement in Peking tomorrow, a Foreign Ministry spokesman announced here today. The pact, first proposed when the two countries established diplomatic relations in 1972, will be signed by Japan's Ambassador in Peting, Heishiro Ogawa, and the Chinese Foreign Minister, Chi Pean-fei.

Wage and price controls will probably be reimposed in two Or three years unless business and labor-break the present wave of inflation, according to C. Jackson Grayson Jr., former chairman of the Price Commission.

The Navy and the Air Force, though both are traditionally volunteer forces, have found the transition to all-volunteer status anything but simple. Senior officers and enlisted men talk of poorly educated blacks seeking meaningful roles in machine-oriented services,

International President Anwar el Sadat of Egypt announced that Egypt would end more than 18 years of exclusive reliance on Soviet arms and seek arms from other sources. Mr. Sadat said he made the decision because the Soviet Union had not acted on Egyptian arms requests during the last six months.

Special to The New York Times TRENTON, April 18-A state police detective said today that he had been threatened by a deupty attorney general with a possible loss of pension if he testified for the defense in a Passaic County police-corruption trial.

DETROIT, April 18 - The American Motors Corporation announced today that its subsidiary, the A. M. General Corporation, had been awarded a $2-million contract to build 350 quarter-ton electric delivery vehicles for the Postal Service.

Bruce Jenner, former Graceland College .star, shattered the meet's decathlon record and Phil Ndoo of Eastern New Mexico set a meet standard for the six-mile run today in the Kansas Relays. Jenner raised his 10-event total to 8,240 points, wiping

The big turnout at yesterday's City Council hearing on a bill to bar discrimination against homosexuals is another indication of the strong emotions generated by a question that has confronted and confounded the Council for several years, Unfortunately, emotionalism has tended to dominate the debate and to obscure the real issue,
The New York Rangers solemnly. shook hands 'with the Montreal Canadiens and. exited from the ice in single file, their eyes on the ground as if they were in a funeral procession.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music is ending its threemonth British Theater Season with two anthology evenings from the Royal Shakespeare Company. Last night the R.S.C. offered "The Hollow Crown" and on Sunday will come "Pleasure and

Julius B. Perlmutter, who retired 15 years ago as head of J. B. Perlmutter Associates, Inc., merchandise brokers, died yesterday at Coney Island Hospital in Brooklyn. His age was 87, and he lived at 200 East 18th Street. Brooklyn.
Zaragoza, Spain--Jose Antonio Jimenez, 125 1/3 pounds, Spain, knocked out Elio Cotena, 125 1/2, Italy, 5 rounds. Las Vegas - Rocky DiFazio,

The Ministry of Justice has turned down a request by an investigating judge to have the disputed Euphronios vase in the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York examined by a team of Italian archeologists and scientists, it was learned today. Sources close to the case said the ministry's decision was

Business activity during 1974 looks better than it did a few months ago and a recession now looks unlikely, Paul W. McCracken, professor of business administration at the University of Michigan, said yesterday.
The head of the Massachusetts Republican State Committee has become the first Republican state chairman in the nation to ask for President Nixon's resignation. William A. Barnstead of Arlington,

Kibbutz Langdon contains 22 young Jewish people attempting a communal return to what they consider the roots of Jewish ritual and identity. This kibbutz, however, is not in Israel but on the Madison campus of the University of Wisconsin.

The Bureau of Prisons has decided to allow reporters to interview prisoners in "minimum security" Federal institutions. The policy change was disclosed by Solicitor General Robert H. Bork in a letter to the Supreme Court, made public today.
The New York Sets are making last-minute attempts to land two of the world's top tennis players. Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia and Virginia Wade of Britain,

Mrs. Lila N. Nichols of Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon in the nondenominational Unity Church of the Palm Beaches to Bradley Gaylord, retired president and chairman of the board of the Pennroad Corporation, now the Madison Fund, Inc. The Rev. Hal Rosencranz performed the ceremony.
The Harkness Ballet had a much-needed success at the Harkness Theater on Wednesday night with the world premiere of Margo Sappington's "Rodin, Mis en Vie."

Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 44 points but the Milwaukee Bucks had to turn back a fourth-quarter rally tonight to defeat the Chicago Bulls, 113-111, in a National Basketball Association Western Conference playoff.

CAIRO, April 18-President Anwar el-Sadat announced today that Egypt had decided to end more than 18 years of exclusive reliance on Soviet arms supplies and to-seek armaments from other sources. The Soviet Union directly and through East European countries,

Roger W. Rowland, president emeritus of the board of trustees of the- Pennsylvania State University, University Park, Pa., died Sunday at the Jameson Memorial Hospital, New Castle, Pa. He was 79 years old and lived in New Castle.

ALBANY, April 18 - A bill that would have allowed contraceptives to be displayed on pharmacy, shelves was defeated in the Assembly today after a long debate in which onpodents asserted that such displays would lead to greater promiscuity among the young.

Wage and price controls will probably be reimposed in two or three years unless business and labor break the present wave of inflation, according to C. Jackson Grayson Jr., former chairman of the Price Commission.

The nation's total output of goods and services dropped in the first quarter of this year by the largest amount since the recession of 1958, the Commerce. Department reported today. The decline was at an annual rate of 5.8 per cent-somewhat more than had been generally forecast at the begining of the year.

WASHINGTON, April 18 United States District Judge John J. Sirica ordered today the issuing of a subpoena, commanding President Nixon to turn over tape recordings and other records of 64 White House conversations relating to the Watergate cover-up.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (Reuters)-Redemptions of mutual fund shares exceeded sales in. March by $49.7-million, the Investment Company Institute reported today. This compared with net redemptions of $87.9-million in February and $12.1-million in March of last year. Sales of mutual funds in March rose to $29659. million from $215.1-million. Redemptions rose to $346.7-million from $303.1-million.

DETROIT, April 18--The General Motors Corporation disclosed today that its chairman, Richard C. Gerstenberg, received a 5.5 per cent raise last year, lifting his total compensation by $48,037 to $923,000 and keeping him well in the lead as the highest paid executive in the country.

With the Knicks trailing the Boston Celtics, 2 games to 0, and desperately needing a victory tonight at Boston in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Conference championship series, Coach Red Holzman will take a 'desperate gamble.

' In early March I became aware that something important had changed. I had stopped being a sports fan. News that the baseball teams were Spring training added no salt to life's daily routine (Nixon, taxes, bills and toil) and the approach of the basketball. playoffs gave no lift to tired blood.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 19--The desert wind died down today and the perfect golfing conditions that resulted made more difference to some than to others in the second round of the Colgate-Dinah Shore Winners Circle $200,000 tournament; Peter Oosterhuis putting 6 feet for an eagle on the sixth green at Pensacola, Fla.

PARTICIPANTS: The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post, negotiating as the Publishers Association of New York City, and New York Typographical Union No. 6, representing 819 printers, including .170 substitutes, at The Times; 945 printers, including 200 to 220 substitutes, at The News; and 312 printers, including 38 substitutes, at The Post.

When Golda Meir's divided Labor party met in Tel Aviv this week to consider the choice of a successor to the 75-year old Premier, a group of demonstrators marched outside the hall chanting and bearing placards inscribed, "Not Dayan and not the kitchen cabinet."
LONDON, April 19-A coroner said today that Desmond Donnelly, a Labor party member of Parliament from 1950 to 1968, killed himself with an overdose of drugs.
IN THE DARK FUTURE The New York Science Fiction Film Society is six months old, but it is already into the series business.

Before the Arab oil embargo so abruptly made us aware of our longbrewing energy crisis, most people were ready to solve the problems of cities by running away from them to suburban complexes of offices and homes.
Monsignor Farrell High School of Staten Island produced a swift anchor leg yesterday to win the championship two-mile relay as the Queens-Iona Relays opened at Queens College in Flushing.

The television networks next fall will cut back in programs that deal with violence and stress series concerned with family life and personal relationships. That is evident from the new prime-time schedules for September disclosed yesterday by both the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System.
Syria and Israel today fought their first air battle over the Golan Heights front since the October war. Artillery duels continued on the ground for the 39th day.
New orders flowing to manufacturers of durable goods declined in March after two months of increases but the unfilled order backlog continued to rise, the Commerce Department reported today.

WARSAW, April 19--Leaders of the seven Communist nations comprising the Warsaw Pact organization have gone home after a two-day meeting at which they declared themselves ready to continue seeking peace while remaining militarily vigilant.

A group of high rollers from the Broadway Association, representing assorted well-intentioned businessmen, propose that the addition of gambling casinos would help "revitalize" Times Square into a glittering Las Vegas Square.

Sam Y. Cross, a 46-year-old career civil servant, was named yesterday by President Nixon as United States executive director of the International Monetary Fund. His appointment is subject to Senate approval. Mr. Cross, who is Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Monetary and Investment Affairs,

Onny Parun of New Zealand came back after a terrible first set today and upset top-seeded Arthur Ashe, 2-6, 6-2, 6-4, in the quarterfinal round of the $50,000 River Oaks-American General tennis tournament.

Lillian Nassau, the nation's top art nouuveau dealer, bought her first Louis Comfort Tiffany wisteria lamp in 1956 for $175. She soon sold that lamp--a sinuous, bronzebased design crowned by a leaded, shade aswirl with vibrantly colored blossoms of laminated glass-for $275.

The defense rested yesterday in the Mitchell-Stans trial with Maurice H. Stans, badly shaken and ashen-faced, conceding that there were discrepancies between his grand jury and trial testimony, but angrily denying that they were lies.

Obviously undaunted by the failure of Julie Andrews's expensive television series of last season, the same producers are now presenting a British-made, postscript "special" titled "Julie and Dick in Covent Garden.

Charging "one' of' the most egregious and systematic frauds in the entire history of cooperative conversions," State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that his office was seeking to return an entire cooperative apartment building on the East Side to rental status and place it under rent control.
Key state legislators today praised Raymond T. Schuler, the Commissioner' of Transportation, as a possible successor to Dr. William J. Ronan as Chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

The Supreme Court, which has been ordering employers to bar. gain with unions for'years, has refused to recognize a local that was organized to represent a 50-member police force assigned to the Court.

The real playoff pressure now is on the Kentucky Colonels, who have to win their next game to keep from being swept out of their American Basketball Association Eastern final series against New York..
The New York Mets lost an opportunity yesterday to break their losing slide of seven games-or to make it eight-when rain canceled the opening of a weekend series against the Pittsburgh Pirates.

South Vietnam's President Thieu must be heartened at the degree of carelessness conveniently exposed in some Pentagon accounting office. Dismay was mounting in Saigon--and at the Department of Defense-that South Vietnam's war effort might have to be sharply curtailed in the coming weeks if the United States did not provide an extra $474 million in military aid for the period through June 30.

(Reuters)-The controller of the currency proposed today new regulations that would require the trust departments of national banks to make public substantially more information about their activities.

The report of R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., issued yesterday showed a 1.1 per cent decline in first-quarter earnings. It was the first quarterly decline by the company in more than a year and a half and compares with a 9.6 per cent fourth quarter profit gain.
A Federal judge refused today to grant a new trial to N. Dale Anderson and directed the Baltimore County Executive to appear May 1 for sentencing for extortion and income tax evasion.
James E. Durkin, who had been an investment counselor with Kidder, Peabody Co., on Wall Street, died Wednesday of cancer at his home, 7 Fairview Road in Scarsdale, N. Y. He was 76 years old.
Mrs.Helen Stevenson Meyner has reconsidered her earlier decision not to run and will seek the Democratic Congressional nomination in the 13th District, a source close to her said today .
Poland beat Hungary in the first singles match of European Zone Davis 'Cup play today. The second match was suspended by darkness.
District Court Judge William Hatten granted today a change of venue from Houston to San Antonio in the murder trial of '17-year-old Elmer Wayne Henley.

Mrs. Miriam Thalenberg Bricker, a lawyer and the wife of Dr. Neal S. Bricker, chairman of the- department of medicine at. Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died yesterday of cancer in the college hospital.

The Ethyl Corporation extended yesterday for the third time its tender offer for the common stock of the VCA Corporation.

Brezhnev, the Communlet party leader, is part of a long-term effort to upgrade the Russian diet by greater production of meat and dairy products. Egg production at a factory near Leningrad. The Soviet Union has unveiled a long-term effort to upgrade the Russian diet with greater production of meat and poultry.

Harry F. Simpson, treasurer of James F. Fox, Inc., a New York public-relations concern, of which he had been a founder in 1961, died Thursday at New York Hospital following a stroke. He was 78 years old and lived at 45 East 66th Street.

Robert A. Maheu's grandson was born in Mexico in 1970 so that the child could own properties there, a Federal trial jury was told here today. The jury is hearing evidence in Mr. Maheu's defamation suit against the Howard R. Hughes interests.

Five detectives who served in the Police Department's special investigations unit were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges that they had extorted or stolen sums ranging from $70,000 to $230,000 from drug dealers.

The pressure of a large number of leftover sell orders once again caused May potato futures to drop the 50-point limit early yesterday. Despite a rally, the closing price was down the limit at 16.50 cents a pound, off from 17 cents on Thursday, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

The felony trial of Ted Patrick, who calls himself a "deprogramer" of young people, resumes here tomorrow. Mr. Patrick, a 43-year-old San Diego man, is charged with second-degree kidnapping, false imprisonment and conspiracy.

There was no joy in Metsville last night. And the gloom could become much worse unless Tom Seaver returns to the form that earned him the Cy Young Award last season. French Foreign Minister, Michel Jobert, who returned today. from a relaxed Common Market ministrial meeting in Bonn, has redefined French policy in a distinctly new and more moderate way.

The death of Jimmy Kay left a large gap in Bergen County coaching ranks. Kay, who was basketball coach at Hackensack High School for II years, died of a heart attack on April 6. Kay's passing shocked the many persons who knew him or knew about him. He was only 44 year old.

Representative - elect J. Bob Traxler, the first Democrat to win Michigan's Eigth Congressional District seat in 42 years, said today that he would take no stand' on impeaching President Nixon until the House Judiciary Committee completed its findings.

A Manhattan jury yesterday convicted a 34-year-old Albanian of murder but acquitted his brother and cousin in the revenge slaying of a fourth Albanian immigrant outside Maxwell's Plum, a popular restaurant at 64th Street and First Avenue, one night two years ago.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy tried out American-style public opinion polling on an audience at Moscow State University today and drew some hostility from a generally silent audience when he asked for a show of hands on whether the Soviet Union should be spending more or less on defense.

Jo Ann Prentice, an Alabama country club owner who had won only four tournaments in 18 years, took the richest event in women's golf today by winning the fourth playoff hole from Jane Blalock with a 3 1/2-foot putt.

The nation's economic performance in the first quarter of this year was almost certainly the most alarming of the entire postwar period. Real output declined at an annual rate of 5.8 per cent, the sharpest drop in gross national product in sixteen years. The Central Committee of Israel's dominant Labor party cleared the way for the selection of a candidate to succeed Premier Golda Meir, who resigned April 11. The life of the present five-member Board of Education -the. interim body appointed to oversee the transition to a decentralized system-ends on June 30th. Thus the news hasn't traveled very far that Connecticut is likely this year to become the first state to elect as governor a woman who is a successful politician in her own right rather than the wife or widow of one.

The state announced today that it planned to delay for seven months, until Feb. I, the institution of tougher standards for the mandatory state test of auto emissions. The program calls for tightening the emissions standards each year for three years.

A regulation under which most persons seeking to influence decisions of the Federal Energy office would be required to regsister as lobbyists has been proposed by John W. Gardner, chairman of Common Cause.
One of the Senate's most junior members waged a floor fight today against a pet bill of one of the Senate's most powerful members. Seniority won easily.

Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today the names of 12 appointees-in. cluding two officials of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations-to the advisory council on Social Security.

About half the staff members who interpret at United Nations sessions stayed out on sick leave today to protest against overwork and understaffing. The one-day action forced the cancellation of eight of the 11 scheduled meetings, including two General Assembly sessions.
Governor Wilson, exercising his power to create new judgeships under the state's special narcotics enforcement program, nominated seven new judges today.
Thirty years of primitive living in a mountainous Philippine jungle may have made former Lieut. Hiroo Onoda one of the healthiest 52-year-old men in Japan today.

The House Commerce Committee voted today to roll back the price of roughly 80 per cent of the crude oil produced in the United States. At the same time, the committee adopted an amendment that would impose a system of stiffer price controls on imported oil.
The Exxon Corporation and Texaco, Inc., two of the largest multinational oil companies, yesterday reported sharp firstquarter gains in profits, continuing their outstanding performance of late 1973.
The New York Times Company reported yesterday consolidated net income for the quarter ended March 31 of $4.8million, or 43 cents a share, up 20' per cent from the same quarter last year.

A 4-year-old girl whose disappearance in South Jersey set off a widespread hunt two weeks ago was found dead last night in a tidal backwater about 15 miles from her home.

President died early today in a hospital, the presidential office said. His age was 74. Moderate Leftist Mr. Jonas, who was president since 1965, was a lifelong Socialist who never was a party firebrand, a marked exception in a country noted for flamboyant leaders of the left.

Two of the three parties in the coalition Cabinet that collapsed Jan. 26 agreed today to try to form a new government.
The Treasury said today that the United States position on gold "remains unchanged-we are not in favor of anything that tends to put gold back in the middle of the monetary system."

NEW HAVEN--The legendary town of Chelm is a haven for fools, and the greatest fool is Shlemiel. He is sent on a mission to spread wisdom to other lands but, tricked by a rogue, he unwittingly returns directly to his home.
Gas rushing from a main torn open by a high-pressure water jet was pinpointed by the Fire Department yesterday as the cause of Monday's office-tower explosion near the United Nations.

Some curators of the Louvre concede that art critics may be correct in questioning the authenticity as well as the quality of some paintings from Pablo Picasso's private collection that were donated to the museum by the late painter's heirs.

Graham Clay. tor Jr., said yesterday that, if the Interstate Commerce Commission approves a 10 per cent freight rate increase, there will be a "substantial" number of areas in which his system won't raise its rates the full 10 per cent and "some in which we can't concur in any increase at all."

Honeywell, Inc., said yestetrday that it was introducing its new "60 series" of computers consisting of large and small systems that are fully compatable with all earlier Honeywell systems. With special "bridges" of hardware and software, the new series is also compatible with competitive systems.

The Naismith Memorial Basket-ball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., will be the scene today of considerable activity when tribute is paid to the Passaic High School Wonder Team of 1919-1925. Passaic's winning streak of 159 games-longest in the history of basketball--will be recognized formally with the dedication of a display picturing each of the six teams and a game-by-game score of each victory and the opponent.

A strange epidemic suddenly hit the children of the West Point Elementary School this afternoon, and many of them called in sick just before the New York Yankees began their exhibition game with the West Point Cadets.

Tyler Jr. refused yesterday to return a teacher to James Monroe High School in the Bronx from which he had been transferred because he recently showed sexual intercourse filmstrips to a biology class. Potato futures for May delivery dropped the daily limit on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday for the fifth consecutive session. The close was 15.50 cents a pound, down the 50-point limit from 16 cents a pound Monday.

The company, which opened last night with his staging of Tchaikovsky's "The Sleeping Beauty," will be in residence for two weeks.

A spokesman for the Central Railroad of New Jersey said yesterday that the railroad would restore service to Phillipsburg in Warren County next month. Since 1967, Jersey Central passenger service has run no farther than Hampton in Hunterdon County. President Nixon will begin tomorrow another series of speaking trips-part of his continuing effort to demonstrate that neither Watergate nor his other problems has robbed him of his leadership ability.
A Long Island businessman has been indicted on a charge of having defrauded two concerns of more than $190,000, the Manhattan District Attorney's office disclosed yesterday.

The Federal Reserve Board, in a strong signal of its anti-inflation policy, raised its discount rate today to a record level of 8 per cent. The increase was from 71/2 per cent, itself a record, established last August. The discount rate is the interest rate charged to banks temporarily short of funds that need to borrow from the Federal Reserve.
Helen Gourlay upset second-seeded Evonne Goolagong, 6-3, 3-6, 7-6, and reached the quarter final of the $50,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament tonight at the Palestra.

A large amount or Arab oil revenues has begun to flow West, including about $1-billion to the United States-a small but significant part of the vastly increased revenues the Persian Gulf states are obtaining for their oil.

Jack Nicklaus occupies his customary position as a solid favorite in the $200,000 Tournament of Champions, which starts tomorrow at the La Costa Country Club. But, grumbling about a bad arm, he isn't the overwhelming choice he often is. The event brings together those who have won on the regular pro golf tour in the last 12 months.
Stock prices fell sharply for the second consecutive session yesterday as investors' concern over rising interest rates and the inflationary spiral battered the market. Trading volume accelerated.

Twelve candidates are in the running to the presidency of France, a field so large that it is being looked upon here as a sign that the Gaullist system has broken down.

The House Ways and Means Committee set off a new round of Congressional hearings into national health insurance today by questioning Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, for five hours about details of the Administration's proposal.

The Tennessee Legislature. has become the second to rescind its ratification of the equal rights amendment. The House Voted 56 to 33 yesterday, to reverse its 1972 vote in favor of the amendment. Earlier this. year, the Senate voted 17 to 11 to rescind.

For a few months after his graduation in 1914 from high school in Ogden, Utah, Bernard DeVoto worked as a reporter on the newspaper there. "Later on," writes Wallace Stegner in this discreet, sympathetic and consistently interesting biography, "warring with the effete and literary in New York, he would belligerently assert his pride in being a 'mere' journalist."
Senate Democrats, in a change that reflected mounting anxiety about inflation and its effect on the November elections, endorsed today a limited extension of authority for wage-price controls.

The annual meeting of the American Newspapers Publishers Association was told here yesterday that a move toward 20-cent daily newspapers had been touched off by rising costs that had pushed the cost of paper and delivery to 25 cents for papers of 64 pages or more.

Should opera for the young try to be relevant? The question has for some time bothered the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, which has in the past presented traditional repertory in the schools in its educational program.

The two main scientific organizations that advise the Federal Government are starting an intensive study of world problems in population, food and energy to determine what must be done to avert a global crisis.

Luck. Casey Stengel said losers talk about it. And in hockey it's no different. The eighth of an inch that means a goal or a stopped shot always plays a role, especially during the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup playoffs.

A 16-year-old youth was arrested yesterday and held without bail on murder charges in the stabbing death of a 24year-old woman in St. Mary's Park in the Bronx two weeks ago.

Five civilian employes of the Police Department were arrested last night in the vicinity of Police Headquarters during a meal break and charged with possession of marijuana. Two were also charged with possession of deadly weapons: 5-inch gravity knives.
The names of a second group of 1,000 high school seniors were listed yesterday by the National Merit Scholarship Corporation as. winners of $1,000 nonrenewable college scholarships.

In a tape-recorded message that the authorities said appeared authentic, Patricia Hearst described herself today as a willing participant in last week's bank robbery. She said not only that her actions were voluntary, but also that the weapon she cartried was loaded and that she was prepared to use it.
The West German mark ruled the roost on world money markets today. The American dollar and the British pound declined and the price of gold also dropped.

President Nixon asked Congress today to authorize a total of $5.18-billion in foreign economic and military aid for the fiscal year beginning July 1. Included is a request for a $900-million package for the Middle East-$350-million for Israel, $250-million for Egypt, $207.5-million for Jordan and a. $100- million contingency fund, part of which seems intended for Syria.

Ben Kahn, Inc., New York manufacturer, and NeimanMarcus, Dallas specialty store chain, announced yesterday that they have purchased the entire 1974 crop of Black Willow mink, the costliest mink grown.

Sammy Davis Jr. has always been a powerhouse of a performer. He can tapdance with thunder, mimic his peers and sing Frank Sinatra songs as well as Frank Sinatra. He is a natural choice for a one-man showeven to fill the cavernous Uris Theater, where Tuesday he began a limited engagement (through May 4), his first Broadway appearance since "Golden Boy" in 1965.

Mrs. Natanya Neumann Manson, a former member of the Martha Graham dance company, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital at the age of 50. She was the wife of Harold P. Manson, director of the office of academic affairs of the American Friends of the Hebrew University, and lived at 320 Central Park West.

Despite all its financial woes, Consolidated Edison is planning to go ahead with its highly questionable pumped-storage generating plant at Storm King Mountain. As evidence continues to pile up that the controversial project may not be worth the company's investment and still less worth the environmental damage it may do, Con Edison may yet recognize this elevenyear-old albatross for what it is-and give it up once and for all.

Lawyers for the House Judiciary Committee will propose tomorrow that the scope of the impeachment inquiry be narrowed sharply to include only the most serious potential charges of wrongdoing by President Nixon.

The leaders of the Legislature have reached agreement on a plan to have the Power Authority of the State of New York buy two Consolidated Edison generating plants at a total cost of nearly $500-million.
Joseph B. Collinson has been named president of Textron, Inc. He succeeds G. William Miller, who was elected to the vacant position of chairman, while continuing as chief executive officer.

The House of Representatives authorized funds today to continue the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency for another year after killing a controversial provision that would have required it to file reports to Congress on the impact of major strategic-weapons systems on arms-control policies.
The Environmental Protection Agency issued today a rare emergency order to halt the sale of 28 pesticide sprays containing vinyl chloride, a chemical linked to a rare form of liver cancer.

Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, disclosed today that he had paid $725,004 in Federal income tax on an adjusted gross income of $3,067,753 for the years 1960-1973.

The Supreme Court refused by 6 to 3 today to grant a Florida widower a property tax exemption that the state gives to all widows. The majority maintained that it was permissible to discriminate against men in this instance because there was "a reasonable distinction" between the ability of men and women to cope financially after. the death of a spouse.

Joseph H. Quinn, former tax manager here for United States Steel International (New York) Inc., and a longtime resident of Westbury, L. I., died in Pittsburgh on Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack.

Dr. James Reinhardt, a nationally known, criminologist, died yesterday at the Lincoln Veterans Hospital. He was 79 years old. He leaves his wife, the former Cora Lee; a daughter, Mrs. Rolland Ritter, and three grandchildren.

Anna Elkan Meltzer, a painter and teacher whose impressionistic oils in diffused lights, angles and colors were widely known, died Monday in a hospital in Great Barrington, Mass. The widow of Samuel Meltzer, a photographer, she was 77 years old and had been living in Copake. N. Y.

IONESCOPADE, a vaudeville musical entertainment, from the works of Eugene lonesco; conceived and directed by Robert Allen Ackerman; music and lyrics by Mildred Kayden; choreography by Merry Lynn Katis; at Theater Four, 424 West 55th Street, 6:45.
Rejecting the recommendations of their union negotiators for the second time, editorial and commercial employes of The Washington Post voted today to end their 17-day-old strike.

The body of Rabbi Elliot D. Waldman, 46-year-old spiritual leader of Temple Emanu-El in Utica, was discovered Tuesday in Kayuta Lake in northern Oneida County by a-state trooper. The state police said the rabbi had died of asphyxiation from immersion in water and that there was no evidence of violence or any indication of chronic disease.
Dr. Herman Max Sternberg, orthopedic surgeon, died of a cardiac ailment yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 147 West 79th Street.

Bud Abbott, the tall, thin, I-am-not-amused straight man who fed Lou Costello the lines and the situations that got the pair into trouble and laid their audiences into the aisles with laughter, died of cancer yesterday in his home in Woodland Hills, a Los Angeles suburb. He was 78 years old.
The American Stock Exchange's market value index fell to its lowest point since Dec. 31, 1973 yesterday as prices continued to fall both on the Amex and the overthe-counter market.

Photographs by United States space flights have indicated what it is hoped may be a potentially rich cooper area in Nevada. Group studies to verify the mineral deposits and their extent are still under way.

The leaders of the Legislature have reached agreement on a plan to have the Power Authority of the State of New York buy two Consolidated Edison generating plants at a total cost of nearly $500-million.

A 6-year-old boy was attacked and killed by a neighbor's dog yesterday as he played on the lawn of his house in East Islip, L. I. The dog, a Saint Bernard, was shot to death by his owner, whom the police did not identify.
The House passed legislation today to provide $50,000 in Federal payments to the survivors of policemen, other local law enforcement officers and firemen killed in the line of duty.

The effectiveness of acupuncture in treating nerve deafness in children has been seriously questioned by Dr. Samuel Rosen, an otologist from New York who learned acupuncture methods three years ago when he was one of the first American physicians to visit China.

Striking workers apparently ignored today a Government warning of stern action against them. More strikes seemed imminent. Students and striking bus drivers stoned taxis in Addis Ababa today.

Governor Byrne gave new support today to controversial legislation that would give citizens the right to sue alleged polluters. The bill is opposed by a powerful alliance of business and labor.
Frederick (Cy) Williams, an outstanding major-league slugger who compiled a record of 251 home runs from the World War I era through the nineteentwenties; died here yesterday. His age was 86.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the counter market fell sharply yesterday in continued light trading.

Idealistic Portuguese Army officers, determined to restore democracy at home and peace to the African territories, appear to have succeeded-on their second attempt in five weeks-in overthrowing Premier Marcello Caetano's authoritarian Government. Sweeping rules changes were made yesterday in an effort, to enliven the National Football League games. Not since 1933 has the sport been so drastically altered.
Reflecting an unusually. strong performance in 1973 and the first quarter of 1974, the Monsanto Company yes terday raised its quarterly dividend for the second timein nine months.

John M. Doar, chief counsel of the House Judiciary Com mittee's impeachment in quiry, said publicly today that his staff was concentrat ing its investigation on seven broad areas of allegationsagainst President Nixon.

Earnings of United States corporations in the first quar ter of 1974 were 24 per cent higher than a year earlier but 4 per cent lower than in the fourth quarter of 1973, the First National City Bank reported yesterday.

A third cash fund controlled by H. R. Haldeman when he was White House Chief of Staff-consisting of a two-inch-thick stack of $20 and $100 bills-has come to light in testimony released today in a Watergate civil suit.

The New York Philharmonic will get a new concertmaster this summer, and yesterday afternoon he was introduced locally as soloist with the orchestra. He is Eliot Chapo, 28 years old, from Miami Beach and a graduate of the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, where he studied with Efrem Zimbalist and Oscar Shumsky.
The General Motors Corporation announced today that its earnings for the first quarter of 1974 declined by 85 per cent from the 1973 first quarter.

Representative Henry Helstoski, Democrat of the Ninth District, testified briefly today before a Federal grand jury investigating allegations that he accepted payoffs for sponsoring special immigration bills to protect aliens from deportation.

The Constitution requires mental hospitals to give treatment to patients committed against their wills, a Federal Appeals Court ruled today.

The prime rate for commercial bank loans-one of the basic interest rates in the nation's economy-moved to new high ground yesterday as the Franklin National Bank went to 11 per cent from 101/2 per cent, and several California banks went to 103/4.

The Mobil Oil Corporation, second largest in the nation, after Exxon, yesterday announced a 66 per cent increase in first-quarter net income to $258.6-million compared with $155.8-million in the same period last year.
Mrs. Marlene Stewart Streit shot one-under-par golf to defeat Mrs. Nancy Roth Syms, 5 and 3, today. It was her second North and South amateur tournament victory.

The trading stamp industry took another severe setback last year, primarily because of the gasoline shortage, and industry officials and observers say it may be 1975 before stamp savers and companies find substantial improvement.

Egyptian security authorities have arrested 75 persons, including 16 military cadets and two sailors, in an alleged plot to overthrow President Anwar elSadat, Cairo newspapers reported today.
The San Francisco Police Department said today it would appeal a Federal court order forbidding the city's massive stop-and-search operation in the so-called Zebra killings.
It will cost "approximately $6 million" to replace the 10,344 window panes in the new 60-inch story John Hancock Tower, officials say.
When the Southport-Westport Antiques Show opened here for the first time a decade ago, few dealers or collectors knew how rich and varied was the legacy of American 19th-century craftsmen.

The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation yesterday named Frederick Seitz, president of Rockefeller University, as its chairman of the board. Dr. Seitz has been on the foundation's board for two years. The announcement was made by the outgoing chairman; James F. Gates Jr., at the annual meeting of the foundation here. Dr. Seitz, a former president of the National Academy of Sciences, became president of Rockefeller. University in 1968.

Bronze plaques marking the graves of nine historical figures, including Benjamin Franklin and his wife, Deborah, have been stolen from the Christ Church burial grounds here, the police said yesterday. The police said the plaques, valued collectively at $2,000 had probably been removed by collectors.
The Rangers and Philadelphia Flyers walked around with swollen faces yesterday, but the New Yorkers were smiling just a bit more through their expensive bridgework.

A fire that authorities called suspicious damaged the basement of a synagogue in Astoria, Queens, yesterday afternoon, about two hours after a group of teen-agers were reported to have broken into the building and committed acts of vandalism. No one was injured.

Senate investigators have concluded that excessive secrecy and concentration of power in the Presidency gave rise to the Watergate scandal, and they have drafted recommendations to drastically diffuse that power as a safeguard against any recurrence.
Mrs. Elizabeth R. Kearns, an elementary-school teacher whose career spaned 66 years, died today in Nassau Hospital, Minneola, She was 88 years old, and lived at 26 Hamilton Place here.

American General Reserve Fund, Inc., a newly-organized mutual fund that will invest in money-market securities, has registered 2 million common shares to be offered at an initial price of $25 per share.

Miss.Anne Wilson, daughter of Mrs. Henry Mayer Wilson of Madison, N.J., and the late Mr. Wilson, was married yesterday evening to Pfc. John Robert Custer, U.S.A. son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Joseph Custer of New Providence. N.J.

Allegheny Ludlum Industries will proceed with plans for a 10-year expansion program in flat rolled steel, Roger S. Ahlbrandt, chairman, told the annual meeting of shareholders today.

The Louis Harris Survey gives the Democrats a 23-point advantage over Republicans in November Congressional elections, the largest margin it has ever reported.

Asserting that it had no power to supersede a local school board, the State Board of Regents today tabled a proposal by Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, its lone black member, to establish a special commission to desegregate the New York City school system.
Striking Canadian postal workers returned to their jobs today, ending a walkout that had virtually paralyzed mail service throughout the country for nearly two weeks.

John C. Sawhill, the new head of the Federal Energy Office, said today that the agency was reviewing its standard for determining how much an international oil company can charge itself for imports of its own crude oil.
Joseph A. Hoffman, State Commissioner of Labor and Industry, today announced a $200,000 tourist promotion campaign to bolster proposed legalized gambling as an attraction here.

Plans call for a restaurant, theater, shops and 20 condominiums, all under one large roof designed to capture enough solar energy to provide 85 per cent of the heating needed in winter.

To the Editor: As a plaintiff and participant in several of the lawsuits referred to in your editorial of April 15, challenging New York State's inequitable Congressional and legislative districting laws, I applaud your condemnation of the way district lines have traditionally been carved out here, but I question the effectiveness of the remedy you propose.

Miss Anne Wilson, daughter of Mrs. Henry Mayer Wilson of Madison, N. J., and the late Mr. Wilson, was married yesterday evening to Pfc. John Robert Custer, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Joseph Custer of New Providence, N. J.

Arbert Reimann: a name that will be new to most American concertgoers. He is a German composer, born in 1936, and on Thursday night Pierre Boulez and the New York Philharmonic presented the American premiere of his "Zyklus," or cycle, for baritone and orchestra. Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, to whom the work is dedicated, was the singer.

Henry Aaron, the major league's career homer run king, broke another record last night when he hit the 15th grand slam of his 21-year career. Aaron's homer was his sixth of the season and No. 719 lifetime.

At the The Churchill Race Track Downs meeting will start tomor row, with the Stepping Stone purse as one of the main attractions. This race, too, will have a comparatively big field, with 13 named on the overnight list.

Gary Kilpatrick, Princeton University's lightweight crew coach, works hard to make sure that his oarsmen never rest. Now in his second year as varsity coach, he is putting the Princeton crew through a training regimen that is tougher than ever, as the lightweights prepare to defend their position at the top of Eastern rowing.

A seven-man trade between the Yankees and Cleveland Indians, announced moments after New York had defeated the Texas Rangers, 4-3, at Shea Stadium last night, created an air of shock in the Yanks dressing room.

The decision of District Attorney Kuh to drop election fraud charges against Assembly Speaker Duryea makes no less reprehensible the deceptive political practices on which the charges were based. Defects in the Election Law, a monstrosity jointly concocted by Republicans and Democrats to protect incumbents and harass challengers, virtually eliminated any chancee of a conviction on appeal.

In contrast with the small size and sparse resources of Portugal, her African posses-ions-particularly Angola-are vast storehouses of actual and potential wealth in the form of oil, iron ore, diamonds, coal, coffee and tropical produce.
Roslyn Diehl Young, a former executive of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, died Monday in the Powhatan Nursing. Home, Falls Church, Va., at the age of 77.
Mrs. Ellen Shealy West, as. sistant personnel director of Time Inc., died Wednesday at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital after a series of strokes. She was 51 years old and lived in Wilton, Conn.
Republican leaders from around the country turned the silent treatment today on the latest White House effort to identify an embattled, President Nixon with party candidates for office this year.

Bearings for Re-Establishment, an agency established eight years ago to help former priests and nuns make the transition to secular life, has ceased operation. The agency had helped more than 5,500 people.
David Valentino, former sheriff of Cumberland County, says he will appeal a conviction by the County Court that he had allowed two inmates out of jail to work without supervision.

Shaken and sobered, a mere shard of his former self, S. J. Perelman has just returned from prolonged exposure to the undiscovered country from which no caviller returns.

A passenger in a dark car spotted' Eamonn Coghlan in the familiar blue Villanova sweatsuit warming up outside of Franklin Field for the distance medley relay today.

An audience composed largely of hunters of Nazi war criminals, including several persons who were survivors of massacres of Jewish populations, yesterday heard Gen. Leonard F. Chapman Jr., the Immigration Commissioner, give an accounting of his agency's pursuit of the fugitives.
A five-mile-long, half-mile wide cloud of fumes spread over Chicago's Far South Side today. The police said at least 16,000 persons had been told to leave their homes.

The century-old Princeton University Glee Club came to Carnegie Hall on Thursday night for a celebratory concert. The ensemble now has as many women as men students, adding up to an appropriate total of 100 singers. With them came an instrumental group, made up of students and area musicians; with that fine professional violinist Nadia Koutzen as concertmaster.

The general who assumed the leadership of Portugal yesterday after the swift military coup said today that a provisional government of civilians headed by a military man would be formed in three weeks. He promised general elections in one year.

Five civilians were tried secretly yesterday and sentenced to death by an army court-martial in San Fernando, a farming center about 80 miles south of here, according to church sources. The five men were identified as Nelson Gonzalez.

Samuel J. Friedman, who over the years has done publicity for many major Broadday producers, died yesterday, apparently of heart failure, in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.
Suffolk County's Chief Medical Examiner said today that "we will never know" why a St. Bernard dog attacked and killed a 6-year-old boy last Wednesday in East Islip.

Little Bud Allin, who insists he's no big deal and plays golf "one stroke at a time," increased his lead to four strokes today in an elite field of 25 golfers as the 22d annual Tournament of Champions reached its halfway point.

The ensemble now has as many women as men students, adding up to an appropriate total of 100 singers. Governor Wilson dealt cautiously with the remaining issues before the Legislature today, offering few details of his position on such questions as help for the New York City budget, rent control and Port Authority bonds.

A film dealing with revolutionary activities in Mozambique, which feature prominently in the page-one news on Portugal, is included in the new screen program showing through Wednesday at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

The salary of the average college professor rose to $17,810 in the current academic year, but faculty members lost ground economically, the American Association of University Professors reported today.

The last liver pate, the last lobster bisque and the last cheese souffle were served at Pierre's yesterday afternoon, and another modest New York landmark disappeared.

West German Chancellor Willy Brandt said in Parliament today that he had kept a suspected Communist spy on his personal staff to help security forces crack an espionage ring at the heart of the West German Government.

Employes of the Atlantic Chemicall Corporation began to pick up the debris today from the thunderous explosion last night that extensively damaged part of the industrial dye plant here and shook the surrounding neighborhood.
A 7-year-old Brooklyn boy hitching on the rear on a Transit Authority bus was killed when he jumped off and then was struck by a car, about a block from his home in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section.

A gang of armed art thieves directed by a young woman raided the mansion of a gold-mining millionaire here late last night, tied up everyone in the house and got away with masterpieces valued by the police at $19.2-million.

Harry H. Wachtel, a longtime member of the board of directors of the Rapid-American Corporation, has resigned in an apparent dispute with the consumer-goods conglomerate's flamboyant chairman, Meshulam Riklis.
State Attorney General William F. Hyland openly broke with Governor Byrne today over a proposed voter referendum on statewide casino gambling in New Jersey.
Secretary of State Kissinger strongly defended the Administration's foreign policy today against any suggestion that President Nixon was trying to manipulate it for domestic political advantage.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today that member thrift institutions gained $1.8-billion in deposits in March despite a rapid outflow of savings at month's end. Except for the unusually high rate of withdrawals in late March, the net gain would have exceeded $2-billion for only the second time in 14 months, an official said.
Profits reported by major oil companies for the first quarter have shown increases averaging nearly 80 per cent from a year ago, but some analysts estimate that they may be much higher.

Refusing to hang up his sneakers after the recent season of limited action, Jerry West signed a longterm contract yesterday with the Los Angeles Lakers that will assure him of playing at least one more (his 15th) season with the National Basketball Association team.

Mindful of the fact that June will soon be busting out all over, and mindful of the fact that people are still getting married, and mindful of the fact that most brides think they need plates and glasses (also known as china and crystal), Georg Jensen held a little wingding the other night.
Declaring that his job was "no longer any fun," John H. (Jack) Krumpe resigned yesterday as president of the New York Racing Association.

City Health Department inspectors yesterday confiscated "several dozen" products that were made in Haiti from untanned goatskin-with the hair still attached. They said the products might be contaminated with anthrax, an acute bacterial disease.

The "grand design" of President John F. Kennedy, revealed in a notable speech in Philadelphia in 1962, envisioned an increasingly united European community linked inexorably with the United States by the bond of "Atlantic partnership."

The Ohio Valley conference established today a postseason basketball tournament, matching the league's top four finishers, to determine its future representatives in the National Collegiate Tournament.
In a shift, the Assembly today voted to have the state retail the power to impose a 2.5 per cent surtax on personal income. It did so by simply suspending the tax for another year.

Charles J. Nourse, retired senior partner in the law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam Roberts, 40 Wall Street, died Thursday at his home, 115 East 67th Street. He was 86 years old and also lived at Oyster Bay, L. 1.

Judge Martin Ginsberg of Nassau Family Court was indicted today on charges of soliciting and receiving $8,000 in bribes for promises of political favors in 1970 and 1971, while he was a State Assemblyman.

The current Martha Graham season at the Mark Hellinger Theater has been particularly interesting not only for the number of works that have been revived from the Graham repertory, but also equally for the number of dancers assuming new roles, either for the first time in New York or the first time in their careers. Incidentally, the nightly programs have religiously documented these debuts, which I think is very interesting for the general public.

Emil J. Sady, deputy director of the Public Administration Division of the United Nations Secretariat, collapsed and died while playing tennis last Saturday in Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y., where he lived. He was 57 years old.

Henry Fonda, who collapsed Tuesday with what physicians called "total exhaustion," was not released from Lenox Hill Hospital as expected yesterday because of a worsening of his condition. Mr. Fonda collapsed after a performance of his oneman show, "Clarence Darrow," at the Helen Hayes Theater.

The Justice Department today rejected Mississippi's proposed open primary law on grounds that it would discriminate against black voters. Under the proposal no candidate could be elected with less than a majority vote,

President Nixon will reportedly seek public support next week for a decision. to give the House Judiciary Committee transcripts rather than tape recordings of Watergate-related conversations subpoenaed for the impeachment inquiry.

Prices of wheat and soybean futures dropped sharply on the Midwest commodity exchanges yesterday, while the nearby corn deliveries were bid up a few cents a bushel.

Tim Spencer, originator of the Western singing group, the Sons of the Pioneers, died today at a convalescent hospital. He was 65 years old.
Vice President Ford, in his first major speech on economic policy, endorsed today the use of tax incentives to expand industrial capacity in industries where there are shortages.

In news conferences in St. Louis, Kansas City, and Jefferson City, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, announced yesterday he was a candidate for re-election. Mr. Eagleton, briefly a candidate for the Vice-Presidency in 1972until it was disclosed that he had once undergone shock treatments for depressionproposed that he and his Republican opponent, Thomas B. A five-judge criminal appeals court today upheld a lower court decision sentencing three Americans to life imprisonment for conspiring to smuggle drugs into Turkey. The session lasted five minutes.

Mark Belger brought the Franklin Field crowd to its feet today with a tremendous effort on the anchor leg of the schoolboy distance medley relay.
A Nassau County patrolman was charged today with having given a spurious summons for speeding to a woman motorist who was actually out of the state on a visit to Florida.

Four new buildings on the Brooklyn College campus in Flatbush were dedicated formally yesterday in ceremonies at which Mayor Beame reaffirmed his support for free tuition and open admissions throughout the City University. The new buildings, which cost $65-million, contain nearly a million square feet of floor space, nearly doubling the college's classroom space at its main campus.
Virginia wade, Britain's newly named Federation Cup captain, advanced to the semifinal round of the $50,000 Virginia Slims of Philadelphia tennis tournament tonight.

A hand grenade was thrown Into a wedding reception last night attended by Premier Long Boret, killing five persons and wounding 15. Government sources said. The Pre mier was not injured.

The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market closed with small gains yesterday in slower trading. Walter S. Logan, general counsel and vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York from 1928 to 1953, died Thursday in Washington, Conn., where he lived. His age was 85.
The special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, strongly defended Judge John J. Sirica today against charges of bias and prejudice in the Watergate cover-up case.

Senator Henry M. Jackson accuses President Nixon of seeking to offset his Watergate troubles by rushing into a "quick-fix" strategic arms agreement at June's summit meeting in Moscow. The Washington Democrat has long contended that the accords signed two years ago in the initial round of strategic arms limitation talks (SALT I) seriously disadvantaged the United States.

An internal Atomic Energy Commission study released today contains a warning on what it called "entirely inadequate" safeguards to prevent the theft by terrorist groups of uranium and plutonium for the manufacture of homemade atomic bombs.

The San Diego Chargers' general manager, Harland Svare, and eight players have been fined a total of $40,000 and placed on probation for violation of National Football League drug policies, Commissioner Pete Rozelle announced yesterday.

Francois Mitterrand, single candidate of the leftist alliance for the presidency of France, was nearing the end of his hourlong speech before a rapt audience of 17,000 that filled the Lyons sports palace from the rostrum to the highest row of the third balcony.

The Daily News estimated yesterday that it would lose about 200 pages of advertising from tomorrow's newspaper as a result of increasing pressure through a slowdown by printers represented by Typographical Union No. 6.

The gasoline shortage cost New Jersey almost $6-million in lost tax revenues, it was reported. The state's Tax Director, Sidney Glaser, said unofficial figures showed that motor-fuel tax income was down more than 8 per cent for December, January and February. "This loss of revenue is a direct result of the energy crisis," he said.

Senate investigators have concluded that excessive secrecy and concentration of power in the Presidency gave rise to the Watergate scandal, and they have drafted recommendations to drastically diffuse that power as a safeguard against any recurrence.

A woman who underwent surgery two years ago to become a man and then married and later sought a divorce, charging abandonment by the "wife," was denied the divorce yesterday on the ground that the marriage was illegal.

Foreign Minister Michel Jobert, who personified France's policy of independence of the United States under the late President Georges Pompidou, today threw his support behind the official Gaullist candidate, Jacques Chaban-Delmas, for the presidency of France.
The Constitution requires mental hospitals to give treatment to patients committed against their wills, a Federal Appeals Court ruled today.

But now the Nets, not the Knicks, are the team in a championship series.

Canada has told the European Common Market that it would like to intensify Its relations with Europe by negotiating a trade treaty with the nine-nation trade bloc, a Common Market spokesman confirmed today.

Colleges and graduate schools retain free to use race as a special consideration in admissions decisions following the Supreme Court's refusal to rule on the merits of the DeFunis "reverse discrimination" case last week, but some campus officials see pressure in the decision to substitute in the future color-blind criteria such as an applicant's social and economic background.
TRENTON, April 29--The State Assembly approved a proposed constitutional amendment tonight that would authorize casino gambling in New Jersey.

Putting on their best diplomatic manner, police officials and civic leaders entertained United Nations and consular personnel at a buffet luncheon with white wine yesterday and then showed them techniques to use against crime - which one police lecturer described as "the negative behavior of some of our citizens."

Tony Waldrop, whose philosophy of competing is explained across the front of his tee shirt-"Run for Fun"--was selected yesterday by the Track Writers Association as the outstanding athlete of the indoor season.
A Federal District Court judge said today that a city had no right to impose limits on its annual population growth and issued a permanent injunction that was sought by developers.

Six years have gone by since the late Walter P. Reuther led his United Auto Workers out of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., complaining that it had become a complacent, contented pillar of the status quo, devoid of either initiative or idealism. Institutionally, not much has changed inside the federation since that walkout.

The Museum of American Folk Art, which began 13 years ago as the first institution in the city devoted to this booming field, is being investigated by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's office as to its financial condition and the disposition of certain art objects from its collection.

Pan American- World Airways, Inc., reported yesterday a $24.4-million net loss for this year's first quarter. It was the second worst showing of any calendar quarter in the company's history. (in the first quarter of 1972 Pan Am had a net loss of $37.9- million.)
The United States and the Soviet Union agreed, in a joint statement, to use their influence and coordinate their efforts to achieve "a positive outcome" of the Middle East negotiations.

The Justice Department approved today Georgia's plan for redistricting 30 seats in the House of Representatives. J.

The Eastman Kodak Company broadcast its third television report to the community last night in Rochester, the city that is home to the company and 46,000 shareholders who hold 15 to 20 per cent of the outstanding stock.

The city's schools reopened today after a 42-day teachers' strike and most of the 60,000 pupils resumed classes.

The McDonald's Corporation, which operates and franchises the nation's largest fast-food restaurant chain, apparently showed little effect from the gasoline shortage on its firstquarter earnings, according to results issued yesterday.

A boyish-looking French - trained economist named Khieu Samphan appears to be gently upstaging Prince Norodom Sihanouk as the eventual leader and spokesman of the Cambodian insurgency.

A senior official of the Civil Aeronautics Board has accused the nation's airlines of writing selfserving ticketing regulations "filled with jargon, doubletalk, strange phraseology and catch phrases" as a "defense weapon to thwart the grievances and desires of the public."

State Senator Clarence M. Mitchell 3d pleaded no contest today to four counts of failing to file Federal income tax returns. He had pleaded not guilty to the same charges a year ago. There was no explanation for the switch.

The bears dominated the Midwest grain and livestock markets yesterday and slashed prices almost to limit lows. in most of them.
Cantella Co., a Boston based brokerage firm, will be merged into Josephthal Co. a member of the New York and American Stock exchanges, the firms announced Jointly yesterday.

The young foursome ot William Natbony and Michael Radin of New York, plus Mark Jacobs of Allston, Mass., and Steve Sion of Brighton, Mass., topped a field of 236 teams to win the Swiss team championship in the Long Island regional tournament at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., over the weekend.
I have a tiny notebook bearing the legend "Loose Ends," and its chaotic contents remind me of every tackle box I own. The idea behind the notebook was commendable.
In a move against "windfall" profits, the Government asked Parliament today for power to freeze prices, or order them rolled back, where there is evidence of profiteering by suppliers.

The Consumer Product Safety Commissioner said today that it had started an investigation to determine if any of the products under its jurisdiction involved hazardous forms of vinyl chloride, a chemical linked to liver cancer.

The Ordinary Meeting of Fiat Stockholders took place on April 26, 1974, in Turin. Mr. Giovanni Agnelli, the Chairman of Fiat, in his report emphasized the fundamental role played by the automobile as the principal instrument of mobility.

The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to use their influence and to coordinate their efforts to achieve "a positive outcome" of the Middle East negotiations now under way to achieve a troop separation on the Syrian-Israeli front.
