In granting President Nixon a delay in responding to its subpoena, the House Judiciary Committee acted with the courtesy and restraint that from the outset have marked its conduct of a difficult assignment. In view of his deliberate delays, his obfuscatory distor tions, his withholding of evidence, and his own verbal attacks and those of his spokesmen, Mr. Nixon can hardly be said to have reciprocated the committee's model behavior.
Bacteria apparently frozen in the Antarctic ice and soil for at least 10,000 years have grown and reproduced in the laboratory, scientists reported today.
The stock market played a waiting game yesterday and closed without a definite trend in very dull trading. Quotations on the New York Stock Exchange moved in a narrow range throughout the session.

Tentative agreement has been reached between Mayor Beame and Governor Wilson on some items in the city's fiscal package, including the $520-million borrowing authority, with the 1-cent-on-the-dollar rise in the sales tax to be taken up tomorrow, sources close to the discussions said today.
Mrs. Carrie Ballin Rukeyser, a past president and director of the National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods, died yesterday at her home, 20 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains. Her age was 65.
Herbert Hosking, a management consultant and former editor, died Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 262 Central Park West.

Roland Petit's "Le Loup" has not been seen locally for 20 years, when it was danced by Mr. Petit's own Ballets de Paris. However, it has maintained itself in a few repertories, including those of the Royal Danish Ballet and the National Ballet of Canada.

The New York Mets managed to chip away 87.5 per cent of an 8-0 deficit after the first two innings tonight, but that wasn't enough to avert an 8-7 loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers, who won their seventh straight game.

The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court for the Second Department unanimously reversed yesterday the murder conviction of Robert Grimaldi in the death of Conrad Greaves, a rackets-inquiry witness. The ruling dismissed the indictment.
The name and address are the same,but the image is different at Rose Lash International at 58 East 55th Street since Mrs. Lash retired last month and her daughter, Corrinne Travis, took over.
The House Ways?? Committee approved today few minor changes in legislation that would increase the taxes to be paid by the oil industry, but it again avoided taking final action on the measure.

The Legislature has approved a measure that would place the city's eight community colleges fully under the authority of New York City's Board of Higher Education. Although the board, and thus the City University, is in fact now largely responsible for the operation of these institutions, the existing organizational structure still involves the State University and its trustees in routine management decisions and paper work.

The General Accounting Office reported today that shortages of basic commodities and raw materials were causing "serious economic, social and political problems" for the United States and other nations and that the Government's ability to deal with the shortages has been inadequate.

A researcher at Harvard University maintains that dropping out of college for a semester or longer, a practice that has traditionally been frowned upon by a society oriented toward completing an undergraduate degree in four years, may be more beneficial than people have thought.
The CBS and ABC television networks accused the Nixon Administration today of bringing an antitrust suit against them in retaliation for their refusal to "play ball" with the Administration.

Gas Company declared today for the first time in its 42-year history a cash dividend on its common stock. The dividend Is 10 cents per share payable in two installments this year, one of 5 cents in June and another 5 cents dividend in December.

The Museum of American Folk Art, which began 13 years ago as the first institution in the city devoted to this booming field, is being investigated by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's office as to its financial condition and the disposition of certain art objects from its collection.

COLUMBUS, Ohio - Our military leaders spend untold hours directing contingency planning for almost every conceivable threat to the nation's security both from within and without. Some of the threats are real. Most, though possible, are highly unlikely.
President Franz Jonas was buried today in a state funeral. Mr. Jonas died Wednesday of cancer at the age of 74.
State policemen stopped about 165 members of the Pagans motorcycle gang near here yesterday and charged them with "following each other too closely."

Victor E. Samuelson, the American oil executive for whom the Exxon Corporation paid a record ransom of $14.2 million 49 days ago, was released today by his guerrilla kidnappers, informed sources said. He had been held for nearly five months.

The Republic National Life Insurance Company, sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission last month on fraud charges, has been sued again by a Tennessee company seeking to rescind a 1971 merger deal, it was reported yesterday.

Seymour Rotnstein, a Queens cab driver, became the second key government witness to change his stance yesterday as the trial of 13 harness drivers accused of fixing superfecta races moved into its seventh week at the Federal Court Building in Brooklyn.

A vice president of the First National. Bank who served as a juror in the Mitchell-Stans trial said yesterday the panel that acquitted the two former Cabinet officers Sunday considered that John W. Dean 3d had had a "relatively minor part in this case."

Victor E. Samuelson, the American oil executive for whom a $14.2-million ransom was paid to Argentine guerrillas more than a month ago, was reported released near Buenos Aires yesterday.
The simple task of washing children's sleepwear in New York State has come to exemplify how two worthy sets of laws can pit one goal against another: in this -case ecology versus safety.

Eugene Klein, owner of the San Diego Chargers, the first National Football League team fined for use of drugs, proposed today that every N.F.L. player be given a urine test after each game. if evidence of drugs is found, "my recommendation is immediate suspension-no ifs, ands or buts," Klein said in a speech to sports writers and broadcasters.

Intense controversy has broken out at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center here over whether doctors can use blood, sweat, urine and feces as freely as has been the custom for research and teaching purposes.
Councilman and Mayor-designate Gerald H. Springer announced today his resignation from the city government, citing "family considerations" as his reason.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation told a House panel today that it was barred by present laws and court decisions from wiretapping terrorist groups like the so-called Symbionese Liberation Army.

Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia University, declared last night that an over-expansion of American higher education in recent years had led to a "rapid deterioration" in the quality of the four-year degree at many public colleges and universities.

Venezuela's new Government pledged today to forge an austerity economy despite unprecedented riches from oil, and unveiled plans to nationalize the United Statesdominated iron-ore industry along with a broad range of foreien-owned companies.
Hawaii's first dual sugarpineapple strike ended today with the return of about 6,000 members of the- International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union to pineapple plantations on three islands.

Last week the Television Bureau of Advertising urged more national ad agencies to get into the retail business and yesterday Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample announced it is in. Beautiful timing, but pure coincidence.

After nearly two years of virtual store-to-store solicitation, a small but growing number of citizens led by a Manhattan housewife have persuaded more than 1,300 small businesses in the city to establish a retail sales discount for elderly persons on fixed incomes.
Soft Lenses, Inc., a small West Coast optical company, has been granted approval by the Food and Drug Administration to make and sell soft contact lenses for cosmetic use.
Yields on three month and six-month United States Treasury bills were sharply higher in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 29-- Senator J. W. Fulbright is in danger of being defeated for a sixth term by a popular young challenger, Gov. Dale Bumpers. Both are Democrats. With the party primary a month away, even Mr. Fulbright's friends and advisers have acknowledged that he has an uphill fight to retain his seat.

The first official toll in the landslides last Thursday that wiped out two Andean villages put the number of dead today at 250 and the missing at 500.

Frank T. Cary, chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, told stockholders at the annual meeting here today that the company had increased security in its laboratories and he pledged to fight pending lawsuits against the company to completion.
The Politics of economics has moved to the center of the French presidential campaign, as left and right clash over how best to assure increased employment and decreased inflation.

John T. Dunlop, the Government's chief price enforcer, fired a broadside of criticism today at the Chrysler Corporation and its chairman, Lynn Townsend, for announcing an average price increase of $99 a car.
Twelve men and women, including a national "porno" film star, were indicted here today on obscenity charges stemming from their alleged participation in a film that was made in Suffolk County.
Dr. A. Charles Posner, former director of obstetrics and president of the medical board of Harlem Hospital, died Sunday at his apartment in the Croydon Hotel. He was 76 years old.

Paul Keres, the Estonian grandmaster, once remarked that he preferred to play in a style opposite to that of his opponent. Against positional maneuverers, he would draw on his remarkable talent as a tactician; against tacticians, he would show off the positional side of his play and his skill in end games.

President Nixon has paid "most" of the $467,000 that the Internal Revenue Service said he owed in back taxes and interest, according to an authoritative source quoted to an night by The Baltimore Sun. The Sun article said its source would not specify how
Transportation and law enforcement officials in 15 metropolitan areas have formed task forces to try to reduce cargo theft, Attorney General William B. Saxbe announced today.
A $10,000 reward offered for information about the missing balloonist, Thomas Gatch Jr., has produced no clues, a spokesman for Mr. Gatch said today.

Egypt's new cabinet, announced last Thursday, was sworn in here today before President Anwar el-Sadat. Speaking at the brief ceremony, President Sadat said that Egypt did not intend to seek the friendship of one superpower, either the United States or the Soviet Union, at the expense of the other.

The massive pile of transcript pages that Richard Nixon now says is to be made public may give him a shortterm political boost; in the long run, however, this gesture does not answer the needs of the House Judiciary Committee or conform to any law but Mr. Nixon's own.

Governor Wilson has acted commendably, and just in time, to prevent destruction of the much-needed Adirondack railroad line from Remsen, just' north of Utica, to Lake Placid. By directing his Department of Transportation to negotiate with receivers for the bankrupt Penn Central, Governor Wilson has held out hope that a sound facility will not be sacrificed either to the greed of the seller or the parsimoniousness of the state.

Ford Motor Argentina will sign a $30-million, three-year, contract for the sale of cars and trucks to Cuba, Ford said today. The contract, to be signed tomorrow, is the second for a United States auto maker's subsidiary here with Cuba under a temporary waiver of the 14-year-old United States trade embargo against Havana.
Four men from Santa Barbara, Calif., were killed yesterday when their light plane crashed and burned shortly after taking off from this coastal community.
Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator and mass-transit advocate, yesterday recommended a 50-cent transit fare during morning and evening peak periods and a 25-cent fare at other times.

Prices rose yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, although trading was the slowest in more than seven years and declines slightly outnumbered advances. Similar conditions prevailed in the over-the-counter market.

The Democrats in the House of Representatives are scheduled to meet in caucus tomorrow and Thursday to decide their party's position on the proposed realignment of House committees. An unusual alliance of business and labor lobbies is working with a powerful bloc of self-interested committee and subcommittee chairmen to defeat this desirable and rather modest reform.

An earthquake rocked a large area of Egypt, including Cairo, tonight but there were no reports of casualties, the Middle East New Agency said.

Among the discoveries of Dr. Alfred E. Kahn during a career as an expert in public-utility regulation has been that the chairmanship of the State Public Service Commission is a thankless job.

Superior Court Judge David D. Furman of Middlesex County invalidated the amendments to Madison Township's zoning ordinances on the ground that they did little to open up what he called an essentially exclusionary housing code. The changes, he ruled, constituted only a "token" step in the direction of making more middleincome housing available in the community, and did nothing whatever to make lower income housing available.

A fire swept through a storage room of the Camden County Courthouse today, destroying several thousand court reporter, steno-type tapes of trial testimony. The cause of the fire is under investigation by state police and the Camden Fire Marshal's office.

After opening slightly higher, prices on the American Stock Exchanged dropped yesterday and closed off on slightly increased trading compared with the day before. However, prices rose in the over-thecounter market.
Nine persons were killed and 11 seriously injured today in the collapse of a bridge being built over a Bavarian mountain stream.

The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it would hold an inquiry to determine whether bank-sponsored investment services ought to be subject to some kind of S.E.C. regulation. The commission said its action was prompted in part by Con. gressional concern over the growing trend of banks becoming involved more in investment service activities.

Alexander P. Butterfield, the former White House aide who disclosed the existence of the Presidential tape recordings to the Senate Watergate committee last July, left here today to tour aircraft factories on the West Coast.

The House Ways and Means Committee gave final approval today to legislation that' would increase the taxes by the oil industry to the Government this year from an estimated $1.6billion to $2.6-billion.
Dr. Halfdan Mahler, director general of the World Health Organization, predicted today that "next year the world will have seen its last case of smallpox."

A Federal grand jury investigating illegal campaign financing today indicted Anthony J. Satile, a former Bergen County Republican chairman, on charges of inspiring fraudulent contribu|tions and trying to impede the Federal investigation.

Springs Mills, .Inc., said yesterday that it had filed suit in the United States District Court here against Saks Co., operator of the Saks Fifth Avenus chain, charging infringement of Springs "Ultrasuede' fabric and "Ultra-Suede" fabric registered trademarks.
Vice President Ford, after reading the released White House summaries of Presidential conversations, said today, "The President, in my opinion, is completely innocent."

As the clucking gets louder over the menace of "happy talk" or "tabloid" news on television, WNBC-TV has come up with an attractive and initially impressive alternative called "NewsCenter 4." Claiming no help from outside "consultants," the New York flagship station of NBC-TV is bringing the metropolitan area its first twohour edition of the earlyevening news.

The Army, whose total recruiting advertising budget has gone beyond $35-million a year, is conducting an inquiry into its relationship with its agency, N. W. Ayer Son. Advertising Age, the trade publication which ran a series of stories from Washington last year that in effect suggested impropriety in the account's reassignment, reported the inquiry in this week's issue.

Victor E. Samuelson, the American oil executive held for 144 days by Marxist guerrillas in Argentina, returned to the United States today to rejoin his family.
As Dick Rosenkranz walked along the dock to his clamming boat before dawn here today, he appeared worried. "It looks rough," Mr. Rosenkranz said as he gathered more than 50 pounds of equipment in his

President Nixon, although he gave the House impeachment inquiry more than 1,300 pages of transcripts of taped conversations about Watergate today, intends to oppose the special Watergate prosecutor's bid for more tapes and documents.

The New York Times begins publishing today, in chronological order, transcripts of subpoenaed Watergate tape recordings as edited and released by the White House. Also included is the text of President Nixon's legal argument issued yesterday. Additional tape transcripts will be published tomorrow.

California's Attorney General, Evelle J. Younger, said today that he has no evidence to link San Francisco's "Zebra" killings with 80 other slaying in California in the last three years as charged yesterday by Mayor Joseph L. Alioto.
America is spawning excel lent young string quartets with an ichthyic enthusiasm these days, and the Cleveland String Quartet is certainly one of the best.
With price controls dying at midnight, major copper producers announced yesterday, that they were establishing a new price of 80 cents a pound for copper cathode, up 12 cents from the old price.
Fighting flared again between Israel and Syria in the Golan Heights today as Israeli leaders worked out their strategy for talks with Secretary of State Kissinger later this week.

A "mass rally" called by fire officers to protest the city's proposed homosexual rights law attracted only a few demonstrators to City Hall yesterday. The sponsors Insisted that they had canceled the rally
Dr. Max Rabbiner, formerly assistant professor of otolaryngology at New York University and Bellevue Medical Center, died Friday at his home here. He was 80 years old.

Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, had his blood pressure taken today for the benefit of 23 million other Americans. His pressure came out well within the normal range--126 over 84--but the Secretary's
The United States Steel Corporation realized a gain of 82.7 per cent in first-quarter earnings over the like 1973 period on an increase of just under 29 per cent in sales and revenues.

The White House transcripts released today support what is known to be one of Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski's key theories in the pending Watergate case: That a principal motive for the alleged high-level cover-up was a desire to pre vent disclosure of the 1971 Ellsberg burglary.
Kevin Loughery, the Nets' coach, and Rod Thorn, his excitable assistant, may have Bore throats from shouting and sore muscles from jumping on and off the bench tonight, but it was all worth it.

To the Editor: William Turner's warning (letter April 16) not to expect political dividends from aid to India is thoughtful, and his suggestion that India obtain a matching grant from the Russians is provocative. It's well known that foreign aid,- unlike Shakespeare's concept of mercy, has blessed neither the giver nor the receiver.

The Dayco Corporation of Dayton, Ohio, filed separate suits yesterday in the United States District Court in Cleveland against the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company charging each company with attempting to monopolize the manufacture and sale of replacement tires in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.
A 12-year-old South Bronx boy apparently drowned last evening while swimming with friends in a pool at St. Mary's Recreation eCnter, 145th Street and St. Ann's Avenue, in the Mott Haven section.

Hooray! Hooray! The first of May! National Radio Month begins today! (Don't scoff: It may be the only non-catastrophic news you'll be getting.) In any event, the monthlong stress on the eary medium is of special interest

In its first major action since assuming power three weeks ago, the coalition Government of Laos agreed today to accept continuing financial aid from non-Communist countries to boister, the chronically weak economy.
The budget of the state Council on the Arts was more than doubled last night under a bill that received final approval in the Legislature last night.

Portions of Duke Ellington's three Sacred Concerts -the works that, he says, have meant the most to him during the last decadeformed the basis for a service at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue
William Zev Hassid, a pioneer research scientist in sugar biochemistry, died Sunday at Alta Bates Hospital. He was 76 years old.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest utility and the third largest in the country, today asked the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners to approve a 19.98 per cent rate increase.

Several cars of an Amtrak passenger train derailed near this northern Indiana town today, the authorities said. The state police reported that eight persons were treated at a local hospital, but none was injured seriously.

The Soviet press, in a rare breach of its usual silence on the Watergate affair, informed its readers today that President Nixon was turning over transcripts of his tape-recorded conversations on the matter to the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives.

The transcripts of recordings of President Nixon's key Watergate conversations released today depict an embattled leader searching early last year for a way to keep details of the case from becoming public but indecisive on the best way to do it.

John D. Ehrlichman, former Presidential adviser, said in court papers filed today that President Nixon had twice "indicated his after-the-fact approval" of the Elsberg burglary by White House "plumbers" and had ordered his Watergate investigators to stay away from it.

The Atomic Energy Commission, fearing possible sabotage, is ordering utilities throughout the country to hire armed guards to protect nuclear plants, despite the protests of some utilities - including the Consolidated Edison Company

Judge Frederick Ziem of Oakland County Circuit Court today barred Dr. Jesse Ketchum, who was convicted of negligent homicide after performing an abortion in Buffalo, N. Y., from practicing medicine in the county. Dr. Ketchum is free on $10,000 bail while he appeals the New York conviction.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has abandoned its opposition to repealing a 12-year-old bond covenant that restricts its mass transporttation capability, Dr. William J. Ronan, the authority's new chairman, said yesterday.
Following is the roll-call vote on the death-penalty bill voted in the State Senate: FOR THE BILL-40 Republicans-34 Ackerson (Tappan) Levy (Long Beach) Anderson Lombardi (Singhamton) (Syracuse)

A trial of Indian militants erupted into a courtroom clash between the police and Indian supporters today. At least 10 persons were injured in the disturbance and two were killed in a related car smash-up.
In the great crises of his political life, Richard Nixon has been almost recklessly bold. He saved himself from charges of corruption in the Presidential campaign of 1952 with his Checkers speech.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today a bill creating a national commission to study allegations of mismanagement of United States Olympic teams. The Senate was expected to give its approval quickly.

Italy unexpectedly imposed severe restrictions tonight on all imports of manufactured, goods. The measure, aimed at fighting inflation and bolstering the sagging lira, caused consternation among

The Portuguese Army and a tumultous crowd of leftists today wel comed home Alvaro Cunhal, the leader of Portugal's Communis party, after 12 years in exile. Minutes after his arrival by air from Paris,

Wall Street's municipal-bond dealers, already discouraged after three months of declining prices and scarce profits, were further dismayed yesterday by New Jersey's final action to repeal a covenant that restricted involvement of the Port Authority in deficit mass transit.

Samuel G. Sanchez, 33 years old, wriggled through the air conditioning ducts of the county jail to the roof. The roof tiles gave way and he crashed through to the courtroom below, where a bailiff grabbed him and returned him to his cell.
An explosion blasted the top off a silo at a grain elevator today, killing four persons and injuring one. The blast and flying debris also damaged several railroad cars and buildings in the vicinity.

A spokesman in the United States Attorney's office here confirmed today that Otis Chandler, publisher of The Los Angeles Times, appeared volun tarily before a Federal grand iury investigating charges of criminal fraud in an oil-drilling-fund program yesterday.
New Jersey and Federal health officials today reported a fresh outbreak of measles in Camden County and announced plans for an intensive immunization program to begin there next week.

Troops and the police here prepared today for possible civil disturbances on May Day.

Directors of the Signal Companies, Inc., yesterday increased the quarterly cash dividend on the company's common stock to 20 cents per share from 15 cents, and declared regular quarterly dividends on preferred stocks.

The $4-billion, ten-point emergency program to assist countries hardest hit by price rises which the United States suddenly proposed at the United Nations yesterday seems intended to head off a rival $3-billion emergency aid fund proposal that was gaining support among developing countries.

The Ford Motor Company closed, six of its automobile assembly plants today and said by Thursday eight others would be out of work, idling about 37,000 workers. The company said that strikes against two of its parts suppliers were to blame.

Under pressure of court challenge and black protests, the large-scale stop-and-frisk operation undertaken by the San Francisco police to find the so-called Zebra murderer has been modified. It amounted to the most senseless violation of civil rights in years, yet few people outside the northern California black community spoke out.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, the financially troubled West Coast manufacturer that has been exploring possible mergers to broaden its income potential, reported firstquarter net earnings yesterday of $3.8-million.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest utility and the third largest in the nation, asked the state Public Utilities Commission today to approve a 19.98 per cent rate increase, a $257-million request that is the largest in the company's history.

The political pulse is barely tangible in this part of the heartland of France as the presidential election approaches. While party organizations paste up posters, usually over those depicting opposing candidates, the electorate in this sleepy capital of the Creuse Department goes about its business.

A public hearing on abortion regulations proposed by the State Department of Health was abruptly suspended this afternoon when foes of abortion defied the presiding officer's order to stop "harassing" a speaker for the New Jersey chapter of the National Organization for Women.
BANG CLANG That perennial fund raiser, FM radio's station WBAI, is launching another airwave marathonrunning an expected six weeks-to try and collect $200,000.

A portion of an ornamental stone windowsill on the top floor of the Abercrombie Fitch Co. building broke loose shortly before midnight last night and fell 12 stories to the deserted sidewalk below, scattering in pieces on the corner of 45th Street and Madison Avenue.

Billie Jean King will head a new equal lending program at the Lincoln Bank designed to end sex discrimination, the institution announced yesterday in Philadelphia..

A Congressional investigation into the use of military personnel as "servants" to the President and his staff has been thwarted by the White House, according to a statement released today by Senator William Proxmire.

A three-judge Federal Court ruled unanimously today that Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx were subject to the Federal Voting Rights Act, and thus made a reapportionment of Congressional and legislative districts in the three boroughs within the next two months almost certain.

New Yorkers who have been planning to surprise Mother with a singing telegram on Mother's Day, May 12, should begin thinking of an alternate tribute. The Western Union Corporation received permission from the

Dr. Charles. R. DeCarlo, the president of Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers, disclosed yesterday that he had been accosted at gunpoint Saturday night by four young men who ordered him to get in their Volkswagen.

Alex Hannum was dismissed yesterday as coach and general manager of the Denver Rockets of the American Basketball Association. He had held the dual position three years and his contract expired yesterday.

They depict Mr. Nixon as having been primarily interested early last year in keeping the facts of the Watergate
A man apparently upset because of an argument with his common-law wife early today threw his two children out of a third-floor apartment window on Detroit's West Side

Directors of Geon Industries, a distributor of automotive replacement parts, especially for foreign cars, voted to accept a second and lower acquisition offer from Burmah Oil, Inc., a British company, for Geon's assets.
The Martha Graham Dance Company embarked on its third and last week at the Mark Hellinger Theater Monday night with the revival of Miss Graham's great duet 'Errand Into the Maze."
George Lee has been appointed vice president of MCA Records, Inc., in charge of Eastern operations, it was announced yesterday. He is a former vice president of Warner Bros.

Jaime Rivera Ballestero of Spain led his countrymen in taking three of the top five places in the main event of the rain-swept Rome international horse show today. Rivera, riding Conquistador over the reduced steeplechase course of six obstacles with a water and triple jump, was first in 70 seconds with four faults.

A community school board in Flushing, Queens, passed a school rezoning plan last night that pleased parents whose children had boycotted their public school earlier in the day, but angered other parents, who said they would challenge it before
The suspended Police Chief of Salem, George A. Johnson, has pleaded guilty to a single count of playing poker and has agreed to resign from the force.
Prices improved yesterday in the corporate and Govern ment bond markets, the tax exempt market demonstrated good initial response to sever a new offerings
Drivers of two New Jersey bus lines that serve 21,000 commuters who work in New York City went on strike yesterday morning in a dispute over wages.

Mrs. John N. Mitchell, dissatisfied with President Nixon's substitution of edited transcripts for the White House tapes, called upon newspapers and members of Congress yesterday to press for what she called "the real thing."

As the House Judiciary Committee recognized last night, the simple fact is that President Nixon has failed to comply with a subpoena duly served by the committee. Nor, it seems, does he intend to comply with a subpoena served upon him by the special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski. The subpoenas required the submission of tape recordings, not selective transcripts edited by the person under investigation.

Hawaii's mandatory gasoline rationing program, the first in the nation, was suspended yesterday. Acting Gov. George Ariyoshi, who imposed the plan three months ago, said it was no longer needed but would be reinstituted if gasoline became scarce again.
The seven-year-old Division of Plastics Technology at Bronx Community College has a mammoth building of its own.. It has hundreds of thousands of dollars in modern equipment.
A forest fire in a populated neighborhood burned out of control for five hours here today but more than 400 firemen were able to prevent it from damagingg homes.
Alloway, Creek Township officials have cleared the way for the construction of a nuclear power plant after studying dangers of possible accidents.
Close to 20 years of serious effort to grow tropical and subtropical plants indoors here paid off for a city resident yesterday at the 28th annual Gramercy Park Flower Show.

The Colonial Commercial Corporation, a consumer finance company in Valley Stream, L. I., said yesterday it had substantially completed negotiations for funding a plan of arrangement between two Cincinnati consumer finance companies and their creditors.

Jim Sherrit sent the Houston Aeros into the final of the World Hockey Association playoffs with a bitterly disputed goal tonight. The Aeros defeated the Minnesota Fighting Saints, 3-1, and captured the four-ofseven-game series 4-2.
The various efforts to bring dramatic programing back to radio are being spurred on by encouraging results, both in audience acceptance and advertising suppport, for "The CBS Radio Mystery Theater."

William A. H. Williams, told a Federal court today that there is no: such organization as the American Revolutionary Army and that he had acted alone in kidnapping J. Reginald Murphy, editor of the Atlanta Constitution.

A spokesman for Alexander P. Butterfield, who until becoming Federal Aviation Administrator last year was the White House aide responsible for the tape recording devices there, challenged today a report in The New York Times dealing with Mr. Butterfield's departure yesterday for the West Coast.
Some physically beautiful people had best beware: Between their good looks and the American emphasis on attractiveness, there is an emotional trap.

A salary increase of 19.2 per cent in the 'first six months starting July 1 and provision for a semiannual cost-of-living increase were among the demands made yesterday by the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association as it opened negotiations with the city for a new contract.
Governor Wilson said today that President Nixon should be treated like everyone else in the payment of taxes in New York State.
The BP Oil Company, Ltd,, raised yesterday the price of gasoline at wholesale by 6 cents a gallon. The company said it would advance the price of heating oil and diesel fuel by 7 cents a gallon.
Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel of the Court of Appeals today denounced the Legislature and, by implication, Governor Wilson for their handling of the courtreform issue.
The Peavey Company, a Minneapolis flour milling and agricultural products company, said yesterday it had sold two Canadian operations to the Cargill Grain Company, Ltd., for about $28-million.

F.A.O. Schwarz, the Fifth Avenue-based chain of toy Stores, is changing ownership for the third time in a decade. The Franz Carl Weber Holding Company of Zurich, Switzerland, has purchased through a new American subsidiary the 91.3 per cent interest in F.A.O.

Governor Wilson today ordered the state's 10-week-old odd-even gasoline distribution plan lifted immediately, but 'said the suspension would work only' if motorists continued to observe gasolineconservation measures.
Preliminary studies conducted at the University of Utah indicate that it may be possible to solve the Sheepman's problem with coyote predation by "turning off" the coyote's taste For lamb.
The Ford Motor Company today revised plans that, would have Idled 37,000 workers as a strike at a key parts supplier neared an end.

The complex and baffling problems of our time are not just a bigger and somewhat modernized version of old ones. Sweeping quantitative and qualitative changes are transforming everything. The manmade world has spread, all over the planet, displacing and subjugating the natural world that has produced our species and nurtured it.

Cornell Warner, who had been unceremoniously dropped by two teams in his four-year National Basketball Association career, was one of the most valuable Milwaukee Bucks last night as they evened the championship series with the Boston Celtics at one game apiece with a 105-96 overtime victory.

The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation,' Frank Wille, announced 'today- the F.D.I.C. board has extended from April 30 to July 31 the comment period on its proposed regulation to establish minimum' standards for the use of offering circulars.

A State Supreme Court Justice ruled yesterday that the 13 defendants in the Attica uprising could continue to be handcuffed behind their backs during the walk from the Erie County Court building in Buffalo to the Holding Center. He said he made the walk himself "without any difficulty."

The Sperry Rand Corporation reported yesterday a 15.8 per cent increase in its net income to $33.8-million for the fiscal fourth quarter. The company also said its net rose 25 per cent for the fiscal year ended March 31 to $112.6-million, or $3.27 a share.

President Nixon warned the Justice Department in April, 1973, that any inquiry into his personal involvement in the Watergate cover-up would be dangerouss to the Presidency," the edited White House transcripts show.
West Coast dockworkers will return to work tomorrow while their union and shippers discuss a demand for a cost-ofliving salary adjustment, the Pacific Maritime Association said tonight.

A United States proposal for a $4-billion assistance program for economically distressed countries was brushed aside without discussion today by delegates to the General Assembly's special session on raw materials and development.

Federal Trade Commission attorneys have said they will attempt to prove that eight major oil companies instigated a move by Treasury Secretary William E. Simon to quash the commission's antitrust case against the companies.
As a warm surf pounded over the beach today, thousands of Sri Lankans waved flags, ate pineapple, drank pink coconut juice and applauded Government pleas for austerity.

Gen. Antonio de Spinola's plan for giving Portugal's African territories self-government, inside a federation with the mother country could be a halfway house on the road to full independence for Angola, Mozambique and Guinea-Bissau. The similarity of the federation idea to Gen. Charles de Gaulle's French Community concept of the nineteen-fifties is striking; the parallel could also be instructive.

To the Editor: Isn't it possible that ..education's financial troubles, and educators' withdrawal from "issues of substance," are in fact symptoms of profound national doubt regarding the validity of the "article of faith-that education and the nation's progress are tied together by policy and fate"? [Fred M. Hechinger's April 16 column.]
Common Market officials in Brussels said today the measures taken by Italy yesterday to discourage imports of manufactured foods endangered the principle of free trade among the nine members.

Major Raimondo D'Inzeo of Italy won both events today in the Rome international horse show. D'Inzeo won the Dunhill Prize aboard Bellevue in the opening event, covering the course in 62.2 seconds. Hubert Parot of France was second in 63.5 seconds aboard Moet et Chandon. In the Grand Prize of Rome event, D'Inzeo repeated, winning in 45.6 seconds aboard Gone Away. Alfonso Segovia of Spain was second, riding Tic Tac.

The CNA Financial Corporation told stockholders at annual meeting in 'Chicago yesterday that the Loews Corporation was planning a takeover bid for the troubled Chicago financial services and real estate company.
The script for the most sweeping reorganization of the House of Representatives in 28 years had its first tryout today at separate Democratic and Republican caucuses and drew only mixed reviews.

Baggage X-ray machines at 23 airports around the country have been found to be emitting too much radiation and have been ordered repaired, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

A dull, vulgar little musical satire titled "Kaboom!" goes kaplunk. Too bad..The dwindling theater season could have used a bright daisy, especially at a place like Greenwich Village's The Bottom Line,

While a field of 40 Belgian draft horses prepared to pull a circus bandwagon in tomorrow's Pegasus Parade, controversial steps were taken at Churchill Downs today to prevent a similar traffic jam in Saturday's 100th Kentucky Derby.

A strong surge of buying swept into the stock market yesterday, sending prices sharply higher in active trading. Brokers attributed the upswing mainly to the ending of price and wage controls on Tuesday and to growing optimism that interest rates may have peaked.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, based on investigations that are not yet completed, believes that it will pay off somewhere between one-third and two-thirds of the claims of foreign banks against the failed United States National Bank in San Diego The bank was run by C. Arnholt Smith, a longtime personal friend of President Nixon's.

Billy Backus a former world welterweight' champion from Philadelphia, got up from a second-round knockdown to. floor Jacques Kechichian three times in the fifth round tonight and was awarded a knockout victory when the Frenchman couldn't answer the bell for the sixth round.
The names of a third and final group of 1,100 high school seniors were announced yesterday by the National Merit Scholarship Corporation as winners of $1,000 nonrenewable college scholarships.

Pierre Dubois is a new member of the French Communist party. He is 29 years old, tall and handsome, with a sprightly face and winning ways. He comes from what he calls a "favored" family--uper middle-class, intelligent, sophisticated and affectionate.

The city's Department of Consumer Affairs yesterday charged the Kaufman Carpet Company, one of the largest carpet chains in the country, with "repeated, multiple. and persistent violations of the Consumer Protection . Law by engaging in deceptive trade practices."

John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, urged the County Legislature today to commit an additional $15-million to preserve farmlands and to check suburban sprawl in this rapidly growing county.

The farther into enemy territory a passed pawn advances, the greater becomes the threat it poses--for both players. Looming large as an incipient queen, a passed pawn may make the defender's blood run cold, but if it is thrust forward in unplanned haste it may outrun its support and be engulfed by eager counterattackers.
The House Armed Services Committee has imposed a small, symbelic cut in the Army's program to develop a new type of nerve gas, committee sources disclosed today.

James W. McCord, convicted. Watergate conspirator, charged today that Earl J. Silbert had supplied the White House with minutes of grand jury deliberations concerning the original Watergate defendants.

On the first day after the end of wage and price controls, producers of several basic products raised their prices yesterday, and West Coast longshoremen walked off their jobs for one day in a bid for a wage increase that they had been denied during the period of controls.
In Sydney, car stickers proclaim: "I'm Dreadin Snedden." In Canberra, somebody changed the sense of a sign reading "Gough's Going Great" by putting a period after the second word.
About 8,000 Penn Central commuters were caught in a suspension of service on the line's Hudson Division during the rush-hour last night because of a series of major fires in Yonkers.
Samuel Bonchek, a founder of the Labor Zionist Movement of America and honorary president of the Labor Zionist Alliance, died Monday at Beth Israel Hospital. His age was 84,

H. R. Haldeman, the former White House chief of staff, asked the United States District Court today to permit him to "inspect and test" the original tapes of all his conversations with President Nixon to help him prepare a defense in the Watergate cover-up case.
Two septugenarians, Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Beech of Metuchen, had luncheon here today in the high school cafeteria with 987 teen-age neighbors as a special program for the elderly began.

Five leaders of two inmate groups at the Rahway State Prison were transferred to other New Jersey penal institutions late Tuesday night after officials found them guilty of organizing an illegal mass meeting.
Two oil-research vessels, working for a consortium of 48 oil companies' will conduct a seismic survey off Cape Cod, including George's Bank, beginning in May, according to a spokesman.

For newsmen accompanying Secretary of State Kissinger, the mood in this seaside city was strikingly different depending upon whom they were listening to.

The Senate Agriculture Committee approved today, in the face of Administration opposition, a bill to require continued government purchases of food commodities for school lunches and other nutrition programs.

The House approved a. bill today to grant radio and television broadcast licenses for five years instead of the present three and to require the Federal. Communications Commission to streamline its procedures in determining license awards.

President Nixon's lawyers asked the United States District Court today to quash the special Watergate prosecution subpoena for tapes and records of 64 White House conversations relating to the Watergate cover-up.
The Southern Pacific Company reported yesterday a first quarter net profit of $17-million or 64 cents a share, a 20 per cent gain over the like 1978 period.

Seton Hall's outstanding group of sprinters enabled the Pirates today to become the first team other than Princeton or Rutgers to win the New Jersey college track and field championships.

Lawyers for the House Judiciary Committee disclosed tonight that discrepancies, perhaps minor, existed between some of the transcripts of the White House tape recordings President Nixon made public yesterday and transcripts of the same tapes made by the committee staff.

The Daily News, hampered by 13 days of slowdown by its printers, served notice yesterday that it' would begin to use automated typesetting processes next Monday if the job action continued and there was no substantial progress in contract negotiations.
American diplomatic sources in London reported that Walter H. Annenberg, the United States Ambassador, will give up his post soon--probably in July--and return home for business and family reasons.

The National Football League yesterday had a good day in its on-going battle with the upstart World Football League. In Dallas a judge granted the Cowboys of the N.F.L. on injunction forbidding W.F.L. clubs from signing any more Cowboys to future contracts.
Adelphi Hospital, a 150-bed facility in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, closed its doors permanently after a union blocked it from receiving Blue Cross, Medicaid and Medicare payments.
The Senate voted, 53 to 42, today to approve a controversial bill to establish no-fault automobile insurance plans in every state. The measure now goes to the House, where its fate is uncertain.

The aluminum industry shipped just under 1.3-billion pounds of all types of aluminum is January, the Aluminum Association reported yesterday.
A $20-million local "nuisance tax" was disclosed by Mayor Beame yesterday as part of the budget-balancing package he brought home from Albany,
George Backer, an author and former journalist long active in Democratic party politics, died last night in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia, Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness.

With the aid of a complaisant State Legislature, a skillfully engineered exercise in armed robbery is on the verge of execution at the toll booths of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. The union representing the 600 toll collectors has lobbied a bill making them pistol-packing peace officers through both the State Senate and the Assembly.

By now Julius Erving's teammates on the New York Nets have come to expect the unexpected. For him, the spectacular is almost routine; the astonishing is almost ordinary. When the Nets resume their American Basketball Association championship series with the Utah Stars on Saturday night at the Nassau Coliseum, his teammates won't be surprised if he scores 47 points, as he did in the Nets' 89-85 victory in Tuesday night's opener.

Oil companies in West Germany have so much fuel oil in stock after a mild winter that some of them have cut back refinery output by as much as 50 per cent, according to officials. The cutback means-that less gasoline is being produced at a time of heavy demand during spring and summer holiday travel.
Sunny skies will cover the Northeast today. Showers and thundershowers will spread from the Carolinas and Ohio Valley to northwestern Florida and southeastern Texas.

PARTICIPANTS: The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post, negotiating as the Publishers Association of New York City, and New York Typographical Union No. 6, representing 819 printers, including 170 substitutes, at The Times; 945 printers, including 200 to 220 substitutes, at The News; and 312 printers, including 38 substitutes, at The Post.
The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court today ordered the Springfield School Committee to put a 5,800 pupil busing plan into effect by September to racially balance the city's schools.

The White House employed "private sources" to tap the telephones of journalists almost from the beginning of the first Nixon Administration, according to transcripts of Oval Office conversations between the President and his aides.
The Confederation of Ethiopian Labor Unions said today that if the Government carried out its threat to close down the confederation this could lead to a general strike, the second in two months.

Representative Hugh L. Carey, a Democratic gubernatorial contender, charged yesterday that the Outdoor Advertising Association of New York State was using 450 billboards around the state to "plug" Governor Wilson under the guise, of a publicservice message on the energy crisis.

In a decisive expression of dislike for wage and price controls, the Senate voted tonight, 57 to 31, against a proposal to give the Nixon Administration authority to reimpose the controls that expired at midnight last night.
South Vietnamese infantrymen backed by tanks and planes have made incursions into Cambodia at two points along the border west of Saigon, according to military sources and reports from the field.

Rawleigh Warner Jr., chairman of the Mobil Oil Corporation, old about 300 shareholders at he annual meeting here today hat "if you take our entire profit away," gasoline would only be about 2 cents a gallon cheaper.

With its Alice Tully, Hall program on Tuesday evening (and its repetition last night), the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center brought to a close its 1973-74 season. In a way it was a peculiar program.

Tight world supplies of cocoa and sugar forced prices higher yesterday, but almost all other basic foodstuffs continued to decline in value. It took only a small amount of speculative buying to send cocoa prices soaring here and in London,
John C. Sawhill, director of the Federal Energy Office, said today that he supported temporary Federal subsidies to ease the soaring cost of electricity in New York City.
Edward Haines, a lawyer in Toms River, N.J., died yesterday in Jefferson Hospital, Philadelphia. He was 66 years old.
BADDEST DADDY IN THE WORLD and CHISHOLM, PURSING A DREAM, 2 documentaries at the Whitney Museum of American Art. TRAIL OF BLOOD, a Japanese film by Misumi, at the Regency Theater.
Israel, Egypt and Syria all-shot down large numbers of their own planes with surfaceto air missiles during last October's war, United States military experts said today.

President Nixon warned the Justice Department in :April, 1973, that any inquiry into his personal involvement in the Watergate cover-up would be "dangerous to the Presidency," the edited White House transcripts show.

A maintenance station for controling pressure in the transArabia pipeline was damaged by an explosion inside Lebanon today but pumping operations were unaffected. A spokesman for Tapline, the American company that owns and operates the pipeline, said here that the explosion had started a fire at the control station, which is situated about 220 yards inside Lebanese territory near the border with Israel.

One of two jurors who lost their jobs while serving at the Mitchell-Stans trial has been reinstated. She is Theresa Cavanna, 60 years old, a risk clerk with the Maryland Casualty Company for 13 years. She said that when she returned to work on Monday, she was given 30 days notice and told her job was being eliminated as part of a general cutback in staff, The Associated Press reported.

Bessie Rowland James, author and historian whose late husband, Marquis James, won two Pulitzer Prizes for biographies on which she provided much of the research, died Tuesday in San Miguel, Mexico, where she retired 15 years ago. Her age was 78.

Maurice H. Nadjari, the state's special prosecutor, yesterday charged the United States Attorney in Manhattan with impeding the prosecution by Mr. Nadjari of more than a half dozen police-corruption cases here.

Cornell Warner, who had been unceremoniously dropped by two teams in his four-year National Basketball Association career, was one of the most valuable Milwaukee Bucks last night as they evened the championship series with the Boston Celtics at one game apiece with a 105-96 a overtime victory.

Lee Elder Day has been proclaimed for tomorrow in District of Columbia by Mayor Walter Washington in honor of the golfer, who earned the first spot for a black in the Masters tournament by winning the Monsanto open a couple of weeks ago. Elder, who has contributed time and equipment to helping Washington's youngsters play golf,

Mrs. Nina. Gore Auchincloss Steers and Michael Whitney Straight of Washington, deputy chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, were married here at noon yesterday in St. Martin's Chapel at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

More than a century after the Civil War ended slavery, a new book written by two economists has stirred up an unusually heated scholarly debate over the institution of slavery and its effect on black Americans.
Nelson Briles, Kansas City Royals pitcher, underwent surgery today for torn cartilage in his right knee. He is on the 60-day disabled list and will be eligible to return to the line-up on. June 22.

The parade of dance companies in New York continues. On Tuesday night one of the city's own companies, the New York City Ballet, in its 25th anniversary season, and, incidentally, the 10th anniversary of its entry into its permanent home,
The Cities Service Gas Company said today it would curtail natural gas service throughout the summer to some industrial customers so it could build up reserves for next winter.

The Cost of Living Council yesterday, withdrew its challenge to an 8.6 per cent increase in salary for Suffolk County police officers. The increase would bring the salary of a Suffolk policeman with four years' experience to $15,410 a year.

Long-range encouragement outweighed short-range disappointment for Tom Seaver and the New York Mets tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers took a 14-inning, 2-1 decision at Dodger Stadium on Steve Garvey's basesloaded single off Harry Parker.

Seven black men were arrested by the police here early today on murder charges, and within hours Mayor Joseph L. Alioto said "I am satisfied that we have the men" who committed 12 apparently motiveless slayings of whites in five months.

Syria has no intention of following Egypt's lead by diversifying the sources of her arms supplies, which at present are almost entirely Soviet. At the same time, Moscow has assured Damascus that it favors a "just solution" of the Arab-Israeli problem.

New reading tests will be given this term to 5,000 city pupils in a move to determine whether there was widespread cheating by teachers and supervisors on the pupil reading tests- given here last month.

A prominent Soviet weekly has dismissed as "delirium" the debate between Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the exiled writer, and Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist over the future course for the Soviet Union.

WILLIAM E. STRAHL William E. Strahl founder and president of the Babylon chemical Company and a partner in Strahl Pitsch, was recovers in Babylon, L. I., died ?? of a heart attack at ?? home, 23 Priory Lane, ?? Manor, N.Y.

A mile-long brush fire fined by high winds roared out of control for hours tonIht through a heavily wooded area about a mile and a half northeast of here. The blaze, which broke out in the dry timberland shortly after 4 P.M., was still not under control at 8:30 PM.

District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn declared yesterday that "a major dent" had been put Into operations of all five organized-crime "families" in the city with the indictment of 117 persons allegedly involved in illegal gambling grossing at least $1-billion a year.
Following are the statements issued yesterday by W. H. James, president and publisher of The Daily News, and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and publisher of The New York Times:
An Essex County correction officer, one of several who criticized conditions in the Essex County Jail, was arrested today and charged with selling drugs to inmate informers.

Peter Ottley, the former president of Local 144 of the Hotel, Hospital, Nursing Home and Allied Service Employes Union, was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to three months in prison, probation for two years

King Hussein of Jordan, in a shift of position, announced today that he would agree to the presence of a Palestinian delegation at Middle East peace talks in Geneva but with restricted negotiating rights.
Most of the nation's newspapers are printing excerpts or summaries of the 1,200 pages of transcripts of Presidential conversations released by the White House, an Associated Press spot check shows.

Mrs. Martha Clapp Taylor, the wife of William James Taylor, president of Ferrenz Taylor, Inc., a New York architectural concern, died April 23 in Devon, England. She lived in Armonk, N.Y., and Paget, Bermuda.

James D. St. Clair, special counsel to President Nixon, indicated today that the White House would resist turning over to the House Judiciary Committee the additional material it has requested in its impeachment inquiry.
A strike shut down Yale's dining halls today, and the university told its 9,400 students to find their own eating places. Students on prepaid meal plans will be given a rebate later .

Contending that it would not significantly "cause a disproportionate change in the racial composition of Morristown High School," the state's Acting Commissioner of Education, Edward W. Kilpatrick today allowed Harding Township to send its high school students to Madison High School rather than to Morristown after June, 1975.
Baroness Margaret von Soosten, an international businesswoman who once married an heir to the Bayer aspirin fortune, thinking he was a garage mechanic, died today.
Two Kuwaiti newspapers said today that the Saudi Arabian Government was likely to buy a large stake in the four United States oil companies that are shareholders in the Arabian American Oil Company.
The House approved today a bill that would postpone certain pollution abatement requirements of the Clean Air Act of 1970. The roll-call vote of 349-43 sent the measure to the Senate.
The United States, will not experience major labor problems in 1974, according to B. J. Widick, professor of industrial relations at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business.
A bomb exploded yesterday in a stairwell between the Alitalia and Scandinavian Airline System terminals at Kennedy International Airport, injuring two airline employes.
The Internal Revenue Service, in a significant reversal of long-standing tax policy, has decided to liberalize its treatment of disability pension benefits.

Milton A. Senn, lawyer, Jewish leader and Government consultant,died sunday at age 60.
Following are the identities of persons described by initials in the transcripts of the White House tapes: P. President Nixon. H. H. R. Haldeman, former White House chief of staff.

Off Off Broadway, a theatrical state of mind divided by a hundred neighborhoods, will take a giant step Saturday toward achieving a clearer focus in the eyes of New Yorkers with a gala Festival Fortnight that will run through May 19.

Eight hundred copies of the edited transcripts of President Nixon's Watergate conversations went on sale here today at the Government Printing Office Bookstore. The supply was sold out in a little more than three hours.

A motorist who said he had been beaten by Newark policemen when he refused to pay them off for safe passage through the city has won a five-year fight to prove that he was the victim of police brutality.
" It'll stir up quite a storm," a drained, relieved President Nixon told a caller a few hours after delivering his television address releasing tape transcripts. "There's some rough stuff in there."

The wife of a Fort Monmouth soldier and her 15month-old daughter died in an early-morning apartment fire in Ocean Township in Monmouth County. Authorities identified the victims as Mrs. Susan Rudolph, 30 years old, and her daughter, Diana. They said George Rudolph, 31, was taken to Paterson Army Hospital in Fort Monmouth to be treated for shock and minor injuries.
' Harold J. Gordon, an investment banker, died Saturday evening at his home in Chicago. He was 79 years old.

Ken Wright, the overweight and under-used pitcher, was optioned to Syracuse and will be replaced by Dave Pagan,. also a pitcher, on the.Yankee roster. Yesterday was not Jim Mason's first three-hit game in the majors. I had three hits against the Yankees one day last season," said the Yankee shortstop who has been hitting surprisingly well. He would've had a fourth hit, but Rollie Fingers, the Oakland pitcher,
Dave DeBusschere, a new face in the offices of the New York Nets, placed his hulking frame behind a desk today and the former Knick put in his first full day as the Nets' general manager.
Senator Henry M. Jackson slid yesterday that the Soviet Union should withdraw its military personnel from Syria if it wanted to show cooperation in working out a Syrian-Isralei agreement.

A 19-year-old girl jogging in a wooded area near the Grand Central Parkway in Queens was raped in broad daylight yesterday and, in struggling with her assailant, apparently suffered back injuries that left her paralyzed from the waist down.
Dennis Guay, who once pleaded guilty to second-degree murder, has been named deputy warden of the Connecticut Correctional Center on Whalley Avenue here.
The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it intends.to use a task force approach to speed-enforcement action against alleged violators of securities laws.

Two Federal offices have been asked to investigate land transactions in the Tocks Island Dam area that allegedly netted some realestate agents quick resale profits from public funds and deprived other landowners of fair prices for their property.

A few days ago we received a communication from the secretary of a library association. It contained a form letter directed to men and women in various professions asking what they would do on a busman's holiday in midtown if they had one day in New York.

Prices rose on the American Stock Exchange and the overthe-counter market yesterday as investors noted signs that interest rates were beginning to peak out. According to the latest reports, commercial and industrial loan demand declined last week.
A new Israeli village will be built in southeastern Sinai, the third such settlement to be set up there since Israel captured Sinai during the 1967 war.

Heyward B. Davenport, deputy executive director of the City Planningn Commission for the last 28 months, was appointed as deputy commissioner of Social Services by the city's Human Resources Administrator, James R. Dumpson.

" We aren't this lively ever in New York," said Ruth Welting, the young soprano from Memphis who will sing the leading role of "Lucia di Lammermoor" in two performances here. "We all come out here and we act crazy."

Attorneys for John D. Ehrlichman presented a mountain of newspaper clippings and testimony by television executives today in an effort to move Mr. Ehrlichman's perjury trial out of Los Angeles on the ground of excessive publicity.
The missing ingredient in the budget-balancing package that Mayor Beame brought home from Albany was disclosed at City Hall yesterday--a $20-million local "nuisance tax,"
Anthony Hyde Francis, who retired in 1967 as vice president and national advertising director of Westchester Rockland Newspapers, Inc., died Tuesday in a White Plains nursing home.
The Federal Reserve Board rejected yesterday the Franklin New York Corporation's planned acquisition of the Talcott National Corporation, a large finance company.
Vice President Ford said today that he was only carrying out "my responsibility" in the fall of 1972 when he helped to undo the first Congressional investigation of the Watergate break-in.

The United States Postal Service today lifted the embargo on Canadian mail for all provinces except Quebec. The embargo was put into effect because of a strike by Canadian postal workers. The Poestal Service said it expected further word on mail destined for Quebec by Friday.
Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel of the Court of Appeals today denounced the Legislature and by implication, Governor Wilson for their handling of the courtreform issue. .
Constantin Brancusi's "La Negresse Blonde II," a work of polished bronze executed in 1926, fetched $750,000 last night, a world record auction price for sculpture.

Instead of a threatened closing yesterday, the Jamaica, Queens,, shelter of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals is to remain open for two more years, according to an agreement announced yesterday by Borough President Donald R. Manes.

United States proposal for a $4-billion-assistance program for economically distressed countries was brushed aside without discussion today by delegates to the General Assembly's special session on raw materials and development.
Dr. Bernard Boris Raginsky, associate physician and honorary attending physician to the Montreal Jewish General Hospital, died Sunday at his home in Montreal. He was 72 years old.

District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn declared yesterday that "a major dent" had been put into operations of all five organized-crime "families" in the city with the indictment of 117 persons allegedly involved in illegal gambling grossing at least $1-billion a year.
President Juan Domingo Peronsilenced chanting left-wing Peronists in a May Day crowd today with a new attack on them and an expression of full support for his conservative followers.
The Health Department has announced the names of '14 more restaurants and food stores charged with having violated the Health Code.

The House Judiciary Committee rejected tonight President Nixon's offer of edited transcripts as a substitute for subpoenaed Watergate tape recordings,. The vote rejecting the transcripts followed the disclosure by the committee's lawyers that the transcripts were, at least in part "not accurate."
Joseph F. Murphy, a, retired assistant vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, died yesterday in a West Palm Beach hospital.
More than 20 Morningside merchants called on Mayor Beame yesterday to provide additional police protection to their area in the aftermath of the killing of a jeweler by two holdup men last Saturday.
Some 150 men who had maintained an around-the-clock vigil since Easter Sunday outside a Metallic Lathers Union headquarters here ended it yesterday in bitterness and disappointment.

David L. Nixon, a lawyer from Boston who is president of the State. Senate, announced his candidacy for Governor today. Mr. Nixon, 42 years old, a liberal, and the incumbent, Gov. Meldvin Thomson, 61, a conservative, are the only two candidates so far in the September Republican primary.

N. Dale Anderson, who succeeded Spiro T. Agnew as Baltimore County Executive, was sentenced to five years in prison today. Mr. Anderson who was convicted March 20 on 32 counts of extortion, conspiracy, and tax evasion, at first refused to resign as County Executive but finally did leave office on April 19.

The New York Times continues today the publication in chronological order of transcripts of Watergate tape recordings as edited and released by the White House. Additional transcripts will be published tomorrow.

NOSY It's not nosiness, it's charity. The Arthritis Foundation's New York chapter today legitimizes traipsing through five homes of very well-to-do New Yorkers to get a glimpse of how the less than-one-per-cent live.

As men and women around the world observed May Day, the international workers' holiday yesterday, celebrations in the great Communist capitals, Moscow and Peking, were marked by an air of informality and relaxation.
The Cities Service Gas Company said today it would curtail natural gas service throughout the summer to some industrial customers so it could build up reserves for next winter.
Brit Selby, Billy Orr and Jack Gibson scored their first goals of the World Hockey Asscoiation tonight as the Toronto Toros' gained a 5-3 victory over the Chicago Cougars.

School Chancellor Irving Anker, displeased by the recent showing at a Bronx high school of a filmstrip explicity depicting sexual acts, said yesterday that he was taking steps to tighten supervision over the use of sex-education material in the city schools.

Governor Wilson's rent program ran into trouble in the Legislature today even before most legislators had a chance to read it, and there were predictions on both sides of the aisle that the Governor's proposals would would need substantial modification before they could be adopted.
The Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda has not accused Turkey of supporting Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq, as was reported in The New York Times on April 27.
The Treasury offered today the highest interest rate on a Government bond since the Civil War - 8 1/2 per cent on a bond that will mature in 25 years.

The main square of this northern hill town, with its 16th-century, facades, began to fill up by midmorning. Not a seat was available at the Cafe Doural and the noise of shouted conversatinns was deafening.

The Fine Arts Chamber Orchestra of New York, an ensemble formed recently under the auspices of the Association for Arts and Culture and under the musical direction of Ronald Isaac, gave its first midtown concert in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night,
A hotly debated issue the World Bridge Federation will have to decide during the next few days at its meetings in the Canary Isles is the use of screens in world championships.

Two thousand supporters of Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn gathered at the Americana Hotel here last night to celebrate the 75th anniversary of their agency, salute the collection efforts in the diocese's parishes and confer awards on two persons for "unselfish support of human services."

An official of the Civil Aeronautics Board was quoted this week as deploring the use of. "doubletalk" in airline ticketing regulations. He didn't mention advertisements, however, but he could have, as a letter from a reader makes clear.

For the first time in its 136-year history, The Akron Beacon Journal was struck today and did not publish. However, the executive editor, Robert Giles said the newspaper intended to resume publication tomorrow.

Portugal celebrated her first May Day holiday in half a century today with an explosion of joy at the end of a dictatorship. A military coup put an end to the Government of Premier Marcello Caetano last Thursday.

A major defense contractor for the Government and the chairman of the concern's board of directors pleaded guilty today to charges of illegally contributing $150,000 in company funds to President Nixon's re-election campaign.

Franklin E. Williams went further than most products of the smalltown ghettos of Florida's eastcentral, "space" coast. He graduated from Morehouse. College in Atlanta; he returned to his home town and became a prominent educator, then last year he was named director of VISTA.

A year or so ago, Fanny, just formed, looked all set to become the first really successful all-female group in rock music. If it hasn't exactly happened that way, Fanny-to judge by its showing at Town Hall on Tuesday-is still in there pitching its highly energized rock'n'roll, still revealing a potent approach to the basic blues form.

Mrs. Louise Grace Ford, widow of, "Senator" Edward H. Ford, the vaudeville comedian best known as a member of the "Can You Top This?" radio show of the nineteen-forties, died Tuesday in St. Clare's Hospital.

President Nixon left by helicopter this afternoon for Camp David, Md., the White House said. Mr. Nixon was expected to stay at least overnight, according to his press spokesman.

Rochester voters indicated overwhelmingly today in a special town vote that they would favor an oil refinery in their city.

A 20-foot-long petition of support was unrolled in President Nixon's Oval Office today as he met with backers from across the country.

American auto plants built 677,783 cars last month, a decline of 19.6 per cent from the 843,242 units built in April, 1973. Production last month was the highest so far this year but still left 1974 production more than a million cars behind output in the first four months of 1973.
The dollar' gained slightly against the pound on the London for eign exchange markets today Gold closed 50 cents higher, at $169.75 an ounce.

A 55-foot Ketch, Southerly, has been declared the winner of the St. Petersberg--to-Mexico yacht race. The vessel, owned by Burt Kennan of Lafayette, La., was first to cross the finish line at Isla de Mujeres last evening and was declared the winner on corrected time today after the rest of the fleet finished. Southerly covered the 456 miles in a record time of 55 hours 33 minutes 45 seconds.
A group or men disguised as the Oakland A's showed up again at Shea Stadium yesterday and just as they did 18 hours earlier, they lost to the Yankees, 4-3.

Charles S. Dewey Jr., an investment adviser, died yesterday at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 65 years old and also lived in East Hampton, L.I.

Earl Weaver, manager of the Baltimore Orioles was informed today that his protest of two games with the New York Yankees was disallowed.

Business was good for Pepsico, Inc., last year and even better during the first quarter of this year, but a number of questions at the annual meeting here today dealt not with profits but with the political activities of Donald M. Kendall, chairman.

Controller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday demanded that the city be compensated for any take-over by the state of Consolidated Edison facilities in the city in lieu of lost revenues.

Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger denied again today that he had any knowledge of the White House "plumbers" group or the involvement of a former aide, David R. Young Jr., in the investigation of domestic security matters.

Albert Chavies, who is being tried for murder in connection with the assassination last September of James McGregor Shabazz, a Black Muslim minister, took the witness stand today to deny vehemently the existence of any plot to kill Mr. Shabazz.

David L. Yunich took office yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and said he was interested in such marketing ideas as a cheaper transit fare in off-peak hours.

The Philadelphia Bell, after a week of indecision, will retain its World Football League franchise and operate' in Philadelphia in 1974. Bell investors became discouraged when the team failed to obtain the University of Pennsylvania's :70,000-seat Franklin Field as a playing site.

A worthwhile concept underlies Governor Wilson's proposals for overhauling New York City's chaotic rentcontrol system, but his specific recommendations would merely make a bad program worse. It is plain that the Governor seeks to apply to the 1.1 million apartments that are still covered by the old world War II control law principles similar to those governing the much more successful stabilization law affecting 250,000 other apartments in this city.
About 3,600 bus drivers and other employes walked off their jobs today despite a court injunction ordering them to work and left the nation's capital jammed with cars carrying commuters and tourists.

A 26-year-old Brooklyn woman was shot in the stomach in the hallway of her home by a man who had followed her home. The wounded woman, Mrs. Dianne Monteleone, was taken to Wyckoff Heights Hospital in critical condition.
Prices of steel, copper, brass, chemicals, aircraft, air-conditioners and other basic materials rose yesterday, the second day after the official end of most wage and price controls.

A man saying he was a member of the gang in the world's biggest art robbery threatened today to burn three Old Masters unless a $250,000 reward was withdrawn, the police said.

The Senate quickly passed and sent to the House today a bill increasing benefit payments to disabled veterans and their survivors. Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana who is chairman of the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee, placed the first-year cost at $566.9-million.

Terrorists threw a bomb into a crowded bar tonight, killing four persons and injuring at least 20, the police reported. Witnesses told the authorities that the terrorists had thrown the bomb from a passing car into the Roman Catholic-owned Rose and Crown in the Ormeau Road district of Belfast.

Shareholders of Fuller Laboratories, Inc., ratified ysterday a bid by Parke-Davis 7/8 Co., a subsidiary of the WarnerLambert Company, to acquire the manufacturer of medical and hospital products. Parke-Davis will exchange 405,280 shares of Warner-Lambert stock for the entire Fuller issue of 445,804 shares.

Central Railroad and various of its subsidiaries and former officers and directors charging fraud in connection with the railroad's collapse in 1970 and losses to stockholders estimated in the billions of dollars.

Homero Blancas, with eagles on two of the last nine holes and nine one-putt greens, surged to the first-round lead of the $150,000 Byron Nelson golf tournament today with a six-under-par 65.

American Standard, Inc, declared yesterday an increase in the company's quarterly dividend to 20 cents a share from 17 1/2, cents. The dividend is payable June 24 to stockholders of record May 23.
