Israel Citkowitz, American composer and piano teacher, died Saturday in his apartment in London, where he had been living for the last five years. His age was 65.
In the Yankee clubhouse before the game today, Fernando Gonzalez was using the locker that had been vacated only minutes before by Rich Sawyer.
The erosion of power-of men who control events gradually overcome by those events - leaps out from the huge transcript of White House conversations that President Nixon made public last week.

Eight-year-old Cub Scouts and a nonagenarian veteran of the Spanish-American war moved up Fifth Avenue yesterday with thousands .of others in a spirited, uptempo parade held by a black war veterans group in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

Mrs. Mary KocKereller Strawbridge, younger daughter of former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and Mrs. Mary Clark Rockefeller, was married here yesterday afternoon to Thomas B. Morgan, press secretary to former Mayor John V. Lindsay from 1969 to 1973.

Vincent Sardi, owner of the tlater-district restaurant bearing his family name, announced last night that he would open .700-seat dinner-theater this summer in Franklin Square, L.I. as the first in a tristate chain.
A stake-out team of Transit Authority policemen yesterday shot a man who was wielding what turned out to be a toy gun in a robbery of a subway token booth in the Bronx.

The recital of sonatas for cello and piano that Zara Nelsova and Grant Johannesen presented Saturday evening at Hunter Colloge was a technically adept, interpretively gracious affair.
Two boys died today when a fire destroyed the house where they, were sleeping and burned sik families out of an adjoining home.

Creativity is one of those much-touted qualities in business as well as the arts. It's supposedly rampant in fashion, which straddles both fields, and where everyone who finds a new place to put a pleat or a pocket is hailed by somebody as a creator.

America's craze for adjustment is gleefully satirized in Terrence McNally's "Bad .Jabits," which, after a successful run Off broadway, last >Might moved' uptown to Broadway. This comedy has no problem of adjustment. It fills .the Booth Theater with laughter.
Dr. Hyman Hershberg, a general practitioner for 50 years, died Thursday In Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx. He was 84 years old and lived at 2080 Barnes Avenue,theBronx.

In the confusion of a t?? tuous final minute, the New York Rangers today let another Next Year slip by them as the. Philadelphia Flyers scored a 4-3 victory and moved to the championship round of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

Blame the fullbacks, the halfbacks, the weather, the photographers or the noise the kids made in the stands, but, please, don't blame the Baltimore Comets for the loss they handed the New York Cosmos in their seasonopener yesterday at Randalls Island.

The record budget for the arts approved by the Legislature and awaiting Governor Wilson's signature is designed to spread culture through the state as it never has been before and also to supply more state funds than ever before for support of major cultural institutions.
South Vietnamese troops and tanks drove four miles into Cambodia yesterday, but were stopped by heavy Communist resistance at a village.

Secretary of State Kissinger flew here today after 'urging Israeli leaders to draw up a new cease-fire line that he could propose to Syria when he returns to Damascus onTuesday in his continuing search for an agreement on the separation of Syrian and Israeli forces.

Teams of panting teenaged Explorer Scouts, wearing blue-and-white sweatshirts imprinted with a big subway token, tore into and out of designated "checkpoint" station-platforms yes terday in a new underground sporting event-an urban cross-country chase called a "subway rally."

Contract talks between' the printers union and the city's three major daily newspapers broke down at 12:30 A.M. today. The Daily News announced it would try to introduce the use of automated typesetting processes tonight.

China's political leadership is aging, so it is not surprising that state funerals seem to occur with relative frequency in Peking. For China watchers, these events are of more than moron bid interest, for China the published lists of those who send wreaths and those who mourn often seem to contain hints on the political status of the quick as well as the dead.

HOUSTON-Not one but two threats should concern Americans today. Attention is being given to one: the threat of continuing shortages of energy supplies. The second threat is much more subtle yet far more dangerous. It is the fast support developing for an economic philosophy based on the simple premise that the Federal Government can run almost any sort of business better than private enterprise.
Protestants led by Brian Faulkner have agreed to form a new party in an attempt to win back apparently dwindling support for power-sharing in Northern Ireland.

The Utah Stars, -trailing New York, 2-0, in their American Basketball Association championship series, will be counting on the return of Zelmo Beaty to try and combat the Nets' "cheating" defense tonight in game No. 3 at Salt Lake City.

John Milner's two-run homer in the 10th inning of the second game at Shea Stadium yesterday gave the Mets a 6-4 victory over the San Diego Padres and prevented a double giveaway by Manager Yogi Berra's men.

Progress was reported last night in contract negotiations between the printers union and New York City's three major daily newspapers in an effort to avert a confrontation threatened for tonight at The Daily News.

The existence of the White House tape-recording machines was disclosed last July 16 by Alexander P. Butterfield,' a former Presidential aide for administration and security, in testimony- before the Senate Watergate Committee.

One of the two fugitives who fled from the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men on Friday night was captured last night a Brooklyn Hospital where he was being treated for abroken heel apparently suffered in the escape, the police said.
The Cornell varsity crew, possibly a growing giant, won the Carnegie Cup here today on the Housatonic River by 2 1/2 lengths. Princeton was second, just ahead of Yale.

Sandra Spuzich knocked in a 6-foot putt for a par on the fifth extra hole today and won a three-way playoff in the $35,000 Lady Tara Open for her first victory on the pro golf tour in five years. Miss Spuzich came out of the left rough with a brilliant shot to set up her victory on the par-4, 400-yard hole.

Harold M Has-well, director of racing at Saratoga Harness, died today at Saratoga Hospital. He was 61 years old. Known as Hap, he was associated with the harness track here since 1944 and had been racing secretary for 23 years.

" Bravo for private Swiss venture capital!" says Hans BaerZurich banker, doting father, and an unabashed customeradmirer of Franz Carl Weber, the celebrated Swiss toy empire that has just bought F. A. O. Schwarz.
The courtship of has ended. Lee, the star guard of DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, signed a letter of intent yesterday and will attend Marquette University in Milwaukee.
Miss Marcia Halleran was married here yesterday afternoon to William Reidy in the Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Evangelist. The Rev. John I. Cervini performed the ceremony.

Miss Heidi E. Humphrey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Griswold Humphrey 2d of Storrs, Conn., and Guilford, Vt., was married yesterday afternoon to Henry Hobart Benedict 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Benedict, of Bethany, Conn.

Carters General Store-it's the only store for a quartermile around in its Ozone ParkSouth Jamaica neighborhood of pleasant frame homes. It sells groceries, beer and soft drinks.

Diminishing winds gave at least temporaryy relief today from a heavy, irritating blanket of smoke over the Miami-West Palm Beach area this weekend. The smoke from several fires smoldering in the Everglades west of Miami reduced visibility to less than a mile in the city yesterday morning, but was not quite as bad today.
The Van Buren Hotel, a vacant welfare hotel owned by a central figure in a policecorruption investigation, was destroyed today in a suspicious predawn fire.

A growing number of real estate zoning suits, many filed by taxpayers angered by the proliferation of high-rise office buildings: and apartments over the shrinking acres of suburbia are cropping up on the docket of Bergen County Superior Court in Hackensack.
Richard L. Ottinger, the former Representative who is running again for Congress as the Democratic candidate in Westchester's 24th District, said yesterday he was worth more than $2.2-million.

Miss Francisca Cora Ehrenclou was married here yesterday afternoon to Robert S. Rowell, a landscape designer and artist of Nicasio, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Walter Donald Kring performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls.

Nearly $1.3-million in stolen property recovered by the Police Department last month will be put on display Wednesday and Thursday at the department's former headquarters building at 240 Centre Street in an effort to identify its owners.

WASHINGTON-The word "browse," as a noun, means the tender shoots and twigs that cattle like to feed upon. Over the years, the action of a cow nibbling gently in a pasture became known as browsing, and now given new meaning as a verb--browse is applied to those relaxed souls who find time to enrich their minds by' casually perusing volumes-in a bookstore.

Adding to an outstanding list of television dance programs, WNET/13 tonight at 8 o'clock is offering "Alvin Ailey: Memories and Visions" as the Public Broadcasting Corporation's Special of the Week.

Governor Wilson and Mayor Beame are heading for a showdown with the Environmental Protection Administration over a plan, drafted by their predecessors, to meet Federal air-quality standards for transportation in New York City.

The Pohang Iron.and Steel Company, South Korea's largest steel manufacturer, announce over the weekend a $99.9-million contract for construction; of a cold rolling mill at the port city of Pohang by a consortium consisting of Wean United, Inc., of Pittsburg; Voest-Alpine of Austria, and Siemens A:G. of West Germany.
Wayne Embry played the role of Red Auerbach, his old friend and one-time boss of the Boston Celtics, today.

Horses worked out today at Churchill Downs, but nobody ekcept their handlers paid any attention. The big show was over. , In the stands under the twin spires and over in the deserted infield an army of clean up men with rakes and truck's inched their way through the tornado of trash left by a record crowd of 163,628 who saw Cannonade win yesterday's 100th Kentucky Derby under a smart ride by Angel Cordero Jr.

Two Palestinian guerrillas convicted of having killed five persons and wounded 55 during a grenade' and pistol attack at Athens airport last year were expelled from Greece today and put aboard an airliner bound for Libya.

The police arrested 60 persons in Margate for alleged possession of marijuana and barbiturates in an early-morning raid on a rented summer home. All suspects were charged with possession of less than 25 grams of marijuana and possession of prescription drugs, including barbiturates. The suspects, all between 18 and 30 years old, were released on bond on their own recognizance.

Chile's military Government has commuted death sentences imposed on five socialists, the Interior Minister, Gen. Oscar Bonilla Bradanovic, announced here tonight. The five socialists were found guilty by a court-martial in San Fernando, southwest of here, 10 days ago on charges of formington a paramilitary group.

Chancellor Willy Brandt, taking responsibility for "negligence" that allowed an East German Communist spy to become a member of his staff, took the unexpected step tonight of tendering his resignation to President Gustav W. Heinemann.

The Boeing Company reported at its annual meeting in Seattle yesterday that its firstquarter earnings rose by 64.5 per cent and were the highest for any quarter in almost six years. Net earnings of $17.6-million, equal to 83 cents a share, represented 2.1 per cent of sales, which totaled $841.4million. In the 1973 opening quarter the company earned $10.7-million, or 49 cents a share, amounting to 1.7 per cent of $630.8-million sales.

After editing the Watergate tapes to its own satisfaction, the White House now says they prove that John Dean cannot be believed. The trouble with this is that it John Dean had done the editing we would probably have an edition proving the White House cannot be believed.

President Juan Domingo Peron of Argentina will visit the Soviet Union later this year, probably in September or October, his personal delegate to Moscow announced today. The Soviet leadership has in the last 24 hours given an unusually warm welcome to Jose B. Gelbard, the Argentine Minister of the Economy,

World trade showed an explosive growth of 36 per cent last year and of 12 per cent event after allowing for higher prices, the International Monetary Fund reported today. The 12 per cent rise in the "real volume" of trade was "far above the average annual growth in past years," the report said. The boom reflected the general prosperity and strong economic growth of all industrial counties in 1973.

The first rules of the White Plains Public. Library were simple but, in some cases, somewhat severe: Any resident over 10 years of age could borrow one book at a time for two weeks. A truant officer was sent after those who kept books more than a month.

The executive commission of the Common Market will .propose tomorrow that the nine members approve as a unit the bulk of the restrictions on imports announced by Italy last week. The measure, which covers 42 per cent of Italian imports, mainly consumer goods, requires importers to make a six-month, interest-free deposit of 50 per cent of the value of the goods imported and goes into effect at midnight tonight.
Waves of selling swept all key commodity futures exchanges yesterday, forcing potential buyers to hide and observe the first rule of their trade-never buck a trend.

Washington's residents will decide tomorrow whether, for the first time in a century, they will have a voice in their own government and thus be able to throw away their "last colony" bumper stickers.

A defensive lineman, Wally Chambers, was named today as recipient of the Brian Piccolo Award for 1974 and received a trophy from two teammates, Dick Butkus and Jim Osborne. Osborne won last season's award, presented to the Bears' rookie who best exemplifies the spirit of Brian Piccolo, a running back for the Bears who died of Cancer.

As he approached final negotiations with Governor Wilson over means to close the city's perennial budget gap last month, Mayor Beame took time out to open an exhibit on how not to be burglarized, mugged, raped or robbed, sponsored by the Police Department and the Association for a Better New York.

The United States Treasury will sell $3.75-billion of securities this week paying 8 3/4 per :ent annual interest-the highest coupon on Federal securities since the Civil War-but an investor cannot buy one unless he has at least $10,000 to invest.

After close to 30 years in public life, Francois Mitterrand, who led the field in the presidential election yesterday, winning a pisce in the runoff vote May 19, is still someMen thing of a mysin the tery to many Frenchmen. News As a personal ity Mr. Mitterrand, who is 57 years old, leaves no one indifferent to him. Frenchmen wonder about him, hate him or love him.
The Interior Department said today that it would make a "smallscale test" of royalty bidding in its September offering of oil leases for two million acres of seabed off the coast, of Louisiana.
Governor Wilson has abandoned his plan for aid to higher education, accepting the approach put forward by the Legislature and agreeing to double the appropriation he had called for only last week.

Dr. Franz Christian Jost, who was the chief of the diabetic clinic at St. Vincent's Hospital from 1958 to 1965 and a specialist in the disease since 1933, died Sunday at the Putnam Hospital, Bennington, Vt. His age was 74, and he lived in Whitingham, Vt. Dr. Jost received his medical degree in 1924 from the University of Innsbruck in Austria. He also spent five years of post-graduate study at the University of Vienna.

TAIPEI, Taiwan - After more than a decade of spectacular economic growth, Taiwan is threatened with the loss of its all-important competitive advantage, which had been based on its cheap labor and ability to' marnufacture inexpensively for export.

Production of Tuesday editions of the Washington Post was delayed more than two h urs tonight after management was reported to have given printers a 36-hourl ultimatum to stop an alleged production slowdown. Governor Wilson has abandoned his plan for aid to higher education, accepting the approach put forward by the Legislature and agreeing to double the appropriation he had called for only last week. In long weekend negotiating sessions, with the legislative leaders, it was learned today, the Governor reportedly agreed to spend $3.8-million this year for a new kind of direct student aid.

Exposures of questionable contributions to President Nixons' re-election campaign and of his relatively small incometax payments won Pulitzer Prizes for national reporting yesterday. The awards were announced for the 58th year in a row.

The mooning saxophones and rising brass accents of big-band music inaugurated a lunchtime series of cultural events in Bryant Park yesterday. A constantly changing crowd of perhaps 500 gathered behind the New York Public Library to tap their toes appreciatively to the nineteen-forties' sound of Harry Terrill and the Mitchell Ayres Orchestra and applaud opening remarks by Carol Channing, the musical comedy star.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, and two House members urged to-day that more money be spent on growing timber in the national forests to help provide lumber and plywood for building homes. Speaking at a meeting of the National Forests Products Association, they said the budget for the United States Forest Service was generally to low.

Princess Margaret and her husband, Lord Snowdon, on their first visit to New York City in six years, received Mayor and Mrs. Beame last night at the royal suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. The two couples talked about horses, the weather and the Mayor's birthplace in England. They joked during the taking of photographs of the meeting in the royal couple's plush three-room suite, decorated in French antiques and gold Victorian mirrors.

This city voted today to lease Memphis Memorial Stadium to the Toronto franchise of the World Football League, perhaps closing the door to obtaining a National Football League expansion franchise. J. Alan Hanover, the Toronto Northmen's attorney here said after the vote that the team owner, John Bassett Jr., had told him he would move the franchise to Memphis if the lease was approved.
The Persian Gulf Arab y emirate of Abu Dhabi has signed a two new sales deals for crude oil with American companies, the authoritative Middle East Economic Survey has reported.

Arthur Donow, a public accountant, who - was controller of the Nassau County Public. Welfare Department from 1930 to 1950, died Sunday of a heart attack in Boynton Beach, FlaHe was 65 years old and lived in Port Jefferson, L.I., and in Delray Beach, Fla. Mr. Donow graduated from Pace College.

Cabin crews of British Airways' Overseas Division went on strike at midnight tonight and the airline canceled all trans-Atlantic and other long-distance flights. The first affected were flights to the Caribbean island of Antigua and Lima. Peru, and two flights from Manchester to New York and Montreal.

Herbert W. Kalmbach has testified about a midnight meeting at which he said a top dairy cooperative official was told that milk prices would be increased and that the White House wanted confirmation of a $2-million campaign pledge, according to informed sources.

Nine inmates escaped from detention facility in the city's prison complex on Rikers Island last night by squirming through a ground-floor window that had bee pried open, authorties reported. Three of them commandeered a tugboat.

The long-delayed John F. Kennedy Library, once envisioned as a massive complex dominated by a glass pyramid, is being redesigned because local residents complained it would be too grandiose. The original plans, disclosed in an elaborate ceremony one year ago, have been set aside quietly in favor of a vastly scaled down version, library officials said in interviews.

The police-corruption witness being fought over by Federal and state prosecutors set off the battle by providing new information linking organized crime figures to narcotics cases, United States Attorney Paul J. Curran disclosed yesterday. The disclosure -- in Mr. Curran's continuing dispute with the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari -- strengthened indications that the witness is involved in current investigations dating from the so called French Connection case.

Waves of selling swept all key- commodity futures exchanges yesterday, forcing potential buyers to hide and observe the first rule of their trade--never buck a trend. The trend was set when all farm commodities opened down their respective daily permissible limits, and traded at those levels or very close to them until the close.

Fred Buzhardt, said today. He explained that the system was voice actuated - that is, turned on by the sound of voices and stopped when there were pauses in speech.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today that "deep down". he would like to be President, but if he-had to make a final decision now he would not run. Mr. Kennedy said he would make his decision "sometime by late 75, possibly earlier" and added, "I think I have that degree of time in order to make any kind of..a deci-.. sion on it."

Angel 'Cordero was back on the job at Aqueduct yesterday, after having ridden Cannonad to victory in the Kentucky. Derby at Churchill Downs last Saturday, and finishing fourth in the Century at Hollywood Park in California on Sunday. When he came out for the first race on a colt called Pancho Jay, Cordero was roundly greeted by many. in the crowd of 20,716.

If you want to boil the frenetic Ranger-Flyer semifinal series down to a single explanation, listen to Orest Kindrachuk, the Philadelphia center: "We played 78 hard games to gain the home-ice advantage; we weren't going to let them take it away from us after all that hard work."
In network television's massaudience programing' departments there are executives, usually vice presidents, in charge of something called "programing practices." What they are actually, are censors.

Pravda today chastised Soviet oilmen in the energy-rich regions of northern Russia for moving much too cautiously in exploiting new oil finds and told them to speed up the time from discovery of deposits to commercial use of oil fields.

SMITHTOWN, L. I--Goodsized brook trout, some about a foot long, darted into midstream or sought the shelter of undercut banks as we moved along the Nissequoque, a lovely Long Island river that has escaped the depredations of civilization. A hatch of midges was on the water, mallards and Canada geese were nesting in secluded nooks, and once a muskrat- 'which we first thought was a rising troutsplashed in alarm at our approach.

The fraud charges filed against the bankrupt Penn Central and some of its former top officers in connection with the railroad's financial collapse four years ago add a dismaying-though long expected-chapter to a sordid story of corporate mismanagement and deceit at the expense of the investing public.

A 15-point lead with less than eight minutes to play wasn't enough for victory tonight, and a 3-point deficit in the final second wasn't enough for defeat for the New York Nets, who went on to a 103-100 overtime victory over the Utah Stars.

The Nixon Administration was astounded tonight by Chancellor Willy Brandt's resignation, so much so that some officials concerned with West Germany were momentarily speechless when told of the hews. Both the White House and the State Department responded to initial queries with "no comment."

Policies of the Nixon Administration "have hindered more than they have helped" in the "delivery of services to those suffering from mental illness," Dr. John P. Spiegel of Brandeis University, president-elect of the American Psychiatric Association, charged today.

New Jersey's race-track operators breathed a collective sigh of relief with the easing of the gasoline shortage. They had reason, for most are dependent on the automobile for their business. Freehold Raceway falls into the same category, but the comparison ends there. The harness track opened March 1 during the height of the fuel problem, but it suffered no serious effects.

A Federal judge took under advisement today a ruling on whether William L. Calley Jr., now a civilian, should remain free on bond. However, Judge J. Robert Elliott indicated strongly that he would continue the bond when he told Government attorneys who had sought to revoke Mr. Calley's bail that he found ample legal precedence for continuing it.

Classes at Morristown High School were canceled shortly after noon today following clashes between black and white students. Eight students were injured, but all were released from hospitals after treatment.

Frustration is like other intangibles. It's usually difficult to put a price on it. But for followers of the New York Rangers, the price of frustration is $5-million. That's approximately the amount they have contributed to the Madison Square Garden box office in the last eight years for the frustration of watching Stanley Cup games.

Brooks Tillotson, one of The busiest and best French horn players in this area, gave a concert Sunday night at Town Hall that was heavy on excellent performances though light in musical substance. Mr. Tillotson, assisted by eight fellow freelance musicians of comparable ability, played with exceptional agility throughout the program, which included two first performances.

Charles W. Duncan Jr., president of the Coca-Cola Company, the largest soft-drink company in the world, will resign this morning at the company's board meeting. According to sources close to Coca-Cola in Atlanta, Mr. Duncan, who is 47 years old, said privately some weeks ago that he would leave the company to return to his native city of Houston at the head of a pipeline construction company there.

With more major banks raising.. their prime interest rates, prices on the Ameritan Stock Exchange fell. againyesterday with volume dropping to its lowest point in seven months. The over-the-counter market's reaction to the moves was mixed.

About 60 members of Congress have voluntarily made public disclosure of their tax returns or net financial worth. Some 25 others who were questioned in an Associated Press survey of all 534 Congressman say they are preparing to make a public accounting of their finances or are considering that step. Full public disclosure by members of Congress is not required by law.

The executive council of the Building and Construction Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor and Council of Industrial Otganizations unanimously elected Robert A. Georgine today as president of the department.

The judge in the murder and conspiracy trial of Black Muslim Albert Chavies today denied a motion for acquittal by the defendant's lawyer and told the jury to be prepared to receive the case by noon tomorrow.

Something new and something old popped up in tennis during the weekend as action ranged over the United States, Canada, Europe and Asia. It was new to see playing for Yugoslavia in the Davis Cup. Last year the volatile left-hander got into trouble over his commitment to play for his country, which led to the wholesale walkout at Wimbledon by the players' association.

I shouldn't say this, but I have the feeling it may be the beginning of the end for us," a high West German official said a couple of weeks ago. By "it" he meant the arrest of an East German spy on the staff of Chancellor Willy Brandt and by "us" he meant the Social Democratic party Ied by Mr. Brandt.

An. Eastern milk producers' group, the Lehigh Valley Cooperative Farmers of Allentown, Pa., was fined $5,000 today after pleading guilty to allegations that it illegally gave $50,000 to President Nixon's re-election campaign. The cooperative, through its lawyer, James Rosenberg, entered a guilty plea before Chief Judge George L. Hart Jr., in United States District Court. Lehigh. represents some 950 milk producers in eastern -Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Maryland.

The International Monetary Fund disclosed today that Arab and other oil-producing nations had "indicated their willingness to lend to the fund" about $2.75-billion to help establish a special new "oil facility" that would lend money to oil-importing countries at a time when these countries will nearly all have deficits in their balance of payments because of higher petroleum prices.

Vladimir. Horqwitz, who last played in 'public six years ago, will emerge again' for a recital at Severence Hall in Cleveland Sunday afternoon. The 69-year-old pianist's program, sponsord by the Musical Arts 'Association governing body' of the Cleveland Orchestra, will' in Clude works of Clementi, Chopin, Scriabin and Schumann. Tickets, scaled from $25'to $5, were to go on sale this morning. The hall, home of the Cleveland Orchestra, 'seats 2,030.

To the Editor: This letter is prompted by the sickening spectacle pictured in the May 1 Times of a group of public officials smirking happily over the signing of a New Jersey bill to repeal the 1962 covenant with respect to Port Authority expenditures in the mass-transit field. Public credit depends in a large measure on the good faith of government at all levels.

One of the three parties in Iceland's leftist coalition cabinet withdrew today in protest over the Government's anti-inflation policies. Premier Olafur Johannesson said he would either resign or ask President Kristjan Eldjarn to dissolve Parliament and call new elections as a result of the defection of the small Liberal Left party.

, the television playwright whose drama "The Defenders" won an Emmy award in 1964, died yesterday of a heart attack at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived at 22 Chestnut Avenue, Larchmont, N.Y.

The Whirlpool Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase prices on most of its brand appliances, effective May 28. The company did not say what the increases would be. The new round of price increases follows earlier advances that became effective March 1. Although Whirlpool did not specify the increases, industry sources estimated that. they averaged about 3 per cent.
Three men aboard a 26-foot cabin cruiser whose engine broke down a mile and a half at sea were rescued today after a 12-hour search by Coast Guard ships and a helicopter.

A contractor who is a key Government witness in the extorsion trial of Representatives Angelo D. Roncallo. Insisted again today that he had paid the defendant $1,000 in 1970 to avoid business ruin,...

Angel Sagaz Zubelzu, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, died today at his home in Jaen, in southern Spain, the Embassy said. He was 61 years old. Mr. Sagaz had been ill with cancer of the bladder and was flown to Spain on April 16 in a United States Air Force plane provided by President Nixon.

William E. Haynes, a mechanical engineer, who formerly headed the vocational shop departments of Thomas Edison, Woodrow Wilson and Jamaica Vocational High Schools, all in Jamaica, Queens, died yesterday in Manhasset (L.I) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 57 Deepdale Drive, Manhasset.

An escaped bank robber was wounded, a corrections officer was pistolwhipped and a bystander was injured today in an abortive attempt to free an inmate of Trenton State Prison who was attending his grandfather's funeral here. The incident touched off a shoot-out, in which at least seven shots were fired, and a getaway attempt in which the prisoner and his accomplice were captured after a chase of several blocks.

The House Ways and Means Committee approved today legislation designed to protect both the Government and the public from incompetent or corrupt tax-return preparers. The committee adopted a seven-point program, covering those who prepare tax returns for others for a fee as part of a larger tax reform bill on which it is working.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz refused yesterday to discuss details of a recent meeting with prominent Broadway producers who appealed for the continuation of Gerald Schoenfeld, Bernard Jacobs and Irving Goldman as trustees of the Shubert Foundation.

WASHINGTON-Secretary, of State Kissinger and the Panamanian Foreign Minister, Juan Antonlo Tack, on Feb. 7 signed a Joint Statement of Principles" to serve as the basis of treaty negotiations for the surrender of United States sovereignty in the Canal Zone.

Both the Government of India and the nation's railroad workers refused today to make concessions to avoid the nationwide railway strike called for Wednesday and the railroad workers' national coordinating committee said, "Now the fight is on." "All attempts for negotiated settlement of our demands have been frustrated by the adamant attitude of the Government," the committee charged.

WILL ROGERS' U.S.A., adapted and directed by Paul Shyre; setting by Eldon Elder; production stage manager, Bernard Pollack. Presented by George Spota, in association with Lester Osterman Productions, Lester Osterman-Richard Horner. At the Helen Hayes Theater, West 46th Street. With James Whitmore.

Battered investors have watched in dismay as such premier, growth stocks as xerox, Disney and Avon have succumbed one by one to the selling touched off by the October middle East War. Many are asking themselves a question that has come up more and more frequently in recent years: Is growth as we have known It in the stock market dead?

Two years ago, only 55 per cent of Americans of voting age participated in the Presidential electionwhich meant, incidentally, that President Nixon, despite his "landslide," was elected by only about one-third of the nation's potential voters.

Prof. Alfred R. Ferguson, a leading Emerson scholar, died yesterday at the age of 58. Professor Ferguson had been editor in chief for 10 volumes of "The Works of Ralph Waldo Emerson," an 'edition for the Harvard University Press. He was also one of the original faculty members of the University of Massachusetts at Boston.

Last October, Bridget Rose Dugdale stood before a judge after a jury had found her guilty of a theft of paintings from her wealthy parents. The judge, Sir Hugh Park, gave her a suspended two-year sentence and set her free, saying:

Among the winning favorites today in the North and South amateur golf tourinament were Dick Siderowf of Westport, Conn.,the British Amateur champion, and George Burns of Manhasset, L. I., the Canadian titleholder, who won 'the: medalist honors in qualifying play;

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it had reversed an earlier decision that would have reduced steelmaking capacity at its plant at Johnstown, Pa., from 2.3 million tons to l million tons annually. Phasing down the operations at Johnstown as originally planned would have eliminated 4,900 jobs.

The energy crisis, which has created huge profits for the nation's major oil companies and a pain in the pocketbook for millions of motorists, has also generated growing profits for te neighborhood service station owner.

Second-period goals by BOD Liddington, Jan Popiel, Bob Sicinski and Darryl Maggs powered Chicago to a. 5-2 victory over the Toronto Toros tonight and clinched the World Hockey Association semifinal- playoff for the Cougars, four games to three.

Harvard's unbeaten varsity crew was seeded first yesterday for the Eastern sprint championships on Saturday at Lake Quinsigamond in Worcester, Mass, The other seeded' crews were, in order: Wisconsin, Massachusetts Institute. of Technology, Cornell, Pennsylvania and Northeastern.

Burr Linden Chase, who retired in 1962 as board chairman of Silver Burdett Publishers, a division of the General Learning Corporation, Morristown, N. J., died Friday at his home in Madison, N. J. He was 82 years old.

The Senate rejected today an Adminstration request for $266million in additional military aid for South Vietnam. The vote was 43 to 38. The action was a serious Congressional setback to the Administration's foreign policy.

LAS PALMAS, Canary Islands, May 6-The American teams substantially improved their standings in the World Mixed Team Championship here this afternoon. Most of them were well over average, and it is highly likely that at least four of the teams to qualify for the eight-team round-robin final will be from the United States. Play is in two sections, with four teams to qualify from each.
Angel Cordero was back on the job at Aqueduct yesterday, after having ridden Cannonade to victory in the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs last Saturday,

The N.C.A.A. Council announced today its endorsement of two bills in Congress that would affect participation by amateur athletes in international competition. The council, a policymaking body of the 775member National Collegiate Athletic Association, approved the measures at its weekend spring meeting at Kansas City ...

Since January, "Let My People Come" has been running at the Village Gate and doing sell-out business '(at $9.50 top on weekends). Negotiations are under way for national and international touring companies. An original cast album has been cut. The cast has joined Actors Equity. The show has all the earmarks of success except for blurbs in ads.

DEMOCRACY AND ITS DISCONTENTS. By Daniel J. Boorstin. 136 pages. Random House. $5.95 Because we insist on seeing the present as "the climax of our history," says Daniel Boorstin, we Americans are nearly always disillusioned. In human beings, unfortunately, climaxes are usually followed by anticlimaxes. Our imprisonment in the present, the author adds, a prison stripped of the comforts of perspective, leads to a morbid preoccupation with ourselves.
Mary and Herman are not your usual. kind of police team, but for the next month they'll become a familiar patrol pair in a corner of Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation, meeting here yesterday, declared a dividend of 85 cents a share but omitted a special dividend of 35 cents a share that was paid a year ago. Late last month the company reported an 81 per cent drop in this year's first-quarter earnings to 41 cents a share from the year-earlier $2.84 a share.

A college administrator hired as a consultant last year by Bloomfield College to examine the institution's financial status testified in Essex County Court today that he had not recommended reduction of the tenured faculty

President Nixon backed down today from his opposition to the Watergate special prosecutor's subpoena for tapes and records of 64 White House conversations by indicating through his lawyers that he was willing to reach an "accommodation" with the prosecution.

Dozens of policemen wielding rifles and wooden clubs today detained 260 Americans, whom they described as hippies, at this Mexican port in Baja California. The police said they moved in after the Americans had damaged the luxurious Hotel Bahia. They said one American assaulted a policeman and then several of the group threw another policeman into a swimming pool.

William F. Buckley Jr. observed in his syndicated column recently that John Mitchell and Maurice Stans probably had spent as much as $200,000 apiece in legal fees to win acquittal in their trail for perjury, obstruction of justice and conspiracy to "fix" the Vesco case in the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The Whirlpool Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase prices on most of its brand appliances, effective May 28. The company did not say what the increases would be.

The first rules of the White Plains Public, Library were simple but, in some cases, somewhat severe, Any resident over 10 years of age could borrow one book at a time for two weeks. A truant officer was sent, after those Who kept books more than a month.

President Nixon will deliver the commencement address Saturday evening at Oklahoma State University at Stillwater, a White House spokesman said today. The press Secretary Ronald L. Ziegler, reft open the possibility that Mr. Nixon might decide to go on to Key Biscayne, Fla., after the appearance. Mr. Nixon's list appearance on a college campus Was last June when he delivered the commencement address at Florida State Technological University.

The city school system could have built one and a half small elementary schools last year for the amount it spent to repair broken windows and the damage caused by break-ins and fires, a topranking school official said yesterday.

A tax ruling involving the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's Canadian subsidiary, Canadian Occidental Petroleum, Ltd., has forced the LOS Angeles-baed company to lower its previously reported 1973 consolidated net income by $2.3-milion or 5 cents a share. The company also was required to lower its 1972 profit by $1.8-milion, or 3 cents a share, acording to an addendum to the 1973 annual report.

Mary and Herman are not your usual kind of police team, but for the next month they'll become a familiar patrol pair in a corner of Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx. Mary is a police officer--the first woman ever scheduled to be assigned to mounted patrol duty in the history of the New York Police Department.

The automated process that The Daily News said it was prepared to introduce last night is known as "cold type"--a sharp contrast' from the traditional and cumbersome "hot metal" of newspaper composing rooms. It is considered automatedand therefore, in the current situation, controversial - because it permits a typist to tap out the letters and words of an article one at a time, continuously, without having to stop to. think about the ends of line.

The 41-foot sloop Surefire, which disappeared a week ago during a 500-mile yacht race and was feared lost with her crew of three, docked at her home port, Coral Harbor, today. Her owner-captain, Gene Broadbent,refused to comment on where she had been.

In an atmosphere of bedsheets and banners, luckynumber scorecards, spectators shouting without being reprimanded, substitutions and play-by-play statistics, World Team Tennis arrived on the professional sports scene tonight.

The president of an 1,100-member group of Conservative rabbis proposed today that the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, the major institution for the training of Conservative rabbis, consider admitting women for ordination as rabbis. Rabbi Judah Nadich, head of the group, the Rabbinical Assembly, also urged that his organization's committee on Jewish law and standards "give careful consideration"

Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson announced today that the public had donated, more than $600,000 toward the $2-million needed to create a memorial to the late President. The memorial, a grove of500 white pine trees along the banks .of the Potomac River, will be, entirely financed through public con-: tributions.

Twenty-two Governors, 31 Mayors and 18 presidents of state bar associations urged today that Congress reject a restrictive proposal for legal services for the poor that the House approved almost a year ago. The officials sent telegrams to President Nixon and the Senate-House conference committee that has been wrestling with the controversial issue for more than a month, calling for final passage of the version of the measure that cleared the Senate last January...

The American Indian Movement said today that it considered South Dakota to 'be "a zone of war" and urged a boycott of the state by tourists. The Indian civil rights organization said in a statement issued here that tourists' cars were subject to being seized by Indians.

Vice President Ford last night told businessmen who might be planning to vote for Democratic candidates in this fall's Congressional elections because of the Watergate scandal that an overwhelmingly Democratic Congress could be bad for the nation's business community.

On May 6, 1954, at the Iffley Road Track in London, a slim, sandy-haired, 25-year- . old Oxford medical student named Roger Bannister ran the world's first mile in under four minutes, On the 20th anniversary of that event yesterday, plans for a reunion bringing together most of the world's greatest milers of the last 20 years were announced here by Sports Illustrated magazine and the National Art Museum of Sport.

a professional, became the third highest pole vaulter in history yesterday when he cleared 18 feet 4 inches in an all-comers meet. Only Bob Seagren (185 3/4) and Kjell Isaksson of Sweden (18- 1/4) have vaulted higher.

City Democrats in the Legislature said today that they were being subjected to an impressive application of personal and political persuasion by Mayor Beame as he sought to push through his fiscal package with its painful city sales-tax rise.

The 1 Peronist left wing, in -a major statement published today, vowed to remain within the Peronist movement despite the rebuff received from President Juan Domingo Per6n last week at the May Day celebrations here. A number of politicians and commentators had suggested that the break between the 78year-old leader and his youthful left-wing followers had become permanent after Gen-: eral Peron denounced them as "idiots," "traitors" and "foreign-paid mercenaries."

The publication of The Daily News was delayed at least four hours last night as the paper prepared to use automated typesetting processes, if necessary, to counter a 19-day slowdown by its 1,000 printers.

Shortages or no shortages, the Premium Show. was bigger than ever yesterday as it opened its four-day stay. at the New York Coliseum with about 1,050 exhibitors and 24,298 registrations. But it seemed as if everyone exhibiting at the 36th annual show-except perhaps Frank Noel of Cincinnati-was running into shortage problems. Mr. Noel, who is with the Velva Sheen Manufacturina Corporation.

New Jersey today became the first state to enact a law providing public funds for the campaigns of candidates for Governor in the general election. At a public signing of the bill, Governor Byrne called the law, which will provide funds starting in 1977, a "first, giant step toward removing the evil of the. large, private contribution from gubernatorial campaigns."

the Senate rejected today and Administration request for $266-million in additional military aid for South Vietnam. The vote was 43 to 38. The action was serious Congressional setback to the Administration's foreign policy.

An escaped bank robber was wounded and a corrections officer was pistol-whipped today in an abortive attempt to free an inmate of Trenton State Prison who was attending his grandfather's funeral here.
The Exxon Corporation announced yesterday that it had raised prices by. 3.2 cents a gallon for gasoline and 3 cents a gallon for distillate products, including diesel fuel, heating oil and kerosene.

The Exxon Corporation announced yesterday that it had raised prices by 3,2 cents a gallon for gasoline and 3 cents a gallon for distillate products, including diesel fuel, heating oil and kerosene. A spokesman said that the increases were pass through of unrecovered higher costs for raw materials and imported products.

Exposures of questionable contributions to President Nixons' re-election campaign and of his relatively small income-tax payments won Pulitzer Prizes for national reporting yesterday. The awards were a announced for the 58th year in a row.

Steven Grossman, who opened for Elliott Murphy at Max's Kansas City through last night, writes autobiographical songs of an intensely personal sort. That itself isn't all that unusual. What distinguished Mr. Grossman's work is the quality of his material, the distinctive manner in which he sings, and above all the fact that he is homosexual.

Under the spur of supply shortages in many parts of the world, the price of sugar is soaring again in commodities markets. Yet the United States, with the capacity to grow much more sugar than it does, is still paying domestic producers to hold down their output.

Yields on three month and six-month United States Treasury bills were higher in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities. The average rate for threemonth bills in this week's sale is 9.036 per cent, up from last week's 8.909 per cent. The average rate for six-month bills in the weekly sale is 9.006 per cent, up from 8.796 per cent a week ago.

Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago was hospitalized yesterday with an ailment diagnosed as hypoglycemia, an abnormally low level of glucose in .the blood that causes weakness and fatigue. His condition was believed to be not serious. The 71-year-old Democrat was in his. City Hall office when he complained to associates that he did not feel well.

The Liao Clinic, the state's first acupuncture clinic, opened today with its founder warning that the much-publicized practice was not a cureall. Dr. Sung J. Liao of Middlebury, the clinic founder opened the facility in association with Dr. Clifford C. Chu of Norwalk and Dr. Alice Lui, a cancer specialist formerly associated with the Downstate University Medical Center in New-York.

SAIGON, South Vietnam Communist forces overran a 40-man, militia post guarding a hamlet on the South China Sea Coast, 340 miles north of Saigon, and took over the hamlet after a short fight, the Saigon military command said today. The hamlet of about 1,200 Inhabitants is seven miles south of Tam Ky. provincial capital, the command said. It ` said the attack started yesterday afternoon and radio con. tact lost soon afterward.

REA Express, Inc., lost today its 33-year-old monopoly in the air express business. The Civil Aeronautics Board issued a series of orders denying REA the right to continue as the sole operator of the airline-expedited freight business after the next two months.

Edward R. Bose, assistant executive vice president and general manager of the International Executive Service Corporation, died Thursday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. His age was 67, and he also lived at 860 Fifth Avenue here.

Donald A. Gordon, 40 years old, of Santa Barbara, Calif., will become president of Pine Manor Junior College July 1. He was principal of Abbott Academy in Andover, Mass., now merged with Phillips Andover.

Members of the House Judiciary Committee warned today, that they would be, forced to serve a second subpoena on President Nixon if he refused to comply with an April 19 request for tape recordings of 141 more White House conversations sought for the impeachment inquiry.

A mounting public campaign against far-reaching territorial concessions to Syria erupted in the Israeli Parliament today when the right-wing Opposition demanded an immediate explanation by the Government of its "plans to retreat behind the 1967 cease-fire line".
While the Milwaukee Bucks and Boston Celtics pondered strategy for tonight's fifth game of the National Basketball Association championship series,

The United Brands Company, which changed its name some years ago from the United Fruit Company, said yesterday that it had received and would buy all offered 340,000 shares of the common stock of the Foster Grant Company as a resuit of United's recent offer to buy Foster Grant shares at $34 each.

Gerald Udell, founder and president of Gerry, Inc., of Bloomfield, N J., manufacturers representatives to the beauty shop and barber business, died Sunday in Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge, N. J. He was 60 years old and lived at 539 Troy Road Parsippany, N. J. His widow, Frances, and two sons, Gary and Glenn, survive.

With more major banks raising their prime interest rates, prices on the American Stock Exchange fell again yesterday with volume dropping to its lowest point in seven months. The over-the-counter market's reaction to the moves was mixed.

The fate of Flip Sal, the horse that broke down Saturday in the 100th running of the Kentucky Derby, may not be known until Wednesday at the earliest. "His chances of being saved for stud service are still pretty poor, but it may take a couple more days before we know whether he'll have to be destroyed," said Dr. A. Gary Lavin, the horse's veterinarian.
The State Senate by the narrowest possible majority, gave final legislative approval today to the establishment of a new Cabinet level Department of the Public Advocate.

Frank W. Begrisch, a retired real estate and investment broker who was a director of the Phillips Petroleum Company from 1944 to 1968, died yesterday in United Hospital, Port Chester, N. Y. He was 72 years old and lived at 10 Sound Road in Rye. N. Y

In a new and informal experiment, homeless adolescent boys who describe themselves as homosexuals and who are unwanted by or unable to adjust to youth homes, have been placed under the foster care of adult male homosexual".

The perversion of purpose that so often characterizes so-called law-and-order legislation is nowhere more striking than in the efforts of state legislatures these days to reinstate the death penalty that was struck down by the Supreme Court in 1972.
The United Stats and the Soviet Union announced unexpectedly tonight that Secretary of State Kissinger would fly from Israel tomorrow to confer

A Mississippi Congressman said today that voters in his district were overwhelmingly opposed to the impeachment of President Nixon. Representative Thad Cochran, a Republican said 90.1 per cent of the more than 23,000 people who responded to a postal questionaire in his Fourth Congressional District indicated they were against impeachment; 88.6 per cent indicated they were against Mr. Nixon's resigning.

With a helicopter and Jim Fregosi helping both American League division leaders, the Yankees received a welcome boost from two of their numerous newcomers tonight and defeated the Texas Rangers, 6-4. Dick Tidrow, one of the new members of the realigned pitching staff, gained a victory in his first start as a Yankee, receiving ninthinning help from Sparky Lyle, who struck out all three Rangers he faced.

Richard Harris was escorted to Newark in handcuffs in keeping with, a state law that permits prisoners to attend funerals of members of their immediate family. The law includes the caveat that such "compassionate" visits can be disallowed if officals have an "overwhelming" reason for doing so.

Joanne Chesimard, the alleged Black Liberation Army leader, was extradited to New York yesterday to stand trial on charges of attempted murder, assault and unlawful possession of weapons, stemming from an unsuccessful 1973 ambush of two policemen in Queens.

Members of the House Judiciary Committee warned today that they would be forced to serve a second subpoena on President Nixon if he refused to comply with an April 19 request for tape recordings of 141 more White House conversations sought for the impeachment inquiry.

The House by a vote of 301 to 17 completed Congressional approval today of a bill authorizing $374-million for treating and preventing alcoholism. The money would be spent mostly in the next two fiscal years, with $173-million in the fiscal year 1975, $188-million in the fiscal year 1976 and $132million in the fiscal year 1977.

Commerce Seceretary Frederick Dent said today that United States payments for oil imports were now running more than $1billion a month above yearagd levels. In a, speech prepared for delivery in Milwaukee and released here, Mr. Dent noted, however: "We consider the prospects for lower petroleum prices later this year to be good Nevertheless, at the same time we anticipate significantly. larger quantities of petroleum will be imported in the months ahead."

The House by a vote of 301 to 17 completed Congressional approval today of a bill authorizing $374-million for treating and preventing alcoholism. The money would be spent mostly in the next two fiscal years, with $173-million in the fiscal year 1975, $188-million in the fiscal year 1976 and $132million in the fiscal year 1977.

Commerce Seceretary Frederick Dent said today that United States payments for oil imports were now running more than $1billion a month above yearagd levels. In a, speech prepared for delivery in Milwaukee and released here, Mr. Dent noted, however: "We consider the prospects for lower petroleum prices later this year to be good Nevertheless, at the same time we anticipate significantly. larger quantities of petroleum will be imported in the months ahead."

The first round of France's Presidential election has brought the Gaullist era to an end. More than 80 per cent of the nation voted for change-after sixteen years of Gaullism. A half-decade after General de Gaulle's departure from office, it is evident that his long years of personal rule failed to leave behind a party capable of carrying on in his name.
New Jersey today became the first state to enact a law providing public funds for the campaigns of candidates for Governor in the general election.

Nearly 500 young voices from a dozen countries conquered the acoustical problem of New York streets for a' few moments yesterday afternoon in the plaza at Lincoln Center. Their performance, two times, of that hardy college perennial, "Gaudeamus Igitur," subdued, with rousing harmony, clanking traffic,. shouting people, droning airplanes and shrieking sirens.

President Nixon backed down today from his opposition to the Watergate special proseCutor's subpoena for tapes and records of 64 White House conversations by indicating through his lawyers that he was willing to reach an "accommodation" with the prosecution.

NORTH SALEM, N. Y.--Two by two they came--the children and the animals. From toddlers to teen--agers, they led or carried their pets to spot in the spring-bright gardens of the Hammond Museum on Sunday, and there received blessing for their creatures from the assembled clergy.

Members of the House Judiciary Committee warned today that they would be forced to serve a second subpoena on President Nixon if he refused to comply with an April 19 request for tape recordings of 141 more White House conversations sought for the impeachment inquiry.

Herbert W. Kalmbach has testified about a midnight meeting at which he said a top dairy cooperative official was told that milk prices would be increased and that the White House wanted confirmation of a $2-million campaign pledge, according to informed sources.

There was a single moment n Joan Miller's "Escapades," which was given its. premiere on Sunday at the Riverside Church Theater, that epitonized the pleasures and problems of her work. Yon Martin, a member-of Miss Miller's Chamber Arts/ Dance Players, prepares for a solo. The Work up to this point has been a happy. blend of lyrical, sometimes almost wistful, solos and anecdotally funny group dance,

Lucien E. Oliver, chairman of Colonial Stores, an Atlantabased supermarket chain since his retirement in 1969 as a vice president of Sears, Roebuck Co. in charge of Southern territory, died Sunday in Atlanta. He was 68 years old.

The United States Steel Corporation disclosed today that , chairman of the Northrop Corporation, resigned Friday from the steel company's board of di-. rectors, two days after he pleaded guilty to making illegal contributions of $150,000 of Northrop funds to President Nixon's re-election campaign.

Specialists in the uncertain arts of long-term prediction and policy assessment opened a weeklong meeting here yesterday,to explore the applicability of computers, human intuition and current knowledge to. the world's most urgent problems.

To mark the 50th anniversary or the Turkish Republic, the city recently put up a statue of a nude in a prominent public square and called it "Guzel Istanbulz"--"Beautiful Istanbul." The work was termed indecent by the Deputy Premier of Turkey, Necmettin Erbakan, who said it should be removed to a less conspicuous spot.

Britain and the Soviet Union signed today a 10-year pact to develop economic, scientific, technological and industrial cooperation, Government sources said. The agreement opens the way for Britain to compete for long-term contracts in the Soviet Union and marks the end of a three-year phase of cool relations between the two nations.

The Chamber Music Society of the American Symphony Orchestra ended its sixconcert series at Carngie Recital Hall Sunday night with a curious, inconsistent program.; Curious because the society abdicated what is presumably one of its principal functions-to give orchestra members a chance to play chamber music-by turning over the, second half of the, program to the Philadelphia' Composers Forun.
Following is the status of subpoenas and requests for evidence made to the White House by the special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, the House impeachment inquiry, and the Senate Watergate committee:

Acting in the public interest, the Interstate Commerce Commission has recorded its "fundamental disagreement" with the drastic plans for abandonment of Northeast railroad trackage recommended by the Department of Transportation.

The Daily News early today ordered its printers to leave its building on 42d Street and Second Avenue in a dispute over the. use of automated type-setting processes, after publication of the paper had been delayed for sevekal hours.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said yesterday that it had formally signed a contract with Saudi Arabian Airlines for delivery of two L-1011 Tristar jetliners. Lockheed's original letter of intent with Saudi Arabian Airlines had been subject to the obtaining of suitable financing by the air carrier. The purchase price of the two Tristars is $48-million.

Cultural anthropologist finished "The Denial of Death" toward end of 1972.... Sought to show that "fear of life and fear of death are mainsprings of human activity" .... The 49-year-old author of eight books said in an interview last year in Psychology Today that, although he had been an atheist, "I think the birth of my first child, more than anything else, was the miracle that woke me up to the idea of God."

Health care.. for. women, long one of the major issues of the-women's movement, was discussed and dissected here at a day-long conference that turned out-to be more of a gripe session than anything else. Called "Psychological Perspectives in Women's Medicine: - Telling- It the Way It Feels," it was a get-together to discuss such things as unnecessary surgery, ondescension of doctors to women patients, depression as a feminist issue, and medical consumerism.

Dick Sharon, a pinch-hitter, drove in the tying run with a grounder in the seventh inning, then stole second and scored on a single by Jerry Moses to give the Detroit Tigers a 5-4 triumph over the Chicago White Sox last night at Tiger Stadium in Detroit. The setback ended Chicago's five-game winning streak.

Rising interest rates bogged down the stock market again yesterday in the slowest trading in more than eight months. In mid-March the prime rate was 8 3/4 percent.

The CBS television magazine, "60 Minutes," will become a prime-time series during the summer months, running Sundays from 9:30 to 10:30 P.M. The move will take place July 7, and the weekly news series will continue at that time through Sept. 1.

District Attorney John T. D'Arcy of Allegany County was indicted today on 85 counts including unlawful imprisonment and official misconduct.

The police arrested three men today charged in connection with the theft of five carcasses of beef one hour before the theft was reported. The beef is worth an estimated total of S65,000.
A special subcommitteee of the House Agriculture Committee recommended today minimum and maximum quotas for domestic sugar producers in a proposed five-year extension of the United States sugar law.

State Attorney General Robert Morgan led two other major candidates by a substantial margin in a slow count of yesterday's Democratic primary for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Sam J. Ervin Jr. However, incomplete returns left in doubt whether he could win the simple majority required to avoid a runoff primary.

It would be easy for New Yorkers to forget that Pierre Boulez has been a composer first and a conductor second. The White House said today that it was "at a loss" to explain an apparent discrepancy in the transcript of one of the. recorded conversations turned over last week to the House Judiciary Committee, which is studying the possible impeachment of President Nixon.

Artillery went into action again on the northern sector of the Israeli-held bulge inside Syria this morning, as Secretary of State Kissinger left Israel for talks in Cyprus with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko.

Louis I. Kahn, who at his death last March 17 was considered by most architectural scholars to be America's foremost architect of his time, died several hundred thousands dollars in debt, according to spokesmen for his estate. ANKARA, Turkey-American diplomats here are worried that the Turkish decision to resume cultivation of opium poppies may seriously impair relations between the United States and Turkey, allies in NATO.

Prime Minister Harold Wilson emphasized today the Labor Government's disapproval of the British national rugby team's tour of South Africa and Rhodesia. But in a message to the Supreme Council for Sports in Africa he said the Government had no powers to prevent the team, the Lions, which left last night from taking part in the tour.
Dick Siderowf of Westport, Conn., and Marty West of Bethesda, Md., both Walker Cup players, were among the favorites who survived today's second round of the North-South amateur golf tournament.

The question of whether a portion of a National Historic District will be rezoned to permit strip mining was left hanging today in this rural central Virginia county when Dr. Daniel Griffith, the official county tiebreaker, disqualified himself.

The $100,000 World Championship Tennis singles finals begin tomorrow night with an innovation - electrical line judges. A sensitive netting resembling aluminum foil will be placed under the playing surface around the outsides of the serving courts.

Bus drivers and mechanics in the District of Columbia, northern Virginia and parts of suburban Maryland returned tp work today after United States District Judge John Lewis Smith ordered both sides in the fiveday walkout to submit issues to arbitration.

A 12-week experimental program to improve conditions in the streets of the garment center got under way yesterday, spearheaded by 18 former offenders and former addicts who have undergone an intensive training program.

From simple batter breads to sourdoughs and egg breads, the homemade loaf has been surging back into its own lately. The emphasis has been on variety and taste.

Secretary of State Kissinger received guarded Soviet support in Cyprus this afternoon for his efforts to achieve a troop-separation agreement between Israel and Syria. He then returned to Jerusalem and was given new Israeli proposals for a troop separation on the Golan Heights.

Federal Judge Charles E Stewart Jr. yesterday rejected a city proposal to increase the number of polling places in the forthcoming District I school board election, paving the way for a new showdown next Tuesday between supporters and critics of Superintendent Luis Fuentes.

" I asked him for his friendship and he refused," Helmut Schmidt said last year of Willy Brandt, recalling an encounter more than 15 years ago at a Social Democratic party convention.
Connecticut's Gaming Commission today gave its approval to the Old Rock Road Corporation of Bridgeport to build a race track in Wolcott, a community on the edge of Waterbury.

The Philadelphia Orchestra concluded its strike-delayed season at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening with a performance that was full of oldfashioned symphonic virtues. An RCA Victor ad in the program proclaims this the world's richest- sounding orchestra," and even in the scrawny acoustical 'ambiance of Fisher Hall, the 'orchestra came close to making good that absolutist boast..

In a national atmosphere of shock over the unexpected resignation of Chancellor Willy Brandt Monday night, the governing Social Democratic party of West Germany named Finance Minister Helmut Schmidt to succeed him. Mr. Brandt's decision appeared to be final, but for the time being, he said, he will not resign as head of the party.
Representative William Green of Pennsylvania, backed by 125 other House Democrats, began an effort today to force a House vote on ending at once, rather than phasing out, the oil depletion allowance.

The state's Chief Medical Examiner, in a reversal of his position, today strongly supported legislation that would allow a trained and certified specialist to practice acupuncture in New Jersey under the supervision of a licensed physician. Willy Brandt, left, after his resignation as Chancellor of West Germany was accepted, with Finance Minister Helmut Schmidt, his designated successor, in Bonn.

Several major producers announced yesterday that they had raised the prices for cadmium, a plating metal that is also used in large quantities in pigments, alloys and chemicals.

Thanks to one lucky bounce followed by one unlikely shot, the New York Nets will have a clean shot at basketball history tomorrow night. No team has ever won a major league championship by going through the playoffs with fewer than two defeats. Brian Taylor

All three members of the Pulitzer Prize jury on fiction expressed distress and- bewilderment yesterday that their unanimous recommendation for a prize for Thomas Pynchon's "Gravity's Rainbow" had been turned down and that no fiction award was given this year.
The Rev. George J. Nasis, who retired five years ago as pastor of the Greek Orthodox Church of the Annunciation, 302 West 91st Street, died Sunday at his home in Dover, N.J. His age was 86.
The Right Rev. Samuel J. Wylie, Episcopal Bishop of Northern Michigan and former dean of the General Theological Seminary here, died yesterday in his sleep at the seminary. Bishop Samuel J. Wylie
The Albany plan to tax off-track betting wagers at the Window-a dime on the standard $2 bet, for instance-was criticized yesterday by Mayor Beame.
The White House has sent an urgent request to all Cabinet-level departments seeking new ideas to be utilized "in the next 1,000 days."

A State Supreme Court justice, the Attorney General of New Jersey and the commander of the state police are expected to be called as witnesses for the defense in a police bribery trial that opened in Superior Court here today.
The House Ways and Means Committee decided tentatively today to require political parties and campaign committees to pay income taxes for the first time.
Francis J. O'Malley, a University of Notre Dame English professor who had to screen applicants because his classes were so popular, died today at St. Joseph Hospital here. He was 62 years old.

An examination of transcripts has disclosed a conflict in versions of how closely a Federal judge and a Watergate prosecutor may have worked together-if at all-in the early days of the Watergate investigation.
Five Tunisians found guilty last night of spying for the Soviet Union received sentences ranging from three years to 10 years hard labor.
The stock market ended mixed yesterday in dull trading as high interest rates and the growing inflationary spiral continued to keep many investors on the sidelines.
Shortages and inflation continue unabated, according to E. F. Andrews, chairman of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Management.

More than 50,000 children who entered New York City's elementary schools in the last school year have not yet been given the physical examinations required under the city's Health Code, according to a survey by the Citizens' Committee for Children of New York.
A Federal grand jury indicted four bankingexecutivesyesterday on 42 felony counts in connection with an alleged $2million manipulation of bank funds in Southern California and Alabama.

" All the Arts for All the Children," a public-school pilot program viewed partly as an antidate to the educationall deprivation" that could result from an overemphasis on reading scores, was announced jointly yesterday by the Board of Education and the JDR 3d Fund, John D Rockefeller 3d and Dr. Edythe J. Gaines, who will administer the Board of Education's new arts program, at news conference yesterday. At left is Chancellor Irving Anker.
Some Communist participation in, the provisional government now being formed is virtually certain, according to political sources close to the negotiations proceeding here for 10 days.
The wife and son of James R. Hoffa, former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, have been dismissed from their jobs with the union, union sources said today.

Victor Starzenski, retired vice president and general manager of the Hudson Valley Fuel Corporation, Troy, N. Y., a former subsidiary of the Niagara Mohawk Corporation, died Saturday at his home in Galway, Ireland. He was 87 years old.
The Legislature late today approved a 1-cent-on-the-dollar increase in the New York City sales tax--the keystone of the-city's fiscal package of 10 bills.

For tonight's presentation on the public television "Theater in America" series, WNET/13 and Jac Venza, executive producer, have tapped New Haven's Long Whart Theater for its fine production of D. H. Lawrence's "The Widowing of Mrs. Holroyd.
The most severe inequities in the new rent control law originally recommended by Governor Wilson would be remedied under the revised rules he is reportedly proposing to the State Legislature.

Louis Harris, the poll-taker, says a nationwide survey indicates that President Nixon's ability to inspire confidence in the White House fell to a new low of 13 per cent among Americans last month.
A combination of political and personal considerations led Willy Brandt to resign as West German Chancellor yesterday.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell sharply again yesterday with a broad decline in Canadian petroleum and mining stocks adding to the pressure of high prime interest rates in this country. In the over-the-counter market, prices also fell compared with the day before.

William C. Sullivan, the former assistant deputy director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation mentioned in the White House tape transcripts, has termed John W. Dean 3d a "liar" and a "double-crosser."

Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Republican leader in the Senate, said today that the transcripts of White House conversations on Watergate portrayed "deplorable, disgusting, shabby, immoral performances" Senator Hugh Scott after he discussed the tapes.

A negotiating session was scheduled for 'tomorrow between the management of Washington's two daily newspapers and union printers, who have been accused of staging slowdowns and disrupting production and delivery schedules.

Governor Wilson has agreed to revise drastically his week-old rent proposals, eliminating nearly all the provisions to which tenant groups had objected. The Governor's office would say only that "a bipartisan bill is now being drafted."

A National Institute for the Humanities, with a focus on the cultural and intellectual life of the United States, is to be established this year at Yale University through a $2.7-million grant from the Federal Government's National Endowment for the Humanities.
Joyce Ebert and Frank Converse in "The Widowing of Mrs. Holroyd," Ch. 13 at 8:30 P.M.

PARIS-It is not yet clear who won the French elections begun May 5 and scheduled to end May 19 but it is obvious who lost them. That man was the late Charles de Gaulle. If nothing else the quest for a new President touched off by Georges Pompidou's death proved that Gaullism could not long endure without its namesake and inventor.

The average rate on the Treasury Department's $1.75billion of notes, dated and bearing interest from May 15, 1974, was 8.73 per cent, in today's auction. The Treasury reported receipt of a total of $3.5-billion in tenders for the 4 1/4-year, 8 3/4 per cent coupon notes.

The Board of Public Utility Commissioners ordered an electric company to make $1-million in refunds and rate reductions to its 46,000 customers because of overcharging and collecting of excess profits. The order against Rockland Electric Company was the first time in five years a power company in the United States had been ordered to reduce its rates, a P.U.C. spokesman said. Rockland serves customers in Bergen.. Passaic and Sussex Counties.

St. Clair, White House special counsel, disclosing a hardened stand against turning over more Watergate tapes: Mr. St. Clair: I think in fairness I should make an announcement to you. James D. St. Clair, President Nixon's lawyer, talking to reporters in the office of Ken W. Clawson, White House communications director, in the Executive Office Building.

Former President Johnson once declared that dairymen had promised him a $250,000 campaign contribution but did not deliver, according to a statement attributed to the leader of the nation's biggest dairy cooperative.

" We really dug deep into ourselves tonight, we really pushed," said John Havlicek, the captain and heart of the Boston Celtics, who drew to within one victory of the National Basketball Association championship with a 96-87 triumph over the Bucks tonight at Milwaukee Arena. Don Chaney of the Celtics dribbling past Bucks' Mickey Davis after Davis took a fall on court during N.B.A. playoff game in Milwaukee. Boston's Jo Jo White looks on.

The United States Consumer Products Safety Commission served notice today that it intended to ban use of vinyl chloride in most household aerosol sprays because the chemical is considered a potential health hazard.
