A maintenance supervisor and seven other employes of the Hempstead Town Highway Department were among nine persons named yesterday in criminal informations charging the theft of gasoline, from a Highway Department yard in Bellmore.

Stockholders of the Squibb Corporation at yesterday's annual meeting in Princeton, N.J., approved a two-for-one common stock split, paving the way city' for an increase of the authorized stock to 60 million from 30 million shares.

Wilbur Wood, Chicago's 32year-old left-handed knuckleballer, who has led the American League in innings pitched and in victories for the last two seasons, proved his stamina again last night by pitching an 11-inning 1-0 triumph over the Tigers in Detroit.

The White House said today that it was "at a loss" to explain an apparent discrepancy in the transcript of one of the. recorded conversations turned over last week to the House Judiciary Committee, which is studying the possible impeachment of President Nixon.

Vice President Ford was given five standing ovations by 1,000 members of the Grand Lodge of Masons in New York State as he called here last night for support of the Nixon Administration's defense spending program.
The House of Representatives blocked and probably killed today a bill that would have allowed voters to register by postcard for Federal elections.
The House has voted to suspend the duty on zinc-bearing ores until mid-1977 to end a competitive disadvantage of United States smelters in buying zinc ores on the world market.

Complaining of looting, red tape and legal snags, about 30 small-business executives from companies at the site of last month's East Side gas explosion met yesterday to look for ways to get back on their feet.

The staff of the Senate Watergate committee has recommended that Congress create a permanent public attorney's office to investigate and prosecute alleged wrongdoing within the executive branch of the Government.

A continuing controversy over lead-based paint has all but eliminated mortgage assistance for low-income families in this city and seriously jeopardized similar home loan plans in urban areas all across the country.

Robert L. Vesco, the international financier who has been a fugitive since he was indicted a year ago along with two former Cabinet officers, John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans, was cited yesterday in a $60million complaint filed in the Federal District Court here.
The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that there was "absolutely no substance" to reports that it might aid the Citron Motor Company in its present troubles.

Residents or Purchase, a once exclusive residential hamlet in this Westchester town, are seeking to "secede" from Harrison by incorporating as a village. The. aim is to slow or stop further commercial development in Purchase. This is the third attempt at "secession" in two decades. The last bid, in 1967, lost by two votes in an election within the Purchase community. This time, those favoring incorporation are Seeking broader support and expert advice.

A simple, low Russian church, tucked away on a side street in northeast Moscow, has in recent weeks become the focus of an unusual pilgrimage of young and old; attracted by the outspoken opinions of one of its priests, the Rev. Dmitri Dudko.

FREEPORT, Minn. - I am a poor little rich boy, I didn't grow up in the slums of Chicago or the ghetto of New York. I was a poor boy without even knowing that I was poor. I grew up on the west side of St; Paul, Minn., not too far from the home of F. Scott Fitzgerald and across the Mississippi from the mansion of James J. Hill, the financier and railway promoter.
The Bates Manutacturing Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it had submitted a new offer to the Martin Foundation, Inc., for Bates stock owned by the foundation.

The Boys' Clubs of America presented their Herbert Hoover Memorial Award yesterday to Albert L. Cole, chairman of the organization's board and former general manager and vice president of Reader's Digest, in an awards dinner at the New York Hilton Hotel attended by 1,500 people.

John McLaughlin, the Jesuit priest who is a special assistant to President Nixon, held an extraordinary news conference today to deny charges by Hugh Scott, the Senate minority leader, and other Republicans that, as Mr. Scott put it, the Watergate transcripts portrayed "deplorable, disgusting, shabby, immoral performances" by the President and his aides.
Many of the nation's leading stockbrokers and investment bankers, assembled here for three days with their wives and golf clubs, heard another grim report on their industry today.
Two gunmen shot and killed a Roman Catholic who answered a knock at his door outside Belfast late tonight, then fled in two automobiles.

Nobody apparently convinced anyone of anything after the first game of tile Stanler Cup final series last night, in which the Boston Bruins won, 3-2, from the Philadelphia Flyers on Bobby, Orr's goal in the last seconds of play.
Investors moved out enthusiastically yesterday to buy the Treasury's new 81/2 per cent bonds and 83/4 per cent notes - the highest interest rates for such securities in the country's history.

day, May 9--Premier Olafur Johannesson announced early today that Iceland's Parliament would be dissolved and new elections held June 30 as a result of the splitting of his coalition Cabinet over how to fight inflation.

Dean Burch, counselor to President Nixon, overreached himself two weeks ago in a speech to the Republican National Committee, a speech that he said he had cleared with the President. Mr. Burch, now the chief political guru on the White House staff, told his fellow Republican leaders that they had to sink or swim with Mr. Nixon because his roles as President and as party leader are "indistinguishable."
In effort to assure more reporting of crimes, District Attorney Richard H. Kuh announced last night that he had assigned an assistant district attorney to each of Manhattan's 21 police precincts.
The San Francisco Giants, victimized by robbers Tuesday night while winning a double-header from the New York Mets, were hit again by thieves prior to last night's game.

A tall, ruddy-faced man, Father McLaughlin was named to the White House staff in 1971 after attracting national attention in 1970, when he ran unsuccessfully on the Republican ticket in trying to unseat Senator John O. Pastore, Rhode Island Democrat. Senator Pastore won by a 2-to-1 martin.
A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted State Senator Leroy R. Johnson, one of the South's most powerful black politicians on four counts of evading $44,339.92 in Federal income taxes.

Willy Brandt who resigned as Chancellor of West Germany Monday night following the discovery of an East German spy on his staff, said in a televised speech tonight that he had quit, in part, because "there were indications my private life would be drawn into speculation about the case."

President Nixon will face a series of subpoenas for tape recordings and other documents on specific subjects if he continues to withhold evidence from the House impeachment inquiry, according to a plan the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee outlined privately to other Democrats this morning.
The Federal Energy Administration challenged Gulf Oil to justify $46.5-million of costs claimed for crude oil it bought from two foreign affiliates. Details on Page 65.

Hobart Rowen, assistant managing editor-financial of The Washington Post, was reelected today as president of the Society of American Business Writers at their annual meeting. Also re-elected were Don Campbell, financial editor of The Daily News, New York, as vice president and Myron Kandel of' the Wall Street Leter, New York as treasurer.
William J. Tumblazer, the key prosecution witness in the murder trial of W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers of America, was sentenced today to 15 years in a Federal prison.

Senate and House conferees reached agreement tonight on a compromise bill to take legal services for the poor out of the crumbling Office of Economic Opportunity and create a new public corporation to handle the program.

Howard M. Pack, president of Seatrain Lines, Inc., which operates a shipbuilding enterprise in the former Navy Yard here, expressed surprise yesterday at being the target of a new investigation by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office.

The Soviet Union today asserted its right to send ships into the Indian Ocean and accused China' of purposely misrepresenting the Soviet naval presence in an effort to whip up anti-Soviet sentiment in the region.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation announced yester day that it had notified the Environmental Protection Agency of the company's intention to file a citizen's suit to force the agency to live up to the rules of the Clean Air Act of 1970.
Fire has destroyed a former motion pitcure studio at the eastern edge of Thousand Oaks. Ventura County arson investigators said that the fire last night appeared to have been deliberately set.

It's a pity that nothing short of fiscal disaster or the stray centenary celebration drives modern-dance companies together for cooperative programs. They are really very pleasant, as was Tuesday evening's retrospective at the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, which is celebrating its first 100 years.

The Senate Judiciary Committee voted unanimously today in executive session to begin fullscale hearings into the Justice Department's failure to unravel the Watergate cover-up in the summer and fall of 1972, Senate sources said.
Mott the Hoople arrived on Broadway Tuesday night for the first of six shows, the first hard rock group ever to appear there, and the Uris Theater will probably never be the same again.

Henry L. Diamond, former State Environmental Conservation Commissioner, was named yesterday by Governor Wilson to the state's Environmental Board. Mr. Diamond resigned last December to become executive director of former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's Commission on Critical Choices for Americans. Members of the part-time board, which has limited power to promulgate environmental rules, are paid $100 a day, up to a maximum of $5.000 a year.
A 15-year-old Brooklyn youth who telephoned the police Tuesday night to report the stabbing murder of his mother and brother was charged yesterday with the homicides.
The nation's farmers are expected to harvest a record 1.6 billion bushels of winter wheat this year, up 27 per cent from the former record, set in 1973, the Agriculture Department estimated today.

After Secretary of State Kissinger completed more than five hours of talks with President Hafez al-Assad today, official sources said that a meeting of Arab chiefs of state might be necessary at an early date.

A rederal grana jury indicted eight area residents yesterday on charges of defrauding two insurance concerns of $15,000 in a scheme that involved nonexistent new autos.

JERUSALEM, May 8-Secretary of State Kissinger said that he had made "some progress" in his peacemaking efforts today, as he shuttled between Israel and Syria to convey each side's revised proposals for separating their troops on the Golan Heights.

John H. Glenn Jr., who defeated Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum by nearly 100,000 votes in yesterday's Democratic Senatorial primary, spent the long months of his campaign deploring the moral climate that fostered the Watergate scandals and President Nixon's tax woes and calling for a return to integrity in government.
Gov. george C. Wallace apparently picked up as much as 25 per cent of the black vote in Alabama yesterday.

The State Department of Health announced today that a restaurant on the New Jersey Turnpike had closed voluntarily after failing a state sanitation inspection. A department spokesman said the restaurant at the Molly Pitcher Plaza rest stop in Cranbury is operated by the Marriott Corporation.
The State Supreme Court upheld today the constitutionality of a Newark ordinance that, with certain exceptions, requires city employes to live in the city.
The Agriculture Deapartment said today that consumers would probably see only slight price increases for food during the rest of this year and might see a small decline late in the year.

A nationwide strike by one of Britain's largest trade unions was settled today when a lawyer appeared in court and paid $156,000 on behalf of an anonymous donor to cover fines and damages levied against the labor organization.

Elinor Guggenheimer, the Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, said yesterday that Irving Goldman, the Commissioner of Cultural Affairs and 'a major fund-raiser in Mayor Became's election campaign, had asked her to "go easy on" a Became campaign contributor whose company was under investigation for alleged consumer fraud.

The Ford Motor Company announced today price increases averaging $163 on its 1974 cars and trucks "to offset in part unprecedented cost increases." The rises amount to $113, or 2.4 per cent, in the sticker price, and $50, or 1.1 per cent, for options that have become standard equip. ment.

The president of City College, Robert E. Marshak, and his dean of the Faculty of Liberal Arts were in dispute yesterday over. charges that the college's accelerated medicaltraining program used racial quotas to fill Its classes.

HAMILL, S. D.-The calves had to be pulled" this yearliterally winched out of their mother's womb. Maybe it was the mild winter or the cross-breeding with European "exotics," but the calves were born bigger.
The Connecitcut General Assembly heard some words of faint, unaccustomed praise tonight from Gov. Thomas J. Meskill when it met in joint session to adjourn after a three-month session.
The architect John M. Dickey has submitted to New Jersey officials plans for a $553,000 project to develop Princeton's Revolutionary War battlefield for the country's 1976 bicentennial.
Mike John G. equaled the track record of 1:08 3-5 for six furlongs in winning the 81st running of the $27,625 Toboggan Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

LUCKY LAKE, Saskatchewan - Like small towns everywhere, this one sustains itself with endless discussion of any tiny irregularity that appears: How did the broken Coke bottle get scattered all over Florence Ashdown's sidewalk this morning?

In what is termed by the union "a withholding of services" rather than a strike, the American Federation of Musicians has stopped work at the three television networks and at a number of independent production companies.

The Republic Steel Corporation expects 1974 to be a good year if the Reserve Mining Company's taconite plant at Silver Bay, Minn., is allowed to operate, William J. De Lancey, president, told about 50 stockholders at the annual meeting here today.

Between Egyptian President Sadat's unabashed predictions of "miracles" and the fears of some Israelis that the slightest concessions would mark the beginning of the end, Secretary of State Kissinger is today a man on the spot. The stakes are so high that no party to the complex diplomacy now under way can lightly contemplate the possibility of breakdown in the Indirect talks between Israel and Syria.

In a unanimous decision, a Federal Court of Appeals ordered yesterday an immediate reopening of hearings on the Consolidated Edison Company's controversial Storm King power plant on the ground that the danger of killing the Hudson River's fish life had not been adequately considered.

Following in unofficial translation is the text of Willy Brandt's television address to West Germans tonight: Having reported to the board of my party, I speak to you for the first time free of the duties of Government office.

To the Editor: The net profit of petroleum companies cannot be correctly stated in the simple terms as presented by the oil companies and in your newspaper. The actual net profits are considerably higher than publicly announced.
Six states with 100 seats in the House of Represehtatives have now held Democratic and Republican primaries without a single upset of an incumbent Representative.
The Queens-bound roadway of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway from Fulton Street to Sands Street, Brooklyn, will be closed to traffic from 9 P.M. today to 5 A.M. tomorrow.
John W. Dean 3d has purchased a canyon home near the exclusive Trousedale Estates section of Los Angeles for a reported price of $100.000.

For many holders of bank checking accounts, getting their own checks cashed at their own banks or other branches of the banks can be frustrating. Cashing a check written by someone else can be a virtual impossibility for the average checking account holder.

, a member of the 1972 United States Olympic soccer team, has finally unglued himself from the New York Cosmos' bench and will become. the team's regular starting goalie beginning Sunday against the Miami Toros.
Following are the results of yesterday's local school elections in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties. Further school elections will be held in these counties over the next six weeks.
The minority Liberal party Govern'ment of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau was toppled today when it lost a confidence vote in the House of Commons over its budget policies.

Education officials here said today they would make "every effort" to resume the normal class schedule on Monday at this affluent commuter town's high school, which has been closed most of the week because of fighting between black and white students.

The "In Concert" seriess, which is presented every other Friday on ABC-TV, begins the first of four programs entitled "California Jam" tomorrow night at 11:30. The programs represent still another maneuver in a relatively contained but fierce battle for the rock-music audience on television.

DALLAS, May 8-Rod Laver, whose steely nerves and penchant for the big shot had carried him to the top of professional tennis, again failed in his quest for the World Championship'of Tennis title tonight.
Governor Wilson tonight sent to the Legislature a new rent bill, replacing one he had introduced last week and incorporating many suggestions of tenant groups.
Large corporations are going to have an increasingly difficult time getting outsiders to serve on their boards, according to a number of prominent businessmen who met here this week.
Like Lisbon, this capital of Portuguese Mozambique has been humming with political talk since the coup that ended nearly a half century of political silence.

With a sparkling performance that gave Manager Yogi Berra just cause to feel there's no pitcher like a southpaw, lanky Jon Matlack led the New York Mets to an easy 4-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants last night at Shea Stadium.
Japan today asked the United States to discontinue operations of the Voice of America in Okinawa as soon as possible, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

A national railway strike brought major passenger and freight disruptions to India today. But Government officials were exultant that on its first day the walkout had not effectively crippled the transport system.
Without ever clearly informing Congress, the Defense Department has been building a $1billion stockpile of weapons and military equipment to turn over to Asian allies in event of war.

Editions of The Kansas City Star with reduced amounts of news and display advertisement and no classified ads were printed again today by supervisory personnel and other employes in the absence of pressmen.

Mrs. Pauline Shapiro, wife of Harold Roland Shapiro, retired senior assistant district attorney of New York County, died Tuesday at the Albert Einstein Hospital, the Bronx. She was 67 years old and she lived at 168-01 12th Avenue, Whitestone, Queens.
A sharp decline in the price of Combustion Engineering highlighted activities on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as the market finished mixed in lethargic trading.

Preston L. Sutphen, who retired in 1948 as a vice president of the Electric Boat Company, which later became a division of the General Dynamics Corporation, died yesterday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old and also lived in East Hampton, L. I.

Three days before Italians vote on whether to repeal Italy's three-year-old divorce law, Pope Paul VI yesterday pointedly gave a group of newlyweds his special benediction, adjuring them to be "faithful to the mission that the Lord confides in the family." Along with the Vatican, the dominant Christian Democrat party and the neo-fascist Italian Social Movement support repeal of the divorce law, but the church has been particularly active in the campaign for repeal.

The younger set took over the North and South amateur golf tournament today and after the third and fourth rounds, the eight survivors ranged in age from 19-year-old Glen (Skeeter) Heath of Hampton, Va., to 36-year-old Dick Siderowf, the British Amateur champion from Westport. Conn.

CBS News said last night that the special Watergate prosecutor's staff believed one reason President Nixon bugged his offices and telephones was to create future income taxdeductible gifts, The Associated Press reported.

Egypt's highest court of appeals, in the first judgment-of its kind, has ruled that confiscation of private citizens' property during the period of power by the late President Gamal Abdel Nasser was illegal and must be rescinded.

President Nixon will face a series of subpoenas for tape recordings and other documents on specific subjects if he continues to withhold evidence from the House impeachment inquiry, according to a plan the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee outlined privately to other Democrats this morning.

John W. McGrath, a long-time campaign aide to former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, has been named director of the Republican State Committee's designating convention to be held June 11 and 12 in the Nassau Coliseum. Richard Rosenbaum, the G.O.P. State chairman, announced Mr. McGrath's selection today.

The body of an 11-year-old boy, who had been missing since Saturday form the Margaret Chapman School for the retarded was found yesterday in a covered septic tank on the school grounds in Hawthorne, Westchester County.

In a unanimous decision, a Federal Court of Appeals ordered yesterday an immediate reopening of hearings on the Consolidated Edison Company's controversial Storm King power plant on the ground that the danger of killing the Hudson River's fish life had not been adequately considered.

Though inflationary pressures have made for a substantial increase in its building costs, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority maintains it will be able to finish its proposed Meadowlands football stadium and race track without further financing.

The carnival music of boyhood once seemed to be tinkling wherever Willie Mays went. But now soft violins accompany him. In his new role with the New York Mets he's almost invisible. He's listed as a coach but he's really an instructor and an ambassador. Tonight he will represent the Mets at a dinner for The Lighthouse and tomorrow he will go to Chicago, where the Mets open a weekend series.

Officials and shareholders of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation who gathered here today for the controversial conglomerate's annual meeting were greeted by more than 500 shouting pickets and protesters chanting that "I.T.T. must go."
Tom Kole, president of REA Express, Inc., issued a statement late yesterday in which he denied that he had "ever used corporate funds for personal investment purposes."
The City Council sent Mayor Richard J. Daley a get-well card today and sweetened it with a $25,000-a-year raise. Mr. Daley has been in Rush-Presbyterian-
Louise Brandwen, who founded Stage Studio, an acting school in Washington, in the early nineteen-sixties, died of cancer Saturday in George Washington Hospital. She was 52 vears old.

Pan American World Airways, concerned over two crashes this year in which 204 persons were killed, ordered for its entire 140-plane fleet yesterday a new cockpit warning system designed to prevent such disasters.

A continuing controversy over lead-based paint has all but eliminated mortgage assistance for low-income families in this city and seriously jeopardized similar home loan plans in urban areas all across the country.
Westchester County proposed today to assume the entire responsibility for processing and disposing of the 900,000 tons of garbage discarded in the county every year.

The first ships are leaving port this week as part of a great mobilization of research vessels, aircraft, satellites, men and equipment for what Government officials call "thelargest and most complex international scientific experiment ever undertaken."

Hal Corizzi, the only basketball coach in Ramapo Regional High School's existence, has coached his final season. Corizzi, coach for 18 years at the Bergen County school, with a won-lost record of 243-103, is retiring as the Raiders' head coach, but is remaining at the school as a teacher.
"A nonGovernor," said Representative Ogden R. Reid, "Failure across the board," said Representative Hugh L. Carey. "Should be demoted," said Howard J. Samuels.

Bill Lee, a left-handed pitcher who eats up the Yankees like Sesame Street's Cookie Monster gobbles cookies, began correcting tonight some of the injustice he had talked about shortly before Boston defeated the Yankees. 4-0.

Joseph Wheeler, owner of the Virginia Ambassadors of the World Football League, said today if he could not get more investors for the franchise by Friday he would have to sell the club. Wheeler said a group in Orlando, Fla., had expressed interest in buying the franchise after meeting with him last night.
The Senate Commerce Committee approved today a bill calling for a two-and-ahalf-year Federal study of the effects of foreign direct and portfolio investment in they United States.

The Justice Department announced today that a Federal Grand jury in Baton Rouge, La., would begin hearing testimony May 20 concerning the deaths of two Southern University students in campus disorders in 1972.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged in United States District Court here that Commonwealth Chemical Securities, Inc., and itM principals had defrauded the public and three mutual funds of $600,000 in the last three and a half years.

Cook-Treadwell Harry, Inc. a 65-year-old Memphis insurance agency and underwriter, requested yesterday suspension of trading of its common stock on the over-the-counter market afterlearning of "material misstatements" of results of its operations in 1972.
The Food and Drug Administration said today that 24,000 cans of oysters were being, taken off the market in four Southern states because they could cause botulism, a deadly form of food poisoning.
The State Court of Appeals today ruled that the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and the Explorers Club must pay real-estate taxes to New York City.
The Sun Oil Company said yesterday that it had increased prices by 2 cents a gallon. on kerosene, No. I and No. 2 distillate fuel and diesel fuel to all classes of customers.
The director of the Cost of Living Council said yesterday that he expected the rate of inflation to decline in the second and third quarters before rising again in the last three months of 1974.
The Combustion Engineering stock market debacle yesterday demonstrated once again that many institutional investors act on the herd instinct rather than on dispassionate analysis of a stock's worth.
A high aide to Secretary of State Kissinger resigned today over what his associates said was iis despair over the way Mr. Kissinger was running the state Department and dealing with the Pentagon.

Weather:. Rain likely today; cool tonight. Fair and cool tomorrow. Temp. range: today 46-58; Wed. 43-65. Additional details on Page 860.
The distinction of sweeping a final-round series for the American Basketball Association championship eluded the New York Nets tonight, ,as they lost a hardfought 97-89 decision to the Utah Stars.

A top White House aide charged tonight that "repulsive tactics" were being used by those "who wished to drive the President from office." The comment by Ronald L. Ziegler, the President's press secretary, was prompted by a Gannett News Service report earlier in the day.

Former Chief Justice Earl Warren observed the other day that the parade of attorneys accused of Watergaterelated crimes has weakened confidence in the legal profession. Starting at the top, the President faces possible impeachment and the former Vice President has been disbarred in Maryland.

The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended yesterday trading in the securities of American Export Industries, Inc., and American Export Lines, Inc., formerly known as American Export Isbrandtsen Lines, Inc., until May 17.

It's been a long time since Jim Lonberg won the Cy Young Award with Boston in 1967 with a 22-9 won-lost record while leading the American League in strikeouts with 246. And it's also been a long time between shutouts.

Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes of the State Supreme Court says law-enforcement officials in New Jersey were authorized to wiretap telephones, and conduct electronic surveillance in 227 cases in 1973. He disclosed the figure in a report to Governor Byrne and the Legislature. The authorizations, Mr. Hughes said, came under the state Wiretapping and Electronic Surveillance Control Act of 1969.
The rate of interest soared to new heights at the Manhattan Savings Bank last week. The interest, however, was canine and. not monetary, for the bank was staging its 14th

The Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, put aside in middebate tonight a bill for the take-over of two Consolidated Edison Company power plants, charging that the State Democratic Chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, had ordered all Democratic Senators not to support the measure.

"Locked Out by The Daily News," read the signs on the picket line yesterday. All except one. That one, worn by a young, mustached printer named Albert Altabet, proclaimed in neat gothic letters, "Computers Can't Picket."

The soviet Ambassador has called on Valery Giscard d'Estaing, the conservative presidential candidate, resulting in an assertion by some right-wing comment. tors that Moscow was interfere. ing in France's internal affairs,

Clarence Farrell, who pleaded guilty to robbing a Bronx subway change booth, was sentenced yesterday to a sevenyear prison term. Mr. Farrell was arrested, last Oct. 24 at a Manhattan train station after he jumped over a turnstile to avoid paying the fare.
Mrs. Eunice Spellman Holsaert, editor of children's books at Holiday House, died of cancer Monday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 64 years old and lived at 410 Central Park West.

The three major television networks said yesterday that they would present live coverage today of the opening statements as the House Judiciary Committee begins its hearings into the possible Impeachment of President Nixon.

Willy Brandt, who resigned as Chancellor of West Germany Monday night following the discovery of an East German spy on his staff, said in a televised speech tonight that he had quit, in. part, because "there were indications my private life would be drawn into speculation about the case."

DeRoss Salisbury, a designer of pipe organs who has been associated since 1946 with the Schantz Pipe Organ Company, died Tuesday in Bellevue Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 124 Ancon Avenue in Pelham, N.Y.

Water Clay Lowdermilk, an international authority on forest, land and water conservation, died Monday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 86 years old. Mr. Lowdermilk was a scientist and at the same time a rugged pioneer with ideals to match his stamina.
The same 100-watt General Electric light bulbs that until recently were selling for as much as $1.48 for a package of four can now be found for as little as 69 cents at Times Square Stores.
The capture of Symbionese Liberation Army members may have been foiled by a published report that the terrorists were plotting to kidnap Mayor Joseph Alioto's grandchildren, police said today.

Prices continued to fall or the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter-market yesterday as investors remained cautious about possibilities of improvement In the economy in this country and showed fears of Canadian tax increases.

Bishop William J. Walls, "elder statesman" of the African, Methodist Episcopal Zion Church (A.M.E. Zion), who began his preaching career at the age of 14, celebrated his 89th birthday yesterday with some advice to his fellow Christians.

Despite a continuing decline in trading volume, the American Stock Exchange had a net income of $87,000 in the first quarter of this year, compared with a $107,000 loss in the similar period of 1973, Paul Kolton, chairman, reported yesterday.

The latest McGraw-Hill capital spending survey finds that American corporations are planning a huge increase in their outlays on new plant and equipment this yeara jump of nearly 20 per cent to a total of $119 billion. But within that total there are enormous disparities. The petroleum industry, With profits soaring as a result of the great run-up in oil prices, will increase its outlays by 52 per cent to $8.3 billion.

Two Broadway performers were chosen yesterday as winners of the 30th annual Clarence Derwent awards for the actor and actress who gave the best supporting performances. Ann Reinking won for her portrayal of Maggie in "Over
NBC-TV disclosed yesterday that it would move its two principal news programs, the "Nightly News" and the "Today" show, to Washington on May 20 until further notice.
The Federal Energy Administration announced today a 10.4 per cent increase in daily gasoline supplies for May, virtually eliminating the prospect of any nationwide shortage this month.
Syria's military SPokesman asserted asserted today that artillery fire was inflicting losses on Israeli forces along the Golan Heights.

Jerry Quarry almost lost a $200,000 paycheck in the Nassau Coliseum tonight when little-known Joe Alexander of Sumpter, S.C.; floored the world's secondranking heavyweight challeger in the first round for a mandatory 8 count.
United States District Judge Joe Eator refused today to dismiss a $10 million libel suit filed by President Nixon's close friend Charles G. Rebozo, against The Washington Post.

Following are the results of yesterday's local school elections in Naseau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties. Further school elections will be held in these counties over the next six weeks.

On what would have 'been former President Harry S. Truman's 90th birthday, members of his family gathered beside his grave here today at a brief ceremony. 'Mr. Truman's daughter, Mrs. Clifton Daniel of Washington, and half a dozen other relatives stood in the courtyard of the Truman Library while a bugler played taps.

Dr. John McLaughlin, the Jesuit priest who is a special assistant to President Nixon, held an extraordinary news conference today to deny charges by Hugh Scott, the Senate minority leader, and other Republicans that, as Mr. Scott put it, the Watergate transcripts portrayed "deplorable, disgusting, shabby, immoral performances" by the President and his aides.
GENERAL Captain Scott and the Antarctic Tragedy, by Peter Brent (Saturday Review Press, Dutton, $12.50). An Illustrated account of the explorer's life and times.

The world mixed-pair championship began here this afternoon, with 236 pairs competing in the two-day event. Defending the title was the remarkable 77-year-old veteran, Waldemar von Zedwitz of New York, who began his illustrious career in the days of auction bridge and was one of the favorite partners of Ely Culbertson.
Mayor Beame, declaring that he was "quite concerned" about recent escapes and breaches of security in the city's jails, ordered an immediate investigation of the correction system yesterday.
The minority Liberal party Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau was toppled today when it lost a confidence vote in the House of Commons over its budget policies.

The younger set took over the North and South amateur golf tournament today and after the third and fourth rounds, the eight survivors ranged in age from 19-year-old Glen (Skeeter) Heath of Hampton, Va., to 36-year-old Dick Siderowf, the British Amateur champion from Westport, Conn.

A 377-pound priest who had difficulty getting into and out of a confessional box was honored today by a local diet club for having shed more than half his former bulk. The Rev. James Clark, now a svelte 172, received a tempting slice of cake and a set of leweled cufflinks as rewards. Father Clark is pastor of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church and School in Perth Amboy.

Formation of a five-member committee of directors of the New York Stock Exchange to study procedures by which companies to be listed on the exchange are allocated to specialist member, firms, was announced yesterday by James J. Needham, chairman.
A young mother and her two daughters were killed and two other children were seriously injured tonight when an explosion and fire rocked the woman's home here, the police said.

The Copper Range Company announced yesterday that, in contrast to other major companies, it would base its prices for domestic sales of refined copper on New York Commodity Exchange, Inc., prices for the metal.

Pan American World Airways, concerned over two crashes this year in which 204 persons were killed, ordered for its entire 140-plane fleet yesterday a new cockpit warning system designed to prevent such disasters.
President Nixon officially notified the United States Disstrict Court today that he would indeed fight the special prosecution's latest subpoena, earlier hints to the contrary notwithNews standing

Shaken by the defection of its star witness, the Government rested its case yesterday in the race-fixing trial of 13 harness drivers and nine co-defendants. Eight weeks of testimony from approximately 75 witnesses have produced a transcript of more than 6,000 pages. Unless Judge Orrin G.
The 700 members of local 211 of the teamsters are to vote tomorrow to ratify a contract proposal that ended their fiveweek strike against the Pitts. burgh Press Company.

The weight of evidence tends to establish that former Attorney General John N. Mitchell approved the. intelligence-gathering plan that led to the Watergate break-in, the Senate Watergate committee staff says in a draft report.

THE POISON ORACLE. BY Peter Dickinson. 181 pages. Pantheon. $5.95. Here's a murder mystery in which the only witness to the crime is a chimpanzee -a chimpanzee who has learned to communicate through a set of symbols. Here's a plot that raises such questions as "Can a chimpanzee lie?" Disguised as a suspense novel, "The Poison Oracle" also broaches such issues as the interplay between language and culture.
The Washington Star-News and The Washington Post terminated their labor contracts with the printers' union today but said they intended to continue negotiations.

The Milton Roy Company, a major producer of hard contact lenses based in St. Petersburg, and Automated Optics, Inc., an East Northport, L.I., company that owns patents to cosmetic soft contact lenses recently approved for marketing by the Food and Drug Administration, formally announced yesterday a joint venture for the manufacturing and sale of the new lenses on a nationwide scale.

When Willy Brandt resigned as Chancellor of the Federal German Republic, he gave the briefest of official explanations: "I accept the politicall responsibility for negligence in connection with the Guillaume espionage affair." The next day, for his parliamentary colleagues, he added:

Pretrial hearings in the murder trial of Police Officer Thomas J. Shea got under way in Queens yesterday, with a fellow policeman changing his story about what Officer Shea told him about the fatal shooting of a 10-year-old boy a year ago.

Dr. Gerson D. Cohen, newly ordained chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, tonight criticized those Americans, including Jews, who seek to abandon the merit system in their support of minority rights. The abandonment of the "ethos of merit," Dr. Cohen contended, is creating a falatious pseudo equality.

Kenneth B. Wackman, vice chairman of the Talcott National Corporation, a large factoring concern, died Tuesday evening at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 61 years old. Mr. Wackman, a graduate of the University of Wisconsin, began his financial career here in 1935 with the accounting firm of Alexander Grant Co.

An impasse over where a 5 per cent surcharge on bets placed at offtrack betting facilities will be imposed is delaying final approval by the Legislature of the Full fiscal package for New York City. The package is designed to close an $818-million gap in the city's budget for the coming fiscal year.
Four buffaloes escaped from their home at the Roger Williams Park Zoo and roamed for more than three hours yesterdav after vandals tore a hole in a fence.

The American Petroleum Institute reported today that estimated gasoline production, aviation and motor, for the week ended Friday amounted to 6,267,000 barrels a day, compared with 6,287,000 barrels a day in the previous week and

A defense lawyer in the trial of five men accused of the 1971 slaying of two policemen at a Harlem housing project contended yesterday that the prosecution's case was "inconsistent and full of contradictions."

Three Brazilian airlines placed orders yesterday with the Boeing Company for a total of 21 advanced 737 jet transports. The order, valued at about $135-million, is the largest South American order ever placed with Boeing. Varig will take 10 planes, Cruziero will take six and Vasp will take five.

There is no need to adapt the Presidency to a parliamentary model. But there is an acute need to modify the office. It is time to consider a step we have for two centuries avoided: separation of the Presidency into two functions, head of state and chief executive.
Theodore W. Kheel, the mediator in the newspaper dispute, asked the two sides last night to meet with him today for a resumption of contract negotiations.
Foreign Minister Menassie Haile resigned today. The resignation was accepted by Premier Endalkachew Makonnen after Emperor Haile Selassie had approved it.

Foreign Minister Menassie Haile resigned today. The resignation was accepted by Premier Endalkachew Makonnen after Emperor Haile Selassie had approved it.

Four persons were killed during a clash between the military and a group protesting the jailing of political prisoners, the police said today. The demonstrations occurred at San Francisco de Macoris in the northern part of the country. Among the dead were a 6-

A student starting now to look for a summer job at one of the nation's tourist spots faces bleak prospects. A nationwide Associated Press survey of tourist regions shows that summer jobs are not generally as plentiful as they once were and in many cases are already taken.

Henry L. Diamond, former State Environmental Conservation Commissioner, was named yesterday by Governor Wilson to the state's Environmental Board. Mr. Diamond resigned last December to become executive director of former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's Commission on Critical Choices for Americans.
A sharp earthquake rocked central Japan this morning. The police said 70 homes collapsed in an area about 50 miles southwest of Tokyo and at least one person was killed.

Portugal has been able to get through the first two weeks of revolution without a serious financial crisis because of emergency measures taken at the start of the military coup that toppled the dictatorship April 25.

James (Fly) Williams of Austin Peay, a sophomore, Gary Brokaw of Notre Dame and Michael (Campy) Russell of the University of Michigan, juniors, were among the 20 college undergraduates accepted yesterday by the National Basketball Association as hardship applicants for its May 28 college draft.

The Soviet leadership expressed its solidarity with East Germany today in the wake of the espiotage case that toppled Chancellor Willy Brandt. But there were signs that Moscow was not entirely happy with East Germany over the affair.

Eight amateur bicyclists challenged a commuter train to a race. The cyclists won. The race ran from McHenry, Ill., to Lake Geneva over a 21-mile stretch where, because of poor track conditions, the Chicago Northwestern Transportation Company has limited its diesel trains to 15 miles an hour.

Secretary of State Kissinger said that he had made "some progress" in his peacemaking efforts today, as he shuttled between Israel and Syria to convey each side's revised proposals for separating their troops on the Golan Heights.

Huge losses from its banana business was the major contributor to the $1.5-million deficit reported yesterday by the United Brands Company for the first quarter this year. In the similar three months last year the company had a net income of $5.6-million, or 46 cents a share.
Westchester County proposed today to assume the entire responsibility for processing and disposing of the 900,000 tons of garbage discarded in the county every year.

Fred W. Keny, a 1912 ?? pic gold-medal winner and aviation pioneer, died yesterday in a nursing home, at the age of 82. Mr. Kelly won the Olympic 110meter high hurdles in Stockholm and as a result was granted a full scholarship to the University of Southern California, graduating in 1917.

Cleon Rubin, 49 years old, of 914 Hancock Street, Brooklyn,.a member of a demolition crew working on a building at 650 Fifth Avenue at West 52d Street, fell four stories through a stairwell at 10 A.M. yesterday.

The new 450-seat theater at the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., will be opened tomorrow evening with performances by Victor Borge, the star of "Comedy in Music," and Marylyn Mulvey, soprano. Mr. Borge's daughter, Rikke, is a

We can quote chapter and verse about the works and world of Georges Auguste Escoffier, the man who is to the Gallic table what games are to Hoyle. But somehow, in the course of our labors in the world of food, we had never heard of Edouard Nignon, another of the titans of French cooking.

How long can one go on hoping for success in the face of adversity? Right up to the 21st and final game of his world championship match with Bobby Fischer in the summer of '72, Boris Spassky still expected to overcome his 3-point deficit and retain his title. At least that's what he said afterward.

The Chicago Tribune, long regarded as one of the nation's stannchest Republican newspapers, called today for President Nixon to leave office for the sake of "the Presidency, the country and the free world."

The Municipal Building, stereotyped in the public mind as a bureaucratic filing cabinet where the arcane business of city government is conducted in grubby surroundings, is scheduled for interior modernization at an outlay of $24million-twice what it cost to

Education officials here said today they would make "every effort" to resume the normal class schedule on Monday at this affluent commuter town's high school, which has been closed most of the week because of fighting between black and white students.

The Senate Judiciary Committee voted unanimously today. in executive session to begin fullscale hearings into the Justice Department's failure to unravel the Watergate cover-up in the summer and fall of 1972, Senate sources said.
The voters confirmed what the pollsters forepaw: Gaullist rule of France is over. It remains to be seen what vestiges are left, but the spirit is gone and grad-

Howard M. Pack, president of Seatrain Lines, Inc., which operates a shipbuilding enterprise in the former Navy Yard here, expressed surprise yesterday at being the target of a new investigation by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office.
Bill Moyers announced at the close of his weekly program on the Public Broadcasting Service Tuesday night that it was "the final edition" of the three-yearold "Bill Moyers' Journal."

Seven persons, including a 2-yearold boy and his infant brother, died in a three-alarm fire that destroyed a four-story brick apartment house here last night. Officials called it the worst residential fire in the city's history.

Considering the bleak news from overseas, it might be welcome to have a sunny, sparkling Israeli-made musical, foaming with melody and dancing and with a sweet underlying spirit of brotherhood. And this is exactly what happened yesterday with the arrival of "Kazablan" at the Festival and other showcases. The picture is delightful.

The elderly wife of a South Bronx shopkeeper was slain by a young gunman yesterday after she had pleaded with him during a $25 holdup to "leave some change in the cash register."

In 1929, Secretary of State Henry Stimson closed down the "black chamber"the State Department's code-breaking office - on the principle that the way to make men and nations trustworthy was to trust them. As he later told aide McGeorge Bundy, "Gentlemen do not read each other's mail."

Tne Akron Beacon-Journal resumed normal publication yes. terday after six days, having reached agreement on a new, one-year contract with members of Local 473 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

State Attorney General Robert Morgan emerged today as the Democratic nominee to fill the United States Senate seat being vacated by Sam J. Ervin Jr. Mr. Morgan, who ran a generally quiet, noncontroversial campaign, will face William E. Stevens, a furniture manufacturer who easily won the Republican nomination.
Despite the prospect of record crops of wheat and corn, prices of both grains rose sharply yesterday, continuing the strength they showed on Tuesday.
8--Calling his daughter's abductors "a bunch of criminals," Randolph A. Hearst posted a $50,000 reward today and said he would do anything in his power to secure her release.

The House Interior Committee all but complete today the final draft of a bill that would curb some of the worst abuses of surface mining for coal by imposing the first Federal environmental regulation on the booming strip mine industry.

The population growth rate of black Americans, although undergoing a slowing trend, continues to outpace that of whites, the Bureau of the Census reported today. A survey by the bureau found that the black population increased '5 per cent, from 22.8 million to 23.9 million, from 1970 to 1973.

The Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, put aside in middebate tonight a bill for the take-over of two Consolidated Edison Company power plants, charging that the State Democratic Chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, had ordered all Democratic Senators not to support the measure.

A $125,000 bonus was offered yesterday to any woman who scores a grand slam of tennis. Evonne Goolagong, with the Australian open already won, is the only player still in the running this year to win the big four tournaments; which also include the French open, Wimbledon and the United States Open.

The New York Stock Exchange's earnings dropped sharply in 1973, to $3.3-million from $16.2-million in 1972, James J. Needham, the Big Board's chairman, reported yesterday. Gross revenues were unchanged at $78-million, but costs climbed by $10.8-million in 1973, to $74.2-million.
Clarence M. Kelley, in his first news conference here since becoming director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation 10 months ago, said today. "we are stumped" in the kidnapping of Patricia Hearst.

The Byrne administration yesterday proposed a program that would require workers and employers to contribute more money to bolster the state's Unemployment Compensation fund. The measure would require legislative passage before it could be put into effect. The State Labor and Industry Commissioner, Joseph A. Hoffman, said it was time for workers and employers to "bite the bullet" because the fund was in "perilous, condition."

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey proposed a world food action program today "to lead the world back from the precipice of famine." Offering his program at the opening of an international conference on food and energy, the Minnesota Democrat urged that the United States take the initiative on the following broad fronts:

The Justice Department has asked the Federal District Court here to suspend proceedings in a civil suit charging that support prices for milk were raised in 1971 in return for contributions by dairy cooperatives to President Nixon's re-election campaign.
There were two returns to the New York City Ballet at, the New York State Theater on Wednesday night, when Edward Villella made his first appearance of the season, and George Balanchine's "Cortege
Jan Kodes got the last laugh on Ilie Nastase and Bjorn Borg stunned Arthur Ashe in surprising quarterfinal-round results of the $100,000 World Championship of Tennis tonight.
A state correction officer was shot to death last night by two Housing Authority police officers in a shootout near a bar and grill in Long Island City, Queens, the police reported.

With the Second and decisive vote for the presidency of France ten days away, both the political left and right are twisting themselves inside out to attract Gaullist voters. MOURN AIR-CRASH VICTIMS: People at a funeral in a suburb of Paris yesterday weeping for victims of Turkish Airlines jet that crashed near Paris March 3. All 346 aboard died, in worst air disaster in history.

Charges against four harness drivers accused of fixing superfecta races at New York tracks were dismissed by Judge Orrin G. Judd yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court. The ruling cleared the way for a return to racing by Ben Webster, Maurice Pusey, George Foldi and William Hudson. Harness drivers, from left, William Hudson, Maurice Pusey, George Foldi and Ben Webster outside of court in Brooklyn yesterday after their exoneration.

Thousands of university students clashed with policemen in Madrid and Barcelona today in the first such protests in three years. Dick Ruthven and Mac Scarce combined on a fourhit pitching effort last night in Veterans Stadium as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-2.

Some 10 days ago many people were disturbed by a proposal to run the centennial of the Kentqcky Derby in two sections. To their satisfaction, however, the Derby last Saturday had a "safe" 23 entrants, and Cannonade led all the others home, with no incident, in a non-split event.

Chris Hallinan is a young man who is going places in a hurry. The Bernards High School long-distance runner, though just 16 years old, is one of the top schoolboy runners in the country. Chris, a 5-foot-10-inch, 140-pounder, ran a mile in 4 minutes 16 seconds in an indoor dual meet at Lawrenceville in February that gave him the fastest time in the nation by a high school sophomore.

In Albany, the Legislature seems determined to kill a plan to establish a two-year degree-granting college for approximately 200 inmates of the state prison system, In Washington, the Federal Bureau of Prisons has adopted a half-hearted measure for adjudicating certain types of inmate grievances within the Federal prison system.

Rutgers University announced today that it planned to offer part-time and evening legal instruction beginning in September, 1975. The university's board of governors unanimously approved a recommendation by Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, president of the university, on the subject. Left open was where and in what form the instruction would take.

Denny Shute, former P.G.A. and British Open champion, died Monday.at his home here. He was 69 years old. Shute was the last golfer to win the P.G.A. championship two years in a row, taking the title in 1936 and 1937.
A $52.2-million expansion at its Fort Worth brewery was announced yesterday by the Miller Brewing Company. Construction will begin immediately and is expected to be completed in late 1975.

A majority of Italians want to retain the country's divorce law, final returns of a two-day referendum indicated. More than 59.1 per cent of the 32 million ballots upheld the law that since 1970 has made divorce possible in Italy. Votes in favor of repealing the law totaled 40.9 per cent. [1:2.]

Since the automobile first came into wide use a halfcentury ago, automobile accident cases have clogged the nation's lower courts. For plaintiffs, these trials have capricious results. Determining who was at fault is often so difficult as to be almost a metaphysical exercise. Some victims win huge damage awards while others who suffered approximately the same physical injuries receive much less or even nothing. Winners and losers alike have to wait years for a verdict.

A Federal trial jury was told today that Howard R. Hughes hired private detectives to follow bankers who had turned down his request for financing of Trans World Airlines jet planes purchases in the nineteen-sixties.

Charles G. Rebozo, former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and Senator John G. Tower, Republican of Texas, all aided in obtaining a Government job for a political supporter in exchange for information on a Chicano political party in Texas, The Houston Post said in a copyrighted article today.
Gov. J. James Exon, a Democrat, easily won nomination to a second term today and carried his virtually unknown running mate to victory over one of the state's most powerful figures.

Lillian D. Rock, who as vicepresident of the National Association of Women Lawyers and as national chairman of Women in Public Service, Inc., suggested in the nineteen-thirties that women fill high public office, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at her home, 440 East 57th Street. She was 71 years old.

Mayor Beame is planning a change that will greatly increase the status and authority of the city's Board of Ethics for the first time since it was formed in 1959 and became the model for some 500 similar municipal and state bodies.

The Greensburg (Pa.) Tribune-Review, whose publisher gave $1million to President Nixon's reelection campaign two years ago, urged the House today to impeach the President and urged the President to step aside pending a Senate trial.
John A. Fitz Randolph, a retired general partner in the investment firm of Francis L duPont Co., died yesterday at his home, 1062 Sunset Road, Stamford, Conn. He was 80 years old.

An executive and a mechanic from the Federal Pump Repair Company of Brooklyn, the concern that installed and renovated the water-pressure tank the Fire Department says triggered the April 22 gas explosion in an office building at 305 East 45th Street, refused to testify yesterday at a hearing convened by the National transportation Safety Board.

Denny Shute, former P. G. A. and British Open champion, died yesterday at his home here. He was 69 years old. Shute was the last golfer to win the Professional Golfers Association championship two years in a row, taking the title in 1936 and 1937.
Secretary of State Kissinger shuttled between Syria and Israel today without making any significant progress toward a troop separation agreement between the two countries.

The Consolidated Edison Company won preliminary approval of a $27.8tnillion, or 17 per cent, increase in its gas rates today as Governor Wilson summoned the bipartisan legislative leadership to his offices this evening for a final effort at resolving the impasse that continued to block state aid for the financially pressed utility.

A limit advance in silver futures prices at the opening set off a swarm of profit taking yesterday in that market and the resulting selling quickly spread to other commodity exchanges. "We are witnessing highly emotional markets," a prominent broker explained.

A public opinion poll that the White House is distributing around the country indicates that 54.3 per cent of the people surveyed want President Nixon to remain in office, while 35.3 per cent feel he should resign.
In a virtual rerun of his 1970 election victory, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson today won re-election to a second term on the strength of black votes cast in the city's South and Central Wards.

A lawyer tor relex computer Products, Inc., told a United States Court of Appeals here today that the International Business Machines Corporation had purposely redesigned electronic data-processing equipment and cut prices to drive Telex out of business.

A seven-man gang used a railroad locomotive to hijack box cars and steal produce at the Hunts Point Terminal Market, the police charged yesterday. Five Penn Central employes and two private security guards were arrested.

The Senate voted tonight with virtually no opposition to allow parents access to the school records of their children and to prevent such documents from being, given to others without parental consent.
In nonclerical terms, Dr. Donald Coggan has a hard act to follow. Dr. Coggan, who was named today as the next Archbishop

A fifth of the 60 Federal prosecutions against 626 defendants affected by Monday's wiretap decision by the United States Supreme Court originated in New Jersey, a survey of prosecutors in the metropolitan area disclosed yesterday.

James E. Smith, the Controller of the Currency, said today he had held a half-hour meeting Monday evening with Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who owns about 22 per cent of the Franklin New York Corporation, parent of the troubled Franklin National Bank.
Henry Benson Rockwell, who retired in 1969 as director of the Putney School in Vermont, died Sunday at his home in West Lebanon, N. H. He was 58 years old.

Federal prosecutors throughout the country reacted with dismay-and, in some cases, anger-to yesterday's Supreme Court decision that could result in the dismissal of hundreds of cases based on illegal wiretaps. "It's just too bad," one prosecutor said in a telephone survey.
A House report that $17.1million in Federal funds had been spent in connection with President Nixon's homes was approved today by the House Government Operations Committe. The vote was 36 to 0.

Raoul Berger, the legal scholar, has given James St. Clair, President Nixon's chief defense attorney, an academic scolding for basing his impeachment defense on what Mr. Berger calls "instant history," "far-fetched theories" and "sheer effrontery."

A Manhattan Supreme Court jury of 11 men and one worn an spent most of yesterday ir court listening to a rereading of testimony. by key witnesses including several who had testified they witnessed the fatal shooting in 1971 of twc police officers in a Harlem Housing Project.

Although more than two months have elapsed since the Internal Revenue Service admitted legal error and revoked a highly favorable tax ruling given to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in 1969,

The Mobil Oil Corporation has paid a one-time bonus equivalent to one month's salary to its non-union employes in the United States. No other major oil companies have taken similar actions but Texaco, Inc., and the Sun Oil Company have recently announced increases in the salaries of some non-union workers.
Twenty - three prominent Americans have agreed to serve on an independent commission that will re-examine United States relations with Latin America.

The Legislature late today approved a $115-million supplemental budget containing funds for items not anticipated when the main budget was adopted in March. Included was $4.5-million in salary increases for judges and $1.6-million for trials of inmates involved in the Attica prison rebellion of 1971.

The House Judiciary Committee, in its second closed impeachment hearing, focused today on the period immediately after the Watergate burglary in an effort to determine whether President Nixon played any role in the genesis of the attempt to cover up the break-in.
Andrew F. Brimmer, the first black member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and one of the highest ranking blacks in the Federal government. resigned yesterday,
President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt has reportedly urged President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to get the best terms he can for military disengagement with Israel and leave discussions on withdrawal

The recent move by the Italian Government to curb nonessential imports is a warning signal that the world energy crisis is far from over and may be entering a new and more dangerous phase. The payments imbalances set off by last year's fourfold increase in Mideast oil prices are beginning to register.

Italy's Roman Catholic hierarchy today de. plored the victory of the prodivorce forces in the national referendum Sunday and yesterday, but said that the church would show "due respect" for the will of the majority.
Little by little last night Ralph Houk became less of an ex-Yankee and more of a manager of the Detroit Tigers.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday receipt of a $100-million order from the New England Electric System for two 1.2million-kilowatt nuclear power plant reactor sys. teams, alone with the initial fuel load. The plant, whose site has not yet been announced, is expected to begin operation in 1982 and a year later for the second nuclear unit.
The House Agriculture Committee voted today to reduce Federal payments .to sugar growers and to allow a $110million excise tax on the refined produce to expire in 1975.

Gen. Francisco da Costa Gomes, who will shortly enter a new Portuguese Government as Defense Minister, acknowledged tonight that the Portuguese territory of Mozambique faced a serious economic and financial crisis as well as antagonism between the black majority and the white minority there.
Paul P. Rao Sr., former chief judge and now senior judge on the United States Customs Court here, was arrested yesterday and charged with lying to a special grand jury.

The White House acknowledged today that Mrs. Richard M. Nixon and her daughters had received gifts of jewelry, including a $52,400 matched set of emeralds and diamonds, from the Saudi Arabian royal family.

Jon Matlack and Tug McGraw, the two ranking casualties on the Mets' pitching staff, were examined by the Cardinals' physician, Dr. Stn London, who found no complications. Matlack strained a muscle in the left thigh last Saturday but will he allowed to try throwing again in a few days, McGraw warmed up in the bull pen Monday night and found some improvement in his left shoulder.... Representative Shirley Chisholm told a conference of civil rights leaders here yesterday that some of her black constituents and fellow members of the Black Caucus in Congress were having second thoughts about fighting for school integration.

The White House admitted today that differing versions of the same conversation had appeared in its edited Watergate transcript, but reiterated its assertion that the transcript gave the full substance of the tape recordings from which they were taken.
The United Nations command lodged a protest today with North Korea over the North Korean firing on two United States Army helicopters near the Korean demilitarized zone last Thursday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday continued the suspension of trading in the stock of the Franklin New York Corporation 10 more days to give the bank-holding company more time to unscramble its affairs.
Government diplomats paid tribute today to Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet as he was buried in the Rotunda of Illustrious Men.

The House Judiciary Committee, ir its second closed impeachment hearing, focused today on the period immediately after the Watergate burglary in an effort to determine whether President Nixon played any role in the genesis of the attempt to cover up the break-in.
New York State doctors whose medical malpractice insurance was canceled last fall have negotiated a contract with a new insurance company at a 93.5 per cent increase in premiums.
Pocono Downs, Inc., denied racing dates this year by the Pennsylvania Harness Racing Commission, today ordered all horses removed from the barn area of its race track.

Paul P. Rao Sr., former chief judge and now senior judge on the United States Customs Court here, was arrested yesterday and charged with lying to a special grand jury. The jury was investigating an a1leged scheme to bribe a State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn to influence the outcome of a robbery case.

PARIS--The Portuguese coup and the revolution developing in its wake are bound to have important strategic repercussions throughout Africa as that continent's last colonial empire starts to unravel. For now that Lisbon inferentially acknowledges it can no longer forcibly rule Angola and Mozambique, it is inevitable that they must either break away or dissolve in racial war.

"We're celebrating black women," said Alvin Ailey, director of the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater. So, for the company's new season, Mr. Ailey has invited Janet Collins and Pearl Primus, two black women who were pioneers in the dance, to stage their works for his dancers. "The Wedding," by Miss Primus, will have its company premiere tonight.

The Libyan Government has cut the price of crude oil to $12.75 to $13.30 per barrel, effective May 1 for the next five months, from a peak of $16, oil-industry sources reported here today.

Between 18,000 and 20,000 passengers using Clifton Bus Company routes, which primarily serves Morris and Essex Counties, may be forced to find other means of transportation when the contract with the company's 200 drivers expires Friday at midnight.
The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that a steam safety valve blew Monday night at its main nuclear plant at Indian Point and the plant was shut down.
The meaning of Watergate and the nation's reactions to the scandal provided the points of departure for major commencement addresses yesterday at Columbia University and Barnard College.

The Tax Reform Research Group said today that a report by the General Accounting Office on the Internal Revenue service was "inadequate" and "does not contain sufficient evidence to support its conclusion" that taxpayers are treated fairly.

Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson celebrated his 43d birthday today by jogging three miles around the Weequahic Park lake before going' to the office to resume a normal work schedule after his strong re-election victory yesterday.
United Air Lines, the nation's largest domestic air carrier, and American Air Lines, the second largest, reported yesterday sharply improved results for April.

Maheu described today how he had tried unsuccessfully to prevent details of the "Hughes-Nixon loan" from being publicized before the 1960 Presidential election and said he had rebuffed a suggestion from Howard R. Roman Michalowski, who lectured on international politics at New York University, died Tuesday at Doctors Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 243 East 71st Street.

While some of the club owners in the National and American Basketball Associations talk and think merger, John Havlicek and Julius Erving like it the way it is two leagues, two champions and the players' salaries skyrocketing.
Mrs. Olga Perger Wyman, of New York and Holmes, N. Y., widow of Charles A. Wyman, was married here yesterday to Clemens L. Resseguier, also of New York.
The final of the world open-pair championship of the World Bridge Federation began here this afternoon, with 13 United States pairs and two Canadian pairs challenging for the title.

Mayor Beame could not be there yesterday morning because of such pressing matters as the city's new budget, but, if he had he would have observed his Commissioner of Cultural Affairs in a hand-clapping foot-stomping dance with cast members of "Don't Bother Me, I Can't Cope."

The Republican leadership of the legislature tonight prepared to pass, with virtually no Democratic support, a drastically revised rent bill that removes most of the tenant protections Governor Wilson offered last week.
Three B-52 bombers left here for the United States today, beginning the first withdrawal of the big planes from Thailand since the Vietnam cease-fire agreement.

Ian Ball, the former mental patient accused of trying to kidnap Princess Anne and with wounding three persons in the attempt, will go on trial in London's Old Bailey courthouse next Wednesday on six charges of attempted murder and kidnapping.

The Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation announced yesterday plans for spending $200million on expansion of steelmaking and finishing facilities at its Aliquippa Works about 15 miles northwest of Pittsburgh on the Ohio River.

The mayors of New Jersey's major cities told a legislative committee today that they would like their police and firemen to live in town. The mayors of Newark, Jersey City, Trenton and Paterson, or spokesmen for them, told the committee they favor a Senate bill that would give municipalities the option of requiring public safety personnel to live where they worked.

The World Bank announced the signing of an agreement at par of the bank's bonds in the United Arab Emirates. The aggregate principal amount of the bonds is 300 million dirhams. equivalent to $76-million.

Pope Paul VI today voiced "amazement and pain" over the outcome of the referendum Sunday and Monday in which Italians voted, 59.1 per cent to 40.9 per cent, to retain the nation's three-year-old divorce statute.

Union printers voted by a 3to-1 margin today to authorize a strike against The Washington Post and The Washington StarNews, their leaders announced.
Schick, Inc., which has not paid cash dividends on its common stock since 1958, is also omitting the June 1 quarterly dividend on the preferred, Edward E. Ettinger, chairman, announced yesterday.

Jack Magidson, distribution and controls manager for the I.B.M. World Trade Corporation, died Tuesday. He was 46 years old and lived at 16 Turkey Hill Road South, Westport, Conn.

For the fourth consecutive session, prices closed lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as a broad retreat by Canadian petroleum stocks and investor concern oyer rising interest rates continued to exert pressures on investors.
Mayor Henry R. Cloff won a second term yesterday, defeating three opponents by more than a 2-1 margin in an election after being cleared of corruption charges just six days before the vote.

Edison posted eight victories and scored 173 points yesterday to win the Queens public high schools track and field championships at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. Bryant and Jackson were second and third, respectively.

A 24-year-old man among a group of 20 persons who were picketing outside the Lincoln Hospital was shot in the shoulder and three others were injured in a scuffle yesterday, the police of the Alexander Avenue station reported.
Gen. Antonio de Spinola became President of Portugal today and named a left-leaning Government dedicated to organizing democracy here and -in Portuguese Africa.

New Jersey, the 1973 winner, captured the 49th Golf Illustrated Trophy in the women's Metropolitan Golf Association intersectional matches played today at the Cold Springs Country Club.

The defense in the racefixing trial of New York harness drivers yesterday trotted out three of the sport's well-known authorities at the Brooklyn Federal Building to support its claim that there had been no wrongdoing by its clients.
Election officials counting the ballots in the District 1 Community School Board vote last Tuesday said yesterday that two candidates, Adolph Roher and Henry Ramos, had apparently been elected.

The Federal Trade Commission has initiated an investigation to determine whether the health warning required for cigarette advertisements in newspapers and magazines has been printed in type smaller than required by a two-year-old consent decree.

The Frick Collection has changed its plans for the development of the vacant property adjacent to it on East 70th Street, and intends to put up a one-story building where the six-story building where the six-story George D. Widener mansion stood until it was demolished last year.

A controversial measure authorizing casino gambling in New Jersey cleared the final legislative hurdle this evening with State Senate approval by a vote of 24 to 13. The bill thus received just the three-fifth majority needed for a constitutional amendment. Legislators gathering for season's last session of State Senate to discuss casino gambling and other Issues.

Before it was turned back into a legitimate theater, the Bijou Theater on West 45th Street was a home for Japanese movies. Now the samurai fight again, live, onstage, in a new musical, "Ride the Winds."

Secretary of.State Kissinger returned to Israel early this morning after making some last minute "new approaches" to President Hafez all Assad of Syria to overcome the remaining hurdles toward a SyrianIsraeli troop separation agreement on the Golan Heights.

Compromise legislation on a legal services plan barely survived a serious test in the House of Representatives today but then went on to win passage by a vote of 227 to 143.

Lee Thomas Melly, former vice president and vice chairman of the board of the Ward Baking Company, died Wednesday in St. Vincent's Hospital, Bridgeport, Conn. He was 75 years old and lived in Bronxville, N. Y.

The Standard Oil Company of California agreed today to pay $2-million in back wages to 160 employes it had discharged and to rehire 120 of them. The settlement was, by far, the largest ever made under the Age Discrimination in Employment Act.
A 29-year-old employee of Icelandic Airlines was crushed to death last night by a front nose wheel of a DC-8 jet on a ramp at John F. Kennedy International Airport, the police reported.

Mario Soares, right, newly appointed Foreign Minister of Portugal, reading during swearing-in ceremonies yesterday in Lisbon. Gen. A controversial measure authorizing casino gambling in New Jersey cleared the final legislative hurdle this evening with State Senate approval by a vote of 24 to 13. The bill thus received just the three-fifths majority needed for a constitutional amendment.

Wheat futures inched upward yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade still influenced by talk of additional export business, mostly from Japan and Colombia. July delivery wheat closed at $3.71, up from $3.70 a bushel.
With the boom of ceremonial can ions and crowds cheering out side the Federal Assembly buildingg today, 82-year-old Marshal Tito signed a document making him President or Yugoslavia for life.

Compromise legislation on a legal services plan barely survived a serious test in the House of Representatives today but then went on to win passage by a vote of 227 to 143.
