Secretary General Waldheim has made an approach to the new Portuguese Government urging it to heed United Nations resonutions calling for independence for the African Portuguese territories.

Syrian gunners shelled Israeli positions and one settlement on the Golan Heights today, mainly around the salient captured by Israel in the October war, a military spokesman said here. Israel suffered no casualties, he added.
The launching of the first "weather bureau in the sky," originally scheduled for yesterday morning, was postponed a day when tests suggested that a component of the launching vehicle was defective.
The Montreal Expos, in a running battle with Philadelphia for first place in the National League's Eastern Division, had beaten the Phillies eight successive times.

A confidential evaluation by the City University has concluded that Manhattan Community College is suffering from "severe deficiencies." The report has found that faculty morale "is at an all-time low," Robert J. Kibbee, chancellor of City University, wrote, "the college is chewing on its vitals." Dr. Edgar D. Draper, president of Manhattan Community College, said college morale is "wonderful."

President Joaquin Balaguer today won re-election to a third successive term, but many Dominicans observed an opposition boycott of the election. According to preliminary returns, only about half of the two million registered voters participated in the election,

The island nation of Jamaica -the world's leading exporter of bauxite and the largest supplier to the United States -outlined plans yesterday to almost triple the taxes and royalties that it takes from foreign aluminum companies engaged in mining its precious natural resource.

Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, urged a Federal judge today to reject the contention that "national security" was involved in the burglary of the office of Dr Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist in 1971.

With his guilty plea yesterday, former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst became the first former Cabinet member convicted of misconduct in office since Albert B. Fall, who in 1929 was found guilty of bribery in the Teapot Dome scandal while serving as President Harding's Interior Secrelary.
No sooner was John Elliott Jr., chairman of Ogilvy Mather, elected the new chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies here today than he asked for money. John Elliott Jr.

A popular Russian Orthodox priest has been called in by the church hierarchy and ordered to explain in writing the outspoken opinions he expressed in an exchange of questions and answers with his congregation.
New and rare works to be performed next season by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center were announced yesterday by Charles Wadsworth, its artistic director.

The "Three by Three" concert format Carnegie Hall introduced last year in cooperation with a National Public Radio project has been brought back this year in a series of three events, of which the first was given Wednesday night.

Helmut Schmidt, elected and sworn in today as West Germany's fifth postwar chancellor, said that he would "continue the foreign policy conceived and begun" by Willy Brandt, who resigned 10 days ago in an espionage scandal. Helmut Schmidt, upon being elected Chancellor yesterday in Bonn, received this hug from Hans Hermsdorf, the State Secretary in the Economics and Finance Min. istry. Mr. Schmidt had headed the ministry.

Nikki Pilic returned from a Davis Cup battle and prepared for a new war of nerves with the New York Sets of World Team Tennis. "I've heard about some of the ideas in team tennis," the rangy, 34-year-old Yugoslav left-hander said yesterday, referring to the shouting, cheering and casual atmosphere encouraged at team tennis events.

An elderly woman was carried unconscious from her burning apartment and seven firemen were felled by dense smoke last night in a threealarm blaze htat heavily damaged a brownstone in Brooklyn Heights and left half a dozen families homeless.

The Senate narrowly approved today a weakened version of a provision aimed at barring the long-distance busing of childrew to end school segregation but leaving the final decision on school busing cases to the courts.
Rumors of an imminent breakup of the European joint currency float - strongly denied by the participating governments - threw foreign-exchange markets into confusion today.

In a step that could force some major oil companies to reduce prices, the Federal Energy Administration proposed today new rules for determining what the companies may charge for crude oil they buy from their own foreign affiliates.

Revenge!" disrupted the state funeral held here today for 18 of the teenaged students murdered in the Arab terrorist assault yesterday. Dr. John H. Mulholland, former George David Stewart Professor and chairman of the department of surgery of the New York University School of Medicine, died yesterday at his home in Heritage Village, Southbury, Conn.

A week after Governor Wilson proposed a tenant-oriented system of statewide rent regulation, the Legislature early this morning passed a drastically different bill limited to New York City and its suburbs and retaining the basic provisions of vacancy decontrol.

On the kind of windswept morning with driving rain that makes people grateful if they don't have to go out, a small bus jounced among construction sites on Roosevelt Island and pulled up in front of Goldwater Memorial Hospital. Helen Satterthwaite, an RSVP volunteer, conducts a slide lecture for elderly men and women gathered at Temple Beth Jacob in the East Bronx.

A Palestinian leader said here today that the attack at Maalot, Israel, that three members of his organization staged yesterday had been aimed against the Middle East peace mission of Secretary of State Kissinger.

Ilie Nastase of Rumania and Manuel Orantes of Spain, seeded first and second, won their secondround matches today to enter the quarterfinals of the men's singles in the Bavarian international tennis tournament.
A protest strike organized by extreme Protestant groups went into its second day today, with industry largely shut down but most shops and services functioning.
A murder charge was brought against a man yesterday after the victim's widow recognized the alleged killer by his tattoos and earings in a chance encounter in a hospital corridor on Wards Island.
Victor Geoffrion, a bass violinist for 65 years, died Tuesday at St. John's Queens Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

Special to The New York Times LONDON, May 16 - The treasury announced today it would pay a record interest rate of 12.75 per cent to borrow $960-million from the public in the costliest financing in British history.
The prime lending rate of the nation's largest banks should rise to a record high of 11 1/2 per cent from 11 1/4 per cent.

Citing "skyrocketing" fuel and maintenance costs and a serious operating deficit, the City Housing Authority yesterday proposed rent increases averaging 8 per cent, beginning Aug. 1, in two-thirds of the 165,000 apartments in its lowincome projects.
Robert Abrams, the Bronx Borough President, called on Governor Wilson yesterday to veto the rent bill passed by the Legislature.
The Continental National Bank, believed to be the first Cubanowned and Cuban-operated bank in the country, opened for business here yesterday.

The latest figures from the New York Stock Exchange on margin debt clearly point to a further deterioration in stock market credit. As of the end of April, accounts that were less than 40 per cent paid up-the ones most vulnerable to margin calls as stock prices recede-made up 16 per cent of all margin accounts. The figure was 12 per cent in March.

The arrests or a omited States Customs Court judge, his son and his son's law partner on Tuesday raise unresolved questions concerning the propriety of using fake arrests as a tech nique for investiNews gating corruption Analysis in the criminaljustice system.

Robert Abrams, the Bronx Borough President, called on Governor Wilson yesterday to veto the rent bill passed by the Legislature. Mr. Abrams urged the Governor to propose new legislation that would abolish vacancy decontrol, which the. present bill preserves.

Robert Petrarca, a 27-year-old window washer, was sentenced today in Essex County Court by Superior Court Judge Ralph L. Fusco to two consecutive life terms in prison for the murder of two Upper Montclair women in their home on May 14, 1973.

A Federal judge in Newark upheld the jury conviction of a former Republican state chairman, Nelson G. Gross, for conspiring to commit tax fraud with contributors to Gov. William T. Cahill's 1969 campaign. Mr. Gross was found guilty in March of five counts of tax fraud and suborning perjury of one of the contributors, William H. Preis of the Grand Union Company.
Russell M. Sanderson, a former director and vice president of Smith, Barney Co., Inc., member of the New York Stock Exchange, died of cancer yesterday at Hillcrest Hospital in Pittsfield, Mass.
Four Black Muslims were indicted today by a state grand jury on charges of murdering three white persons and of conspiring to murder whites at random.

The Association of 'American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17.3 billion ton-miles, 1.4 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 543,860 cars, 0.9 per cent below last year.

Reflecting continuing low trading volume, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that first quarter "net revenues" declined 43 per cent from the year-ago period. The net for the quarter was $541,000 on gross revenues of $18.7-million, which compared with $948,000 on a gross of $19.8-milion last year.
Paul Gonsalves, Duke Ellington's tenor saxophonist, was found dead in bed Wednesday K at a house in North London, the police there reported. He was 53 years old and lived in New York.
The executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee cautioned American Jews yesterday not to label everyone who disagrees with them as anti-semitic.

A misunderstanding may have led to the battle in the Maalot school yesterday in which 20 Israeli high school students and three Arab terrorists were killed, officials involved in the negotiations said today.

No purpose has been served, nothing has been achieved-except the death of innocents and the clouding over of the most promising prospect for peaceful disengagement that the troubled area has known for many years past.

If Richard Nixon lived in Sweden, the truth about his tax deductions and payments would have been known as soon as he filed his return. By tradition and law, just about every public document here is open to anyone who wants to see it, whether it concerns him or not.

Rescue workers looking for survivors in a building In Saida struck during Israeli raids against Lebanon The body of a Palestinian killed in an Israeli raid on the Nabatieh refugee camp in Lebanon being borne away. Egypt tonight denounced Israel's bombing attacks on Lebanon but continued to observe complete official silence about the attack on a school in Maalot, Israel, yesterday. Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy issued a statement denouncing "Israel's repeated aggression against densely populated civilian areas" in Lebanon, and pledged Egyptian support for Lebanon if needed.
A widow who operated a jewelry store was shot to death yesterday morning in the doorway of her home in Highland Park without apparent motive, the state police reported.
A woman with her 3-yearold son in her arms leaped in front of a Queens subway train yesterday and, although two cars passed over them, neither was seriously injured.

The New York Pro Musica Antiqua performed for the last time at an invitation Petrarch concert last night at the Pierpont Morgan Library, and today the collection of instruments used in its performance of early music is being turned over to New York University.
Imperial Oil, Ltd., which is 70 per cent owned by the Exxon Corporation, announced in Toronto yesterday that it had raised its wholesale prices for gasoline and heating oil, its principal products.
Tom Okker upheld his second seeding with a 6-4, 5-7, 6-0 victory over Cliff Richey today in gusty winds to reach the quarterfinals of the $150,000 Alan KingCaesar's Palace tennis tournament.

Lieut. Gen. Guy Granville Simonds, a leading Canadian field commander in World War II who was at the age of 39 the Dominion's youngest general, died yesterday. He was 71 years old. Lieut. Gen. Granville Simonds, as major general in World War II, wading to shore in Sicily from a landing craft.

The House Judiciary Committee heard evidence today about one of the key elements in the Watergate case - the vast amount of money that financed the Watergate burglary and the subsequent payments to the burglars.

A lawyer for Charles G. Rebozo reportedly said in a telegram it sent today to the Senate R Watergate committee that because of "intentional false and malicious" leaks about his client's testimony, he would petition the panel to withdraw its subpoena for Mr. Rebozo's bank records.
Housing starts rose by almost 10 per cent in April to an annual rate of 1.63 million units, the Commerce Department reported today.

It will take enormous effort to provide enough energy for American needs during the next 10 years and even then the effort may only postpone a grim future of scarcity, an expert panel of engineers reported to the Government today.

Matthew P. Boylan, director of State Division of Criminal Justice, announcing Equity Funding indictments.

With the election of William Rockefeller as president of the Metropolitan Opera Association, a question that comes instantly to the mind of a non-Rockefeller is Feels the arts cannot depend upon private philanthropy to get along.

Agreement was reached here today on the first steps toward construction of Connecticut's innovative $290-million system for converting all the state's household and commercial garbage into low-sulphur fuels for electric generating plants and commercially salable scrap iron, aluminum and glass.

Lloyd Monroe of Upper Montclair, in his 10th year as a golf professional, won the $25,000 Dodge open today with a 72-hole total of 281 at the Rockaway River Country Club. Lloyd Monroe driving during last round of Dodge open at Denville, N. J., which he won with a 281.
A Federal grand jury today indicted 12 building maintenance concerns and five company officials on charges of rigging bids and allocating customers throughout New Jersey.

The 43-member City Council prepared to pare Mayor Beame's "austere" $11.1-billion budget yesterday. The Councilmen-33 are up for re-election in November-seem determined not to impose nuisance taxes or increase the real-estate tax by 45 cents to balance the budget.
The Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater has drawn its chief inspiration from the black heritage, but that heritage up to now seemed to be defined by the Western hemisphere.

The Agriculture Department alarmed at a growing intrusion of meat packers into the custom feedlot business, announced today that it would put into effect stiff new rules to prohibit dual ownership of such enterprises.
United States District Judge Alfonso J. Zirpoli ordered two persons jailed today who had refused to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the Patricia Hearst kidnapping here.
The House voted today to keep the Overseas Private Investment Corporation going three more years but to move it out of the risky war and expropriation insurance business.

The General Accounting Office disclosed today that it intended to seek access to records al, of the White House gifts unit in Jo an investigation of compliance with the law regarding foreign gifts to Government officials and the President's family.

John Davies Stamm, an art collector of this city and Lenox, Mass., where he owned the Walker-Rockwell Gallery, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at his home, 120 East 95th Street. He was 63 years old.
American car production is expected to drop by 1,413 units this week from last, largely because of a strike that has forced the shutdown of the main Cadillac assembly plant in Detroit.
Ruth McGinnis, wommen's pocket billiard world champion, died of cancer yesterday at the age of 64. Miss McGinnis began playing billards at the age of 7 at her father's billiard parlor here.
The Xerox Corporation did slightly better in April than the 13 per cent profit increase and 20 per cent revenue gains reported for the first quarter, the company disclosed here today.

The Saigon command said today that up to 5,000 North Vietnamese troops, backed by tanks, had overrun a South Vietnamese base, inflicting heavy losses and pushing the remnants of the fleeing government forces into a tight pocket.
The president of the Grumman Corporation said yesterday the company expected soon to regain its credit line with commercial banks and to cancel the agreement providing loans from the Navy.
When Texas loyalists say "The South will rise again," what they have in mind is the wind that rises out of the South to defend the 7,142-yard, par-70 course of the Colonial Country Club.

In the shambles of the adjournment rush at Albany, the Republican majority in the State Legislature-with indeterminate help from Governor Wilson-has undone the sensible rent control bill agreed upon by the Governor, Mayor Beame and a bipartisan coalition of legislators from New York City. In its place, the Legislature has enacted a measure that provides almost no relief from the irresponsible vacancy decontrol law adopted three years ago.

Four measures broadening the rights of the state's 3.8-million tenants received final legislative approval in the State Senate today with no opposition. Governor Byrne, who made tenant rights a major plank in his campaign platform, is expected to sign the measures into law without delay.

Despite daily reports that the farm prices of meat, wheat and many other basic commodities are heading down sharply from their all-time peaks of a few months ago, it costs the average New York City family $7 today to buy the same amount of food $6 would buy a year ago.

In an effort to unseat the powerful Republican who is Speaker of the New York State Assembly, Perry B. Duryea, the Democrats of his home Suffolk County have nominated Mrs. Joyce Burland as their candidate in the 1st Assembly District on Long Island. Although Mrs. Burland is a newcomer to county campaigning, she is no neophyte in politics.
Prices of wheat futures registered sharp declines yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade following the announcement late Thursday by the Canadian Wheat Board of a $1-a-bushel price cut.

A limited death penalty was restored today by Governor Wilson, who found "sufficient benefits" to mandate it for the murders of policemen and prison workers, and in murders committed by life-term prisoners.

Four Philadelphia Black Muslims were convicted today in the slaying of seven Hanafi Moslims on Jan. 18, 1973, at their northwest Washington headquarters. A Superior Court jury returned the verdict after two days of deliberations.

Mrs. Ann King, wife of a former narcotics detective now under investigation in the theft of millions of dollars worth of heroin from the police department property clerk's office, made "substantial deposits to numerous banks" over the last five years, according to court papers filed yesterday.

Maxwell Eckstein, composer, pianist and arranger, who was a consultant and former piano editor of Carl Fischer, Inc., music publishers, died Thursday at his home, 108 Sanford Street, Yonkers. He was 69 years old. Mr. Eckstein specialized in educational music and prepared the Eckstein Piano Course and "The Let Us Have Music" series.
A judge dismissed Federal charges today against W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers. Mr. Boyle was convicted last month on state murder charges in the Yablonski slaying.

A surprising suggestion that demands by responsible consumer activists should be examined with an open mind was made here today by the head of one of the country's largest food companies and a major advertiser.
Evonne Goolagong and Dianne Fromholtz scored straight set victories today over Italian opponents and moved Australia into the semifinal round of the Federation Cup tennis competition.

In an unseasonable burst of summertime weather, the temperature climbed past a 78 year-old record of 87 degrees here yesterday and set a new May 17 mark of 92, leading the Consolidated Edison Company to begin its first hotweather voltage reduction of the year and causing extensive delays on the Long Island Rail Road.

President Nixon asserted the doctrine of executive privilege again today in an effort to block a Government subpoena for correspondence between himself or his White House aides and Maurice H. Stans, who was his chief fund raiser in the 1972 campaign.

The incredibly gloomy estimate originally issued by the Commerce Department on the depths of national "slumpflation" in the first quarter of this year has proved not gloomy enough. The Labor Government of Prime Minister Gough Whitlam is favored to survive tomorrow when Australians vote in their second national election in 17 months.

In Louisville not far from Churchill Downs is a primary school where the teacher in an early grade digs horse racing. Each year as the Kentucky Derby approaches, the kids in her class fashion horses' heads from paper, affix them to broomsticks and name them after steeds entered in the Derby. Then, straddling their broomsticks, the kids race around the classroom with Teach serving as starter, placing judge and steward.

Two police officers, Kenneth Ukronets and Leopold Stiuso, were fired on early yesterday morning while on routine patrol in Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. Two shots, fired at DeKalb Avenue and South Elliott Place, broke a window of the patrol car and the car, out of control, crashed into a tree. The police searched the area, but were unable to find who had fired the shots. The two police officers were treated for minor bruises.

Our Own," which he wrote and then adapted in collaboration with David Shaber ("Such Good Friends," etc.).

But it's maintaining consistency, under pressure, that's most important."

Two deans at a Bronx junior high school have been accused by teachers and students of using a thick wooden paddle, leather straps and their fists to enforce discipline at the school.

Dr. Fritz Jules Roethlisberger, first Wallace B. Donham Professor of Human Relations at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, died Friday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 75 years old.

Optimism that a contract settlement between union printers and the city's three major daily newspapers was now likely was expressed yesterday by Bertram A. Powers, president of New York Typographical Union No. 6, which has been engaged in a work stoppage at The Daily News,

The community school board election in District 1 has denied a decisive victory to both factions in the contest. Although the United Federation of Teachers emerged with a 5-4 majority, the Por Los Nifios (For the Children) slate identified with Luis Fuentes, the controversial district superintendent, managed to reduce the union's former representation by one seat.

A French grand prix ace, JeanPierre Beltoise, and a codriver, Jean-Pierre Jarier, swept their 12-cylinder Matra-Simca round the twisting circuit of Nuerburgring today to win the 1,OO0 kilometer race and moved Matra into the lead for the manufacturers' world championships.
Mrs. JoAnne Carner, a former winner of the Bluegrass invitation golf tourney, won the event for a second time today in a sudden-death playoff with Sandra Spuzich.
Miss Paula Melinda Borger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Borger of New .Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday morning to David Emrys Morgan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emrys Morgan of Worcester, England.

A72-acre expanse of unspoiled woodland was dedicated here today as a nature and wildlife sanctuary, to be preserved in perpetuity with a $250,000 endowment donated by Mr. and-Mrs. Walter M. Weis of New York City.

President' Anwar el-Sadat said tonight that he had received a friendly message from the Soviet party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, that would usher in a new stage in relations between the two countries.

Israel said today that both she and Syria could accept the compromise cease-fire line proposed by Secretary of State Kissinger to clear the way for a SyrianIsraeli agreement on separation of forces on the Golan Heights.

Portugal's new military-backed Government is urgently inviting signals for truce talks from the guerrilla movements in Angola and Mozambique following its agree. ment for talks with the rebels in Portuguese Guinea.
The five major stock exchanges took an irreversible step last week toward creating a "consolidated" ticker tape, a keystone of the central market system envisioned for the nineteen-eighties.
India's explosion Saturday of a nuclear device inevitably raises the question of how near is she to membership in the club of nations armed with nuclear weapons?

There are two methods that could Weaken supply restrictions -rapid nationalization by members of Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries,, and coupling American military and political policy with conditions in the world oil market.
Herbert J. Wollner, a chemical engineer, who was former secretary of the office here of the United Nations Standards Committee, died Friday in Boston. He was 73 years old and lived in Belmont, Mass.

The Houston Aeros, with two goals each by Murray Hall and Larry Lund and Gordie Howe's four assists, defeated the Chicago Cougars 6-2 tonight to win the World Hockey Association championship in four straight games.

To the gardener,' dandelions are anything but splendor in the grass. But to the creative cook, they're an ingredient for a tasty salad; to the winemaker, they're an element for a sweet, potent brew; to the craftsman, they're a coloring for a golden dye; to the photographer, they're an intriguing subject, and to the child, they're gossamer puffs to blow apart or yellow blossoms to twine into a bouquet.
Clayton L. Seitz, a retired senior vice president of the American International Underwriters Corporation, died Satarday of a heart attack at his home in Greenwich, Conn. His age was 66.

Paul F. Chatelain, retired director of sales for Realty Hotels, Inc. - the Biltmore, Barclay and Park Lane Hotels- died Saturday in Flushing (Queens) Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 42-45 Kissena Boulevard, Flushing.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark. - The people who scoffed when Orval E. Faubus announced that he was running again, for the eighth time in 20 years, are now grimly conceding that he has an outside chance of becoming the Governor of Arkansas once more.

The first Eastern Lawn Tennis Association junior indoor grand prix, the most ambitious tournament series for players 18 and under in E.L.T.A. history, draws to a close this week, with final eliminations scheduled for May 23-26 at the Roslyn Racquet Club on Long Island.

A flashy wire for terrier, Ch. Sunnybrook Spot On, keeps right on the winning trail. Today, at the 72d Long Island Kennel Club Show, the English import, owned by Mrs. Robert V. Clark Jr. of Middleburg; Va, gaited his way to his 19th top award.

Hays Clark's and Jim Grant's Gambler, a 40-foot Standfast sloop out of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, won the Larchmont Y. C.'s annual distance race for the Edlu Trophy today.
Old age is overtaking the ships of the Soviet Navy and should reduce their number considerably by the end of the decade, a Defense Department study has concluded.

WASHINGTON--Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger is trying to convince Congress to fund: the biggest military budget in United States history. His approach blends hoary coldwar assumptions with new and sophisticatedrationales.

On a weekend when country music was mixed with stock-car racing at a horse track, the Mason-Dixon 500 ended on a sour note for Richard Petty today.

Repeal of the foreign tax credits available to United States oil companies would undermine the oil industry, raise the cost of imported oil and curtail the nation's foreign earnings, according to a report released today by the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation.

For the last year and a half, the threeblade windmill, mounted atop a 50-foot tower behind his sprawling farm house, has been the source of electricity to light his home, wash his clothes and pump his water.

Mrs. Dorothy Dinforth Compton, a trustee of the Danforth Foundation and of College Careers of Westchester, Inc., died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. She was 78 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.
It was a gala day-ini-thepark for more than 800 elderly citizens of this city as they were entertained today by volunteer groups and the New Brunswick Department of Social Services.
Dan Topping, an owner of the New York Yankees in their glory years after World War II, died of complications of emphysema Saturday night at the Miami Heart Institute. He was. 61 years old.

Having established his unchallenged leadership over New Jersey's Democratic party and his new state administration, Governor Byrne now faces the controversial issues of tax reform and public school financing.

The naming of a Chief Medical Examiner for the city to replace Dr. Milton Helpern has been delayed by a dispute over selection procedures that has angered and embarrassed the five deputy medical examiners here.

Roy E. Randall, Haverford College football coach for 27 seasons and the all-America quarterback of Brown University's "Iron Men" team of the nineteen-twenties, died yesterday at his home in Tuckerton, N.J. He was 70 years old.

The prosecution has rested in a murder trial here that could make medical and legal history on the definition of death. They key issue in the trial is whether the removal of the victim's heart, while still beating, for use in a transplant operation means that death was caused by the operation rather than by a gunshot wound.

The did man on Ridge Street was talking about his landlord. "He has an evil mind, a greedy face and a false smile," the old man said, and then he sat down. He was small and bent over, and his chin rested on his chest. "Here," he said, "I have some cookies for you."

Continuing to prove why he is one of the best amateur golfers in the nation, George Burns finished his 13th day of tournament golf in the last 16 days by easily winning the 64th annual Walter J. Travis Memorial tournament today.

Tyree Glenn, who played the trombone and vibraphone with many of the great jazz names of the big-band era, died Saturday in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 308 West Englewood Avenue in Englewood.

WASHINGTON--In the coming debates on impeachmnet, two groups of Americans will be making the noise and getting the attention while two other groups will be making the decision.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation classified Patricia Hearst as "an armed 'and dangerous fugitive" tonight and announced that felony charges would be filed against her as the woman who fired a machine gun into a sporting goods store here on Thursday.

ABERDEEN, Scotland The electric guitars and the lyrics to American country and Western ballads boomed out across the dance floor at the Petroleum Country Club here the other night as oilmen enjoyed a boisterous session of drinking, dining and dancing.

The Philadelphia Flyers arrived today. With a remarkable 1 0 shutout of the-Boston Bruins at the Spectrum, the National Hockey League's West Division champions turned back the East Division champions, 4 games to 2, and became the first expansion team to win the Stanley Cup and the league title.

The legendary David.Ogilvy, who attended his first American Association of Advertising Agencies meeting in 1938 and last spoke at one 15 years ago, delivered a sentimental "thank you" to Madison Avenue today as the association ended its 57th annual meeting.

Another roundelay for seats on the New York State Court of Appeals, with judges dancing for party and popular favor, is in prospect for the third year in a row. Having merely gone through the motions and failing to create a pre-screened appointive system for the judiciary, the State Legislature has put the burden back on the ballot. That is where the politicos, who control the nominations that usually determine the outcome, want it.

Soldiers ride through the streets of this bustling African city, where skyscrapers and highrise apartment buildings adjoin extensive areas of slum shacks. But there are no other visible martial signs here. The war with guerrillas is far away; it has continued for 13 years mainly in border areas to the east and north, with the guerrillas operating from bases in Zambia, Zaire and the Congo Republic.

Jamaica, the world's largest exporter of bauxite, has rejected an offer by American aluminum producers that would have boosted their tax and royalty payments to the island's Government from $25 million to $80 million in the coming thirteen months; instead, Jamaica is demanding an increase to about $200 million.

Adoption and implementation of a national "urban bill of rights" to supplement the Federal Constitution's Bill of Rights were urged here tonight as a means to achieve a "just society" and to avoid civil disobedience and violence.
Military sources said that three Vietcong infiltrators dynamited a 250,000-gallon fuel tank at Nha Be early today, sending huge balls of fire into the sky above South Vietnam's largest fuel depot.

Dr William D. Mackolin, the controversial Superintendent of Schools who lost the support of the Board of Education here, has accepted an administrative post in New York and may be leaving here shortly.
Arm-wrestling may strike most people as a harmless reaffirmation of masculinity for boys of all ages, usually carried on in the corner tavern after five or six boilermakers.

Premierdesignate Yitzhak Rabin received a mandate from his Labor party tonight to form a new governing coalition somewhat more leftist than the outgoing administration of Premier Golda Meir.

Israel continued her. reprisal raids against Palestinian camps in Lebanon today with a naval bombardment of the Rashidiyah refugee camp south of the old port of Tyre. Abu Yussef, a Palestinian guerrilla leader at the camp told newspapermen later that eight people had been killed and about 10 wounded by missiles fired by Israeli gunboats.

George Bush, chairman of the Republican National Committee, rejected today the suggestion that President Nixon's present troubles had been caused by a "vendetta" waged by Mr. Nixon's political enemies.

The getaway from Pimlico today was just about as fast as the stretch rally displayed by Little Current in winning the Preakness yesterday. Only one trainer of prominence, Stan (Skip) Shapoff, who handles the activities of Hudson County, was on hand in the barn area early this morning.
Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing won the French presidential election today, turning back the most effective challenge yet made by the left here.

The explosion of a nuclear device by India raises another monument to human folly. Indian leaders may pride themselves on a scientific and technological achievement so far equalled by only five other nations. The more appropriate reaction would be one of despair that such great talent and resources have been squandered on the vanity of power, while 600 million Indians slip deeper into poverty.

Three persons were injured by a car bomb that exploded in a parking lot at London's Heathrow airport today. The automobile, said by the police to have been packed with at least 100 pounds of explosives, was left in the multistory garage at one of the airport's three terminals.

Lou Piniella, the hero of New York's 6-2 victory over Milwaukee in the first game of their double-header today didn't quite feel like a hero after the second game. The Yankees lost that one, 3-1, to split the four-game series with the Brewers.

SOMERS, Conn. - Psychologists at the state's maximum security prison here are using electric shock and other experimental "behavior modification" techniques in an attempt to cure convicted child molesters. Governor Byrne today formally proposed a state income tax for New Jersey, saying that it would enable the state to underwrite a substantial share of local school costs and thereby reduce local property taxes in the state by an average of approximately 25 per cent.

President Nixon offered today to compromise on a national health insurance program in order to enhance prospects for passage of national health legislation this year.

The city's Consumer Affairs Department charged yesterday that the Ryder Technical School was "riddled with deceit and misrepresentation", and that it lied to prospective students about job opportunities and placement services.

The Federal Power Commission reported today that electric utilities will have more generating capacity this summer but-because of shortages of coal, oil and natural gas-may e unable to deliver all the power consumers want.

Town police officials and the Essex County Prosecutor's office today charged Sidney Selip, the owner of the house in which a mother and two daughters were found dead after an explosion on May 8, with three counts of murder in connection with the case. Rear of home at 109 Willow Street in Bloomfield where police found three bodies after explosion and fire.
President Nixon returned last night from a long weekend at his Florida retreat reportedly at peace with himself and with his decision to reject all pressures for his resignation.

Carter L. Burgess, chairman of Flagship International Inc., has been designated chairman of the board of directors of the Foreign Policy Association.
Despite increased freshman applications this spring, state and land-grant universities expect a slight decline in first-year enrollments next fall.

Patricia Hearst said she had nothing to do with her own kidnapping but later joined hey abductors because of disatisfaction with her father's $2million food program to free her, The Los Angeles Times said today.
With political talks between the Salgon Government and the Vietcong halted, the four-nation International Commission of Control and Supervision is beginning to show signs of severe strain.

The settlement was reached in a discrimination complaint brought against the state police by Janie Bulaga, 26 years old, of Hightstown, and Sharon Strickland, 22, of East Orange.

An Urban Academy-said to be the first municipally sponsored training institution in the country for city employes and executives-will be established jointly by the city and The City University, Mayor Beame announced yesterday.

The quiet ferment set off in Spain by the upheaval in neighboring Portugal confronts the Eranco regime with its most serious dilemma since World War II. A few liberal Cabinet ministers reportedly are pressing for urgent reforms, arguing that keeping the country's authoritarian system under tight lid invites an explosion of the kind that wrecked the Portuguese dictatorship.
The House Ways and Means Committee has tentatively agreed to increase the amount of medical expenses a taxpayer must have before medical deductions can be claimed.

The president of a Manhattan trucking company was indicted yesterday on charges that he had bribed two police officers to fix $30,000 worth of parking violation judgments, Maurice H. Nadjari, tht special state prosecutor, announced.

"I decided in a meeting with my agent this morning to give the car to our coach," said Bernie Parent, the Philadelphia Flyers' goalie, before turning over the new Javelin he won as most valuable' player in the Stanley Cup playoffs to Fred Shero. "It was a team effort and Fred Shero was responsible for us winning the Stanley Cup."

Britain has offered a new draft for a declaration of principles for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that, according to diplomatic sources here, makes no references to a separate European identity in the alliance.

A painting by Mark Rothko sold on May 21, 1970, by executors of his estate to Marlborough Gallery for approximately $18,000 was sold six months later for $180,000 to Mrs. Paul Mellon, it was shown yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

After years of experiments and delayed starts, pay-television - a medium that would deliver programs to subscribers for a fee-is beginning to make its way across the country. And the word of its coming is being circulated not by the pay-TV entrepreneurs themselves, but by their natural enemies, commercial broadcasters. As might be expected the word is being promulgated in the form of an alarm.

, Controller of the Currency, said today that his agency had completed a "truncated" examination begun early last week to evaluate the assets of the Franklin National Bank and that "my position is the same as before-it is a solvent bank."

Sixty-two Palestinian guerrillas who were arrested in Jordan while trying to enter Is. raeli territory during the October war arrived here today.

An indefinite commitment to a mental. hospital was ordered for 26-year-old Peter Sydney Ball, alias Ian Ball, after he entered a plea of guilty in London's Old Bailey to the attempted kidnapping of Princess Anne and related charges.

Argentina, tuning up for' World Cup soccer competition, tied England, 2-2, tonight on a penalty shot late in the second half before 68,000 spectators.

For many women, fashion change doesn't happen over night. After they see some radically new styles in the stores for a while, or on their friends, they begin to consider wearing them themselves. Or at least trying them on.

G. Gordon Liddy, serving heavy prison terms for the Watergate break-in, succeeded today in persuading a judge to lift a portion of a sentence that Mr. Liddy considered illegal and felt he could not fulfill.
New York's best-publicized lady-in-waiting, Frances, the pregnant whale, has become ill in her tank at the Aquarium at Conev Island.

Mayor Beame is reported planning to phase out the city's business with the Rand Institute, offshoot of a California "think tank" that former Mayor Lindsay commissioned to analyze a broad range of urban problems and help streamline the city's bureaucratic structure.

Christian Buchheit, the only nonartist who was made an honorary member of the Art Students League, which he served as building superintendent from 1905 to his retirement in 1971, died Tuesday St. Clare's Hospital, Denville, N. J. He was 89 years old and lived at 69-25 Manse Street, Forest Hills, Queens.
Prof. Irmgard Flugge-Lotz, the first woman to hold a full professorship in engineering at Stanford University, died yesterday in Stanford Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. She was 70 years old.

Space scientists will try early next month to correct the faulty orbit of a weather satellite, the project manager said yesterday, adding, "We expect to be right on the money."

Gov. George C. Wallace has been running far ahead of President Nixon and Senator George McGovern in a Presidential preference poll conducted by Mr. Wallace's campaign coordinators, his staff said yesterrday.

In what he calls his private Thought Book, the 1972 Olympic 400-meter champion once wrote, "I'll die before I can really live." But even the obituary of Vincent Matthews will be a reminder not so much that he won the gold medal but that he slouched on the victory stand. In the hours and days that followed, his explanations were minimal. He even told his mother that he "just didn't feel like" standing at attention.

It appears that Gordie Howe, who came out of retirement at the age of 45, will be voted the World Hockey Association's most valuable player and his 18year-old son, Mark, will be the league's rookie of the year.
Stockholders of both Foote, Cone Belding and Grey Advertising heard demands at their annual meetings yesterday that more advertising be placed in black newspapers.
New York's best-publicized lady-in-waiting, Frances, the pregnant whale, has become ill in her tank at the Aquarium at Coney Island.
A Westchester bus company specializing in the transportation of handicapped children was the target last night of vandals who slashed tires and broke windows on most of its 75 vehicles.
His Baltimore Teammares call Paul Blair "Motor-mouth" because he talks so much. He also swings a pretty good baseball bat.
The Justice Department filed a proposed consent judgment yesterday in which 11 concrete block producers in the Chicago area would be prohibited from conspiring to fix prices or allocate customers.

That stark question is posed by political economist Robert Heilbroner in a short new book, "An Inquiry Into the HUman Prospect," and his answer troubles some of the people in guiltedged Washington who consider themselves, in Heilbroner's phrase, "the sentries of our society."

Kathleen Eaton Cannell, who covered European fashions from Paris for The New York Times from 1931 to 1941 and in recent years had contributed ballet reviews to The Christian Science Monitor, died Sunday in Boston. She was 82 years old.

It was 11 A.M., Monday, May 6, a gray, windy, raw-cold morning. Willy Brandt had just finished telling those of his staff who did not already know it that this would be his last day as Chancellor of West Germany.

Miles, retired executive .director and chief curator of the American Numismatic Association, died of cancer Tuesday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 70 years Old and lived on East Hudson Road in Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y.

The question of the legality of the May 18 qualifying for the Indianapolis 500 auto race was unresolved after a hearing today in Marion County Superior Court. Judge Frank A. Symmes Jr. recessed the case until tomorrow morning.

The Cosmos, who played three soccer games at home and had lost all three, came to Philadelphia to play the Atoms tonight, and played well. The problem was the Atoms played better and defeated the New Yorkers, 1-0, before 10,117 fans.

A Puerto Rican jockey, Johnny Belmonte, brother of Eddie Belmonte, was charged today with first-degree murder in the fatal shooting of his wife late yesterday in front of the couple's suburban Carolina home. Belmonte was released on $13,500 bail.
President Nixon informed the House Judiciary Committee today that he would refuse to comply with two subpoenas for additional Watergate tapes and documents and would do the same on future demands.

Officials at the United States Naval Academy are investigatihg possible cheating incidents involving an unknown number of midshipmen, the academy's superintendent, Vice Adm. William P. Mack, confirmed today.

The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 220.6 from 224.8 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 164.0 on May 22. 1973.

Richard H. Kuh, the Manhattan District Attorney, disclosed yesterday that he had intervened to help have set aside a $10,000 judgment against two Upper West Side merchants, one of whom mistakenly identified a former Columbia College student as an armed robber three years ago.

Two former Portuguese leaders-the gray-haired men at right--Cesar Moreira Baptista, Interior Minister, and Joaquim da Silva Cunha, Defense Minister, being transferred from a van to a prison near Lisbon yesterday.

Andrew D. Lyons was found guilty yesterday of voluntary manslaughter after a jury of eight men 'and four women had deliberated for 14 hours. The case generated considerable interest because the heart of Samuel M. Allen Jr. the man shot by Mr. Lyons last Sept. 10 had been removed for use in a transplant operation while it was still beating with the assistance of artificial life-suport systems.

The Baroque music marathon that is being run this week at Carnegie Recital Hall reached the half-way mark on Wednesday night. The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.039-billion up 13 per cent from the year-earlier $923-million. Total retail store sales were about $10.341-billion up 6 per cent from last year's $9.752-billion.
The New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld the state's legislative reapportionment plan, contending that partisan considernations were valid in carving the new districts.

Two Bronx junior-high-school deans who have been accused of beating students with a thick wooden paddle, leather belts and their fists to punish them for misbehaving, have been restored, without explanation, to their posts at the school by the district superintendent.

President Nixon told a visiting Soviet group today that his plans were moving ahead for a meeting in Moscow with Leonid I. 'Brezhnev, the Communist party chief, probably at the end of, June.

Secretary of State Kissinger, after another day of negotiations in Syria and Israel, said early this morning that he had made "good progress" toward removing a principal obstacle to the conclusion of a SyrianIsraeli troop - disengagement agreement.

Four of the country's largest retailers - Federated Department Stores, Inc., R. H. Macy Co., Inc., the W. T. Grant Company and the Allied Stores Corporation - reported fiscal quarter results yesterday that indicated a mixed pattern of consumer buying and pressure on earnings.

Business loans at major New York City banks declined $249-million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This was the largest decrease on business lending since January.
Eddie Dibbs of the United States, who is seeded sixth, whipped Juergen Pohmann of West Germany, 4-6, 6-0, 6-1, today and advanced into the quarterfinals of the German International tennis tournament.

Premier Chou En-lai today met Pierre Sudreau, a French member of Parliament, at a time when the. Premier has considerably reduced his activities because of fatigue.

Sanford K. Bronstein, former president of a Miami hospital that once drew praise from President Nixon, has been charged with 64 criminal counts in connection with the alleged forging of checks totaling $525,000.
The Internal Revenue Service has declined to supply the House Judiciary Committee with information on President Nixon's tax returns for its impeachment inquiry, an I.R.S. spokesman said tonight.

The Association of American Railroads reported today freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17.2 billion ton-miles, 0.2 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago.

A suit charging the Board of Education here with discriminaing against blacks and Puerto Ricans in its hiring of teachers was filed yesterday in Federal Court by a group of plaintiffs seeking abolition of the present teachers' examinations.

Yuen Su Wong, editor and Chinese Ambassador to Mexico from 1932 to 1937, died Monday at Mercy Hospital in Sacramento, Calif. His age was 86, and he lived in Sacramento.

Secretary of State Kissinger, after another day of negotiations in Syria and Israel, said early this morning that he had made "good progress" toward removing a principal obstacle to the conclusion of a SyrianIsraeli troop - disengagement agreement.

United States auto makers reported today that new car sales in midMay were 13.9 per cent less than a year ago, better than any other 10-day selling period of 1974, a year in which the auto market is down more than 25 per cent.

Federal aid to medical education has been earmarked for drastic cuts, spelled out in a recent report by Henry E. Simmons, Deputy Assistant Secretary for Health. A quartermaster "who just likes to see the guys pass" supplied examination answers to one-sixth of the United States Naval Academy's sophomore class on Tuesday, a faculty source said today.
A measure calling for the impositior of a 5 per cent surcharge or the winners' pool at all offtrack betting parlors in the state has been signed into law Governor Wilson's office an nounced today
The homosexual-rights bill, defeated in the City Council on Thursday by 22 to 19, will be resubmitted next week, but its co-sponsors will not press for action until. after the November election.

Soaring exports pulled the United States balance of trade back into surplus in April despite another big jump in the dollar value of oil imports, the Commerce Department reported today.

The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that its RCA Electronic Components division would raise prices by an average of 5 per cent on the industrial tubes and products it sells to original-equipment makers in the industrial, communications, aerospace and military markets.

" Will we yield to the lesser impulses or will we affirm the decency and tolerance and justice which is so much a part of the very best of what we are and stand for," Councilman Carter Burden asked the other evening as the City Council prepared to vote on a long-delayed bill to ban discrimination against homosexuals in jobs and housing.

The secretary of the Yugoslav Communist party said today that party officials had given no consideration to picking an eventual successor to President Tito, and that the subject of succession would not arise during the party's 10th Corngress opening next Monday.

Citing recent episodes of serious occupationally caused illnesses, Senator Robert Taft Jr. asked the General Accounting Office Thursday to review the effectiveness of the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health, the Federal research agency that oversees the health of the nation's work force.
Rev. Frarcois Jentel, the French priest condemned to 19 years in prison for encouraging Brazilian peasants to revolt against large' landholders, ,wa freed last night, his lawyer declared today.

In a surprise development, Prof: David G. Trager was sworn in last night as United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York. The oath of office was administered by the chief Federal judge for the district, Jacob Mishler, in a ceremony conducted in his chambers in the United States Court house in Brooklyn.
Bill Rea was almost as excited today about his first major achievement as a dental student as he was about his latest long jump title in the I.C.4-A. outdoor track and field champlonships.

Tight surveillance is being maintained along both sides of the Mexican border against the possibility that Patricia Hearst and two fugitive companions of the self-styled Symbionese Liberation Army may try to reach a hideout in the mountains of Baja California.

Judge Fred Nichol of Federal District Court denied today a defense motion to suppress admission of evidence, including four Molotov cocktails, in the trial of Russell Means and Dennis Banks, leaders of the Indian occupation of Wounded Knee, S. D. The evidence was obtained in a search of an automobile at a Government roadblock outside Wounded Knee on March 6, 1973.

ROME--Some young scholars commute to the Vatican to pore over old manuscripts. Others study Renaissance villas all over Italy or ancient electoral graffiti in Pompeii. A sculptor is working on bronze doors for the Episcopal Church here and a 21-year-old artist from the Bronx is painting abstracts.

Penthouse, which describes itself as a "sophisticated entertainment magazine for men," filed a $40-million suit in Federal Court here yesterday against Playboy Enterprises, Inc., for allegedly disseminating "false and fraudulent information" about Penthouse's circulation among advertisers and ad agencies.

The'Rev. Stephen A. Cuddeback, who retired in 1971 as pastor of the Roman Catholic Cure of Ars Church, Merrick, L. I., died Thursday of a heart attack in the rectory. He was 74 years old.

Alvin D. Stone Jr., cable editor in the New York bureau of Stars and Stripes, died yesterday of cancer. He was 62 years old. Mr. Stone joined the paper in 1967 after a career in public relations, advertising and newspapers.

Premier Sanya Dharmasakti, who resigned with his Cabinet three days ago, today accepted a parliamentary appeal to return to office, thus ending the first major leadership crisis of Thailand's young civilian order.
President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he was opening the way for the restoration of the writ of habeas corpus to prevent summary arrest and detention.

The National Advertising Review Board is looking for a new chairman. The unexpected search began yesterday with the surprise announcement that Edwin D. Etherington was resigning for personal reasons after the Spring board meeting on June 5.

Under the general title of "Metal Meditations," Philip Corner, the composer-and performer, has been offering a series of events this week at the Kitchen. From Tuesday through yesterday in the afternoons, his collection of "resonant metal objects and calligraphic scores" was on display.

The Israeli Cabinet today gave its general endorsement to Secretary of State Kissinger's corn. promise plan, which he hopes will win Syria's approval tomorrow and lead to rapid completion of a troop-separation agreement on the Golan Heights.

Many Connecticut schools steer students into certain courses on the basis of their sex, according to a survey by the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union. Of the 112 responses received from school superintendents, 11 said they did discriminate by prohibiting girls from taking industrial-arts courses and boys from taking homemaking courses, according to the survey. Only when a "student is unusually persistent and is vigorously backed by parents, do some schools make exceptions," the survey said.

Our Royal Ballet revels now are ended, and the company has left for a two-week stand at the Kennedy Center in Washington. By and large this has been the British troupe's most successful New York visit, if not from the creative point of view, at least from the sheer dance power of the company.

The Supreme Court, and particularly its Chief Justice, face difficult and politically explosive decisions in the request by the Watergate special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, that the Court take immediate jurisdiction of the dispute over President Nixon's refusal to surrender 64 White House tapes.
PLEASANTVILLE, N. J. For the first time since the columned, three-story brick Plesantville High School was erected 40 years ago, policemen with guns and tear gas are patrolling its corridors.

The nation's six major multinational oil companies, which had total net profits of $6.7billion in 1973, have reported that they paid worldwide taxes of $25.4-billion on their operations-but they paid only $642million in domestic Federal income taxes. The companies' gross revenues totaled nearly $50-billion for the year.

" Hear ye, hear ye, here ye--all persons having business before this... United States Court of Appeals for the Second Judicial Circuit draw near, give your attention and ve shall be heard." Chief Judge Irving R. Kaufman of U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Judicial Circuit.

Tennis was fighting dragons over the weekend--while from Rome, where the Italians shut the door on Jimmy Connors, to New York's Central Park, where hundreds of frustrated players almost stormed the Arsenal building in protest against court coneditions.
Moe Levine, a partner in the law firm of Shayne, Dachs Moe Levine, of Mineola, L. I., died Sunday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 68 years old and had homes there and at 100 Clinton Avenue, Mineola.

Fast food places, though welcome on open highways, are a mixed blessing on New York's residential streets. The operating premise of these establishments is high traffic and fast turnover on a prefabricated food product. The chief virtues of fast food are that it is cheap and convenient. Its takeout format may attract as many as 1,500 transient customers during a noon lunch hour.
Paul Berl, who headed the opera workshop of the Mannes College of Music, died Sunday in New York Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 250 West 85th Street.

Jacques Chirac, the 41-year-old Minister of the Interior, was named Premier of France today. The announcement was made a few hours after the inauguration of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing. Jacques Chirac after being appointed Premier yesterday President Valery Giscard d'Estaing greets well-wishers

The seventh GoldwaterMarshall invitational tournament was won this year by International Master Andrew Soltis, who topped the 10man field with a 6-3 score. Soltis's brew of strong opening play and alert middle-game tactics enabled him to run effortlessly through the event, held at the Marshall Chess Club in New York and sponsored by its president G. Walter Goldwater.

A woman who had been fatally shot told Queens police officers just before she died last night that she had shot and killed the man who had wounded her, following an argument in the man's apartment at 150-29 122d Avenue, Jamaica.
John Vanneck, financier, industrialist and sportsman, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Parsonage Point, Rye, N. Y. He was 68 years old.

The districts of Representative John J. Rooney, dean of the New York congressional delegation, and State Senator Carol Bellamy, one of only three women in the State Senate, would be dismembered in a special reapportionment scheduled for approval at a special session of the Legislature tomorrow.

Despite registering a 6-0 victory over San Diego, the short and otherwise happy day of Ken Brett, a Pirates' left-hand pitcher, was irreparably spoiled by Fred Kendall of the Padres, in the first game of a Memorial Day double-header yesterday before a crowd of 16,000 at the Three Rivers Stadium in Pittsburgh. The Pirates' Ken Brett pitching against the Padres yesterday in Pittsburgh. He retired the first 24 batters.

A Navy pilot safely ejected today before his A-4 jet aircraft th crashed into the sea after being accidentally hit by an inert missile fired by an A-7 Corsair jet attack aircraft off the coast of Jacksonville, Fla., Atlantic Fleet headquarters reported.

Rapid advances in weapons technology, demonstrated in the 1973 Middle East war, are being incorporated into a major modernization program of the United States land forces. A two-man crew test firing a TOW antitank missile at -Camp Roberts, Calif. The acronyn stands for tubelaunched, optically-tracked and wire-guided.

Depending on whom you listen to-the Federal Government or the state government-it either was or wasn't Memorial Day here today. It was Memorial Day on the Federal calendar, and many businesses shut for the occasion.

The Soviet Union today mounted a diplomatic and propaganda offensive to bolster its influence among the Arab states. The Kremlin sent Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to Syria and Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, the Defense Minister, to Algeria.

Miss Donna Dean Carter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Carter of Sudbury, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Gagarin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew P. Gagarin of Litchfield, Conn. The Rev. Carl R. Scovel performed the Unitarian ceremony in the First Parish Church in Sudbury.
Bep Guidolin, coach of the Boston Bruins for the last 18 months, resigned today after failing to reach a contract agreement with the National Hockey League club.

Janus, keep comedians going Freddie Prinze. The Puerto Ricans have a voice.
Kevin Finnegan of Britain scored a close, unanimous decision over Jean-Claude Bouttier of France tonight to win the European middleweight boxing championship at Roland Garros Stadiuum.

Secretary or the Treasury William E. Simon says the Government should aim toward a balanced budget in 1976 as a key to controlling the nation's "totally unacceptable" inflation rate - 11.5 per cent in the first quarter.
Scotland Yard has begun taking over responsibility for security at London's Heathrow Airport, nicknamed "Thiefrow" because of a high rate of pilferage and other crime there.

In St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, 371 Avenue of the Americas, yesterday afternoon, Miss Anne Elizabeth Kelly and Richard S. Skolnik, who are with the actuarial department of the Royal-Globe Insurance Companies here, were married by the Rev. Robert V. Lott.

Leigh Buck of Baltimore scored six goals as the United States First Team defeated the United States Reserves, 13-7, as the three-day women's national lacrosse tournament ended today at Germantown Academy.

It is, according to one woman who knows all about such things, "this week's status symbol." The woman in question is, however, usually two or three months ahead of ordinary mortals, so it is very likely that the gold chain she was describing will be with us for some time.

In 1966 Tennessee Williams's "Slapstick Tragedy"- two odd one-act plays "The Mutilated" and "The Gnadiges Fraulein" - survived only one week on Broadway. The second half of that double bill has now been resurrected tinder the title "The Latter Days of a Celebrated Soubrette."

Two of the leading black elected officials of New York City today called on the Justice Department to reject the proposed new, Congressional and legislative district lines on the ground that, although they favor minorities on paper, they are likely to hinder-not enhance--minority representation.

Large writedowns by the Teleprompter Corporation last year resulted in a net loss of $30-million, in contrast with net earnings in 1972 of $12.6million, or 7 cents a share. The company's report for 1973 was delayed partly because of drastic changes in the direction of the company, which has had a realignment of officers last fall.

Bobby Fernandez was giving his all last September for Morris Hills High School as a defensive back on the football team when tragedy struck. Now, Morris Hills has done something to give it all back to Bobby.

Howard Burdwood Jr., president of the New England Homing Pigeon Combine, says those scarlet birds dropping out of southern Maine skies may have "simply run out of gas."

In a far-reaching decision, State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts yesterday found that the Uniformed Fire fighters Association, and by extension the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, could be prosecuted under the state's criminal statutes for any strike that plated the city's residents in "imminent peril." Richard J. Vizzini, head of the Uniformed Firefighters Association.
Government censors have moved against the independent Brazilian press with renewed vigor after a brief relaxation of controls.

The New York Sets got into woman trouble again last night, and it cost them a World Team Tennis match with the Los Angeles Strings, the Pacific Division leaders.

The body of Edward Diggles of 24 Derry Gally Circle, who disappeared early last Friday evening as he was finishing his newspaper-delivery route here, was found floating this afternoqn in Rickabear Lake, about two miles south of this borough.
The great Italian team won the world team championship here this afternoon, its 15th victory since 1957, but only after the American Aces gave them a considerable fright.

PARIS--The old Byzantine game in which observers measure the relative importance of Soviet leaders by respective positions of their photographs on public display or their listing in official state communiques is kindergarten stuff when compared with analysis of similar formal hints in China.

Sanya Dharmasakti was named to succeed himself as Premier today in a royal decree, ending seven days of political crisis. The Premier, who resigned last Wednesday and agreed with reluctance to return to office at the urging of politicians and the public, said he had not completed his new cabinet.

F. Lyle Lodwick, a copywright expert and member of the Institute of Scientific Information in Philadelphia, died Saturday while on a visit to Washington. He was 52 years old and lived in Voorhees, N. J.

Lawyers for the House Judiciary Committee are drafting a letter warning President Nixon that his refusal to honor impeachment inquiry subpoenas risks the eventual conclusion that the President is withholding incriminating evidence.
Dorothy Donegan, who used to roll out the boogie-woogie at the Embers 10 and 15 years ago, is back in town after a long absence, this time at Jimmy Weston's, 131 East 54th Street.
The Reds gained another measure of revenge tonight for the embarrassment they suffered when the Mets eliminated them in last season's playoff series for the National League crown.

The Nastase of Rumania defeated Martin Mulligan of Italy, 6-4, 5-7, 6-2, today and Bjorn Borg of Sweden beat France's Patrice Dominguez, 6-2, 7-5, in first-round play, at the 31st Italian open tennis tournament.

Willy Brandt, who resigned as Chancellor of West Germany after an espionage scandal three weeks ago, returned to pitch in for his party in a crucial state election campaign here this week, and the crowd loved it.

Gov. Dale Bumpers overwhelmingly defeated Senator J. W. Fulbright in his bid for nomination to a sixth term in today's Democratic primary. Early yesterday morning, a man accompanied a California architect to his room at the Plaza Hotel, then - waving a double-edge razor blade-stole $2,000 and some jewelry from the architect and a second man who was also staying in the room, tied up the two men and escaped, dressed in the architect's $450 butterscotchcolored suit.

With the imminent departure of Paul A. Volcker from his post as Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, the Nixon Administration loses the last of its economic strong men-not counting Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who (though a Nixon appointee) cherishes the Fed's vaunted independence.

Kenneth Patton, who was tile city's Economic Development Administrator, bought a dachshund puppy not long ago, and one day last week his son took the dog for a walk in Prospect Park. When he did, he took the leash off the puppy, whose name was Charlie, and allowed him to run with some other dogs.

Three hundred college scholarships worth $4,000 each were presented last night by the United Federation of Teachers to graduating seniors representing every one of the city's 94 public high schools.
Jack Anderson, the columnist, reported todaythat Charles G. Rebozo, President Nixon's close friend, paid for nearly $12, 000 in improvements at the President's house in Key Biscayne, Fla., in 1969.

The partner of Thomas Shea, the police officer who is accused of murder in the fatal shooting of a 10-year-old black boy in a lot in Jamaica, Queens, in April, 1973, testified in Queens Criminal Court yesterday that the boy's stepfather, Add Armstead, had fired at him with a gun Mr. Armstead had taken from the totally wounded boy.
Howard J. Samuels proposed yesterday the establishment of an office of special state consumer affairs prosecutor with broad powers to initiate civil and criminal actions on behalf of consumers.
Gen. Charles de Gaulle reached into the French Embassy in Bonn to tap an obscure diplomat, Maurice Couve de Murville, as his Foreign Minister. "Bright, articulate, good at his job"
The Federation of Musicians said yesterday it had reached a tentative contract agreement with the three major net works, temporarily ending the union's 3 1/2-week strike.

The Rev. Herbert Musurillo, an authority on the writings of early Roman Catholic Church fathers and professor of classics at Fordham University since 1963, died Monday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N. Y., of injuries suffered in a one-car accident last Wednesday on the Bronx River Parkway. He was 56 years old. The Rev. Herbert Musurillo
At least 23 persons drowned in California during the long Memorial day weekend, nine of them in a 25-mile stretch of the treacherous Kern River near Johnsondale.

The Pentagon wants 450 more beagle pups but says they will not be used to test nerve gas. The dogs will be used for such programs as "detecting of toxicity in products of demilitarized chemical munitions, detecting toxicity in normal munitions damaged by binary compounds to be used in developing vaccines for chemical agents," a Pentagon spokesman said today.

The Supreme Court today agreed to review a court decision allowing radio and television stations to broadcast the winning numbers in the New Jersey state lottery.
Jury selection began today in the bribery-conspiracy trial of Joseph M. McCrane Jr., the former New Jersey State Treasurer accused of using $6-million in treasury funds to influence a bank.

Eugene T. Gunn, president of Gene T. Gunn Company, an insurance and real-estate brokerage concern here, died of a ?eart attack yesterday in New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 25 Interlaken Drive, Eastcheser N.Y.

Delicate negotiations intended to revive the New York City rent-control issue for the special legislative session, recessed inconclusively this evening with some participants saying success was likely but others terming a chance of success only "fifty-fifty."

Former United States Senator Wayne Morse won a four-way primary race for the Democratic senatorial nomination today. With 1,060 of Oregon's 2,514 precincts reporting, unofficial returns gave Mr. Morse 44,146 votes, or 50.3 per cent, to 33,910, or 38.7 per cent for Jason Boe, the State Senate president.

Heiry Aaron of Atlanta, in hi the career home-run leader, smacked his 722d regular season homer in the 10th inning last night to give the Braves a 2-1 victory over the visiting Philadelphia Phillies and now needs only one more to pass Babe Ruth.

The opposition leader, Bill Snedden, today conceded defeat to the governing Labor party in Austtraila's May 18 general election. Mr. Snedden said the task of forming a new administration would fall to the Labor party of Prime Minister Gough Whitlam.
President Nixon asked Congress today to vote an additional $10-million for the Health, Education and Welfare Department budget this year for spending on social and rehabilitation services.

Five hundred town and county officials and friends attended a funeral service in Montclair yesterday for Ambrose R. During, treasurer of Montclair, who was shot to death Friday night in an apparent robbery.

Francis Farrell, owner of the Brotherhood Winery in Washingtonville, N. Y., which was founded in 1839 and claims to be the oldest in the United States, died Monday at his home in Washingtonville. He was 69 years old.

Northern Ireland's coalition government of moderate Protestants and Roman Catholics collapsed, brought down by the action of Protestant extremists whose general strike crippled the economy and gained wide public support. Another period of direct British rule is expected. [1:8.]

' A Westchester man who was portrayed as depressed and unable to accept the fact of his year-old divorce was accused yesterday of murdering his wife's friend, a 30-year-old woman, in his former Chappacqua, N. Y., home.
The Atlantic County Sheriff said today he believed that casino gambling in this faded resort city would increase the pressure on his already crowded jail.

The House Rules Committee has postponed for a week a showdown over allowing a vote on the floor on a proposal to abolish the oil depletion allowance. Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, chairman of the Ways and Means Committtee, asked fo the delay.

The State Liquor Authority is looking into charges by a Nassau County man that he wash'held by two bouncers at Jimmy's restaurant here and punched by Sid Davidoff, one of the owners and a former administrative assistant to Mayor John V. Lindsay.
A National Labor Relations Board trial judge has ruled that the American Motors Corporation must reinstate two workers he said had been dismissed because of union activities.

The Metropolitan Opera led with one of its trump cards in beginning its June Festival Monday night with "Les Contes d'Hoffmann." Few productions of recent seasons have worked so well on so many levels as this rethinking of the Offenbach score by Richard Bonynge, the night's conductor.
The Supreme Court upheld an Interstate Commerce Com. mission requirement today that railroads pay additional per diem charges for freight cars belonging to other lines.

The message between the lines of President Nixon's interim economic report to Congress today was that the Government has no quick or painless cure for inflation and that the public had News better brace itself Analysis for a rough period of persistent inflation and a determined squeeze on nondefense spending.

For more than a year, scientists have been producing an infection-fighting antibody in a factory of living cells growing in a laboratory. So far, the scientists have done this with one kind of animal cells that produce one specific kind of antibody.

Frank Lloyd. the most powerful single self-made figure in the international art word since World War II, will take the stand in Surrogate's Court tomorrow, bringing to a climax a suit by 22-year-old Kate Rothko to divest him of 800 paintings left by her father, Mark, when he died by suicide Feb. 21, 1970.

Vic Hadfield, the Rangers' captain and once Coach Emile Francis's pet player, was traded before yesterday's midnight deadline forNick Beverley, a journeyman defenseman on the Pittsburgh Penguins.
A 2-year-old library researcher for the Dell Publishing Company was found apparently strangled yesterday in her second-floor rear apartment at 488-East 74th Street.
