Witnesses have given the police a description of a man who shot to death a wealthy widow during an attempted robbery at her apartment in an exclusive apartment house on Sunday in East Orange. The police said they were looking for a black man, 6 feet tall, and weighing about 180 pounds, who had been seen wearing a dark windbreaker, a blue shirt with white stripes, dark pants and black shoes.

When, some 200 years ago, that slightly smelly real estate speculator Daniel Boone slashed his way to the top of Cumberland Gap, he saw blanketed before him what was probably the largest territorial commons in the history of North America.

Mrs. Lucile Becker Ogsbury, a prominent New York and Vermont golfer and the wife of James B. Ogsbury, a retired radio and television station owner and executive, died of a stroke Monday in a hospital in Waynesboro. Va. She was 58 years old and lived in Waynesboro.

The Petroleum Association of Japan, 12 oil companies and 17 senior oil executives were indicted here today on charges of conspiracy to fix prices and to control refinery production during 11973. Hirotaka Mitsuda, chairman of Petroleum Association of Japan, responding at a news conference to the government indictments of oil company executives.

Mrs. Andrew Sage of Piping Rock led the opening round with a five-overpar 77 today in the 42d annual Women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hole medal championship over the 5,480-yard course at The Creek Club.

The chances of holding this year's City Council election have been put in jeopardy by a delay in supplying Washington with racial statistics on the districts, a lawyer for the NAACP-Legal Defense and Edunational Fund said yesterday.

Announcing his candidacy for re-election yesterday, Francis W. Sargent, the Republican Governor of Massachusetts, said he would be quite happy to have Vice President Ford campaign for him, but as for President Nixon, "I prefer that he didn't." Cyrus R. Vance

A recent edition of this newspaper carried a threequarter-page advertisement billed as a "Nonpartisan Letter to the American People" from Otto E. Passman, a veteran Congressman from Louisiana. Essentially, Mr. Passman's message was that Richard Nixon has been a great President and that he is being attacked unfairly for precisely that reason.

Kenny Noe is hardly apprehensive about a split of the Belmont Stakes, a possihihty that has been speculated on because of the disappointing showing of some highly regarded 3-year-olds in recent races.

Gordie Howe, 46 years old, was voted the World Hockey Association's most valuable player for the 1973-74 season, the league president, Dennis Murphy, announced tonight. Howe, who finished third in regular-season scoring with 31 goals and 69 assists, drew 135 points in the voting, 49 more than Mike Walton of the Minnesota Fighting Saints, who won the scoring title.

The Dalkon Shield, a widely prescribed type of intrauterine contraceptive device (IUD), has been implicated by its manufacturer in the deaths of four women who became pregnant while wearing the device and suffered septic spontaneous abortions in the second threemonth period of pregnancy. Thirty-two other women suffered similar septic abortions, but did not die.

An explosion in the reading room of the John F. Kennedy American Center here injured three Lebanese today. None of the three, two women and a man, was seriously injured, according to the United States Embassy.

Hayden Stone, Inc., and Shearson, Hammill Co., Inc., two of Wall Street's bigger investment banking and brokerage houses, confirmed persistent rumors yesterday that they were talking merger. President Nixon is making a persistent, determined effort to delay the House impeachment inquiry and the special prosecutor's multiple investigations. Rightly or wrongly, he believes that time is on his side. He has boldly asserted that he will provide no further evidence to the House Judiciary Committee, no. matter how many subpoenas it may issue.

The collapse of Northern Ireland's five-month-old moderate provisional government is a triumph for the Protestant extremists-and for their temporarily quiescent Catholic counterparts-that spells almost certain tragedy for Ulster.

The body of Edward Diggles of 24 Derry Gaily Circle, who disappeared last Friday as he was finishing his newspaper- delivery route here, was found yesterday in Rickabear Lake, about two miles south of Kinnelon, N.J. An autopsy performed by the medical examiner's staff of Morris County determined that the boy had died of drowning, There was no evidence of foul play, it was disclosed, and death occurred late Friday night.
Prices dipped in quiet trading in the Government, corporate and tax-exempt bond markets yesterday as participants attempted to sift the implications of weekend statements from Washington.
Edward J. Boyd 5th, who had actively sought appointment as United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, will become the No. 3 man in that office, it was announced yesterday.
The head of the All India Railwaymen's Federation was released from prison today as rail services around the nation slowly returhed to normal.

The company scheduled to take over the operation of several bankrupt Northeast railroads probably would run out of money shortly after it began operations, the First National City Bank has charged in court papers filed recently.
The Security Council today approved 14-0 an agreement between Iran and Iraq to end their border dispute and negotiate a comprehensive peace settlement.

GRAND COULEE, Wash.--A small group of wheat farmers here has taken on the Navy, the state of Oregon, the Boeing Corporation, the Portland General Electric Company and the Atomic Energy Commission in a fight to stop the Navy from turning their wheat fields into a bombing range.

REA Express announced yesterday that it was filing for a 10 per cent rate increase on all air express rates, effective June 21. The company provides air freight service to about 22,000 communities in the United States and Canada.

Henry Aaron, Atlanta's career home-run leader smacked his 722nd regular season homer in the 10th inning last night to give the Braves a 2-1 victory over the visiting Philadelphia Phillies and now needs only one more to pass Babe Ruth.

President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers predicted today that the nation's inflation rate, now 12 per cent as measured by the Consumer Price Index, would drop to "the neighborhood of 7 per cent" by the final quarter of this year.
A state appeals court today upheld a law that permits local election officials to place the names of candidates in primary elections on separate lines on the ballot.

The Rev. Billy Graham has called his reading of the transcripts of President Nixon's Watergate conversations "a profoundly disturbing and disappointing experience" but added that, as Mr. Nixon's friend, he had "no intention of forsaking him now."
Joseph P. Conway, president of Joseph P. Conway Associates, a public-relations consulting concern in Garden City, died last night at his home. He was in his mid-50's and lived on Chapel Gate Lane.
The Justice Department meu a proposed consent decree today to terminate a civil antitrust suit against the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's largest commodity exchange.

Mr and Mrs. W. R. Ballard's Arrive Alive captured the intermediate jumper event in a four-horse jumpoff today and the 5 points he earned pulled him into a tie for the lead for the title in the Devon horse show.

In the aftermath of the Watergate scandal in which nearly three dozen lawyers have either admitted or been accused of crimes that include perjury and burglary, the legal profession has intensified its reassessment of the way it governs itself.
The Reds gained another measure of revenge tonight for the embarrassment they suffered when the Mets eliminated them in last season's playoff series for the National League crown.

A dispute involving alleged Air Force retaliation against one of its captains for a study he made of illegal practices in the nation's service academies is being turned over to the General Accounting Office for investigation.

The Babcock Wilcox Company said yesterday it had won a $60-million contract to supply a 1.26-million-kilowatt nuclear steam system and its fuel for the Portland General Electric Company. This would be a duplicate of one the utility bought in 1973. Both units will be located at a site near Arlington, Ore.

Former Assemblyman Joseph A. Fusco, a Bronx Republican, was charged with five other men in a Federal indictment yesterday with stealing Cadillacs and 'delivering them to customers in Florida and Pennsylvania.

The military command for Angola is deeply concerned over growing racial tension in Luanda, the capital, and believes white agitators to be mainly responsible.

Frank W. Hyman, president of Avery Macey International Corporation and a pioneer in the rotogravure printing process in this country, died Monday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 25 East 77th Street.

A high-explosive time bomb hidden in a plastic garbage bag exploded today, killing six persons and injuring 94 at an anti-Fascist rally in this industrial town in northern Italy. By a vote of 49 to 19, the Senate approved today a bill to include a stretch of the New River on the North CarolinaVirginia border among the rivers to be studied by the Department of Interior for inclusion in the Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

William McLemore Richardson Jr., executive vice president of Young Rubicam, Inc., advertising agency, at his retirement in 1971, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. He was 60 years old.

A panel of foreign-affairs scholars advised the United States yesterday to make a searching reappraisal of its relations with other countries.

The Supreme Court today agreed to review a court decision allowing radio and television stations to broadcast the winning numbers in the New Jersey state lottery.

Steve Smith, who has achieved the only 18-foot indoor pole vaults, said yesterday that he felt capable of going 18-6 or 18-7 tonight at Madison Square Garden in the final meet of the International Track Association's second professional season.

Gov. Dale Bumpers defeated Senator J. W. Fulbright in his bid for nomination to a sixth term in today's Democratic primary. With 1,276 of 2,688 precincts reporting, the unofficial tally was: Gov. Buoyed by Canadian oil stocks, the American Stock Exchange market value index rose yesterday although the number of issues showing declines Outnumbered those advancing. In the over-the-counter market, the indexes were down and declines sharply out-numbered advances.

The death of Stewart Alsop is a marked loss for the profession of journalism. For nearly thirty years, he covered politics and foreign affairs with acumen, grace and amiable authority founded upon intensive and conscientious reporting. He may be best known to future readers, however, for his book, "Stay of Execution," the extraordinary memoir in which he tells of his encounter with the rare disease to which he finally succumbed.

In a far-reaching decision, State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts yesterday found that the Uniformed Firefighters Association, and by extension the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, could be prosecuted under the state's criminal statutes for any strike that placed the city's residents in "imminent peril." Richard J. Vizzini, head of the Uniformed Firefighters Association.

Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia said tonight that voters in the midterm election 11 days ago had strongly reaffirmed the program of his Labor party and he declared that the Government would push through controversial legisolation blocked by the old Senate.

Drivers who have been dodging from pillar to post on the alternative route underneath the elevated West Side Highway since the latter was closed for inspection and repair may have a new twist coming this summer: The city's Transportation Administration plans to resurface the rough roadway under the dilapidated elevated structure from the Battery to about 59th Street.

The House Judiciary Committee, completing closed hearings on the Watergate cover-up, appeared divided and uncertain today on whether evidence presented to date had implicated President Nixon in any impeachable misconduct.

The Environmental Protection Agency plans a major revision in the way it reports fuel economy on 1975 cars in the hopes that it will give clearer and more pertinent information to the average car buyer than in the 1974 model year.

The Senate voted 55 to 27 today to approve a United States contribution of $1.5-billion over four years to the World Bank to help the poorest nations. The House rejected the same legislation last January, and whether it will get a second change remains in doubt. Much will depend on whether the Nixon Administration can round up House Republicans to support the bill.

Capital appropriations of the nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers dipped 0.6 per cent in the year's first quarter, the first decline in 11 quarters, the Conference Board reported yesterday in releasing the results of a survey.

The growing controversy over fast-food take-out shops in the city was brought out before the Planning Commission yesterday when a score of neighborhood leaders and their elected officials urged tight curbs to keep such establishments out of local shopping areas.

Kenneth Appleton Ives, president of Kenneth Ives Co., Inc., New York and Connecticut real-estate brokers, died yesterday at his home, 31 East 79th Street. He was 71 years old.
When the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham addressed his hall on the first tee today, he brought a new dimension to golf: A gallery marshal called out, "Kneel, please!"

The first, Wilde's best play and one of the most delicious concoctions in comedy literature, has been accorded a hummingly good production by the New York Arts Theater group at 25 East Fourth Street (228-1338).
Political prisoners continue to disappear in Brazil despite assurances by the new Government headed by Gen. Ernesto Geisel that it will end abuses by the police.

Secretary of State Kissinger's peace mission in the Middle East lends new substance to the Federal Energy Office's assurances that there will be enough gasoline this summer for vacationers, even for drivers of motor homes.

The Cincinnati Reds, seeking to close ground on the highflying Los Angeles Dodgers in the National League West race, continued to thrive at the expense of the New York Mets tonight.

Egyptian officials expressed gratification today over the conclusion of a disengagement agreement between Israel and Syria and paid tribute to the tenacity and diplomatic skills of. Secretary of State Kissinger.

The troubled Pan American World Airways reported yesterday sharply larger deficits for April and the first four months this year, even after taking advantage of huge tax credits and realizing capital gains on sale and property both of the airline and of its subsidiary, the Intercontinental Hotels Corporation.

Representative Angelo D. Roncallo, who was acquitted two weeks ago of Federal charges of conspiracy and extortion, plans to announce next Monday that he will seek a second term in the Third Congressional District.

A suit has been filed in Federal District Court here to force the state to return to Rahway State Prison four inmates transferred to Trenton State Prison following a disturbance at Rahway on April 30.

A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Border Patrol's practice of routinely stopping cars at fixed highway checkpoints was unconstitutional. "As I read it, it means we can't operate the fixed checkpoints," said Assistant United States Attorney Steven Nelson of the ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

The United Mine Workers union said today it had received pledges from 52 national labor unions and four major: church denominations not to buy Duke Power Company stock to support the union's attempt to unionize a Duke-owned coal mine in eastern Kentucky.

Maurice Girodias, the French publisher, said here yesterday that the State Department had ordered his ouster from the United States after having received a complaint that he was publishing a "vile pornographic book" entitled "President Kissinger."

The market for basketball players is apparently tumbling. Player agents, who could virtually name their own terms two years ago, are finding business more difficult to transact. Bob Woolf, players' representative, said, "Both leagues are taking a tougher stand." Mike Storen, A.B.A. commissioner, said, "Before summer is over the agents will be in a panic."

Tonight at 8, on ABC-TV, the ABC News Closeup series enters unusual documentary territory with "The Culture Thieves," an examination of the proposition that "history is being mutilated to supply an ever-increasing and ever more profitable international traffic in antiquities."
San Diego pitching appeared to be just what the doctor ordered for Pittsburgh batters last night as the Firates erupted for 14 hits in a 13-3 rout of the Padres in Three Rivers Stadium.

The Connecticut College American Dance Festival, considered a modern-dance mecca since its founding in 1948, will expand its traditional format of dance presentations by adding performances and residencies by seven experimental theater companies during its season from June 24 through Aug. 3.

The Senate approved an amendment today allowing Americans to buy and sell gold as of Sept. 1, 1974. The action came on a voice vote to the amendment offered by Republicans Peter Dominick of Colorado and James McClure of Idaho to the bill authorizing $1.5billion in funds to the International'Development Association.

A project in which the 25,000-square-mile Hudson River Basin will serve as an environmental laboratory to help determine the future quality of life for 20 million people was announced here yesterday by the Rockefeller Foundation.
Greece'sarmed forces were reportedly placed on alert tonight after Turkey announced that she had sent a research vessel to a disputed area of the Aegean Sea.

Coach John Wooden of the University of California, Los Angeles, flew here today for the third time this year, and signed Provo High's 6-foot11-inch center, Brett Vroman, one of the outstanding schoolboy players in the nation. "This is the first time I've ever made three trips just to sign one player to a letter of intent," Wooden said. "It usually only takes one visit."

It will be girls and boys together when the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association holds its all-group track and field championships at Rutgers University June 8. This year, for the first time, an all-group girls' meet is being held in conjunction with the boys' competition. The girls began their playdown to the finals with sectional meets the May 17 weekend, the boys began with four meets last Saturday.

The House Judiciary Committee, completing closed hearings on the Watergate cover-up, appeared divided and uncertain today on whether evidence presented to date had implicated President Nixon in any impeachable misconduct.
Few periods in the alleged cover-up of the Watergate affair seem to emerge as more crucial than the second half of April, 1973.
Governor Byrne today announced his nomination of former State Senator Ralph DeRose as the New Jersey Commissioner on the bistate Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.
The Department of Defense disclosed today there had been a clash of black and white army enlisted men at Fort Davis in the Panama Canal Zone on May 12 that left five injured.

Italians staged a four-hour general strike this morning following a bombing at an anti-Fascist rally in the northern city of Brescia yesterday. Action followed a bombing an anti-Fascist rally in Brescia Tuesday in which six persons were killed and scores injured.
When the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham addressed his hall on the first tee today, he brought a new dimension to golf: A gallery marshal called out, "Kneel, please!"

Dr. Robert M. Featherstone, chairman of the department of pharmacology at the University of California's San Francisco Medical Center for 16 years, died in Geneva, the university said yesterday. He was 59 years old.

To the Editor: After India's "peaceful" nuclear blast, the international community must wake up more vigorously to prevent India from embarking upon a nuclear weapons program as well as to block further proliferation.
The arrival of striped bass along the coast as far north as Martha's Vineyard prompts one to recall the time when they were not greeted by hordes of anglers.

A Japanese Government oil specialist predicted today that, contrary to some views in the United States and Western Europe, the price of oil would continue to rise in the near future.

A Federal grand jury has begun investigating allegations that employes of Security National Bank were compelled to contribute to a secret political fund when they were promoted, Justice Department sources said yesterday.

Sheriff C. P. Walker of Shelby County arrested seven persons last night-two reporters for The Birmingham News, the county probate judge, the county coroner, who is the sheriff's opponent in a run-off election next Tuesday, and three of his campaign workers-and charged them with conspiracy to murder or maim him.

With some legislators already heading for home in the belief that the session was over, Governor Wilson early this morning suddenly submitted to the Legislature amendments to the recently passed rent control bill that provide some limited new protections for tenants but give landlords new powers as well.
A White House spokesman denied today that President Nixon was employing delaying tactics to thwart impeachment proceedings now under way in Congress.

In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More here yesterday afternoon, Miss Cynthia Tilghman Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Walker of New York, East Hampton, L. I., and Hobe Sound, Fla., was married to Piers Louis Sunderland Diacre of London, son of Kenneth Diacre de Liancourt of Tryall, Jamaica, W. I., and Mrs. C. Richard Hinds-Howell of London. Mrs. Piers L. S. Diacre, was Cynthia T. Walker.

We have at hand what we consider the final word on the subject, and it appears in the work of a friend, Madhur Jaffrey. Madhur Jaffrey, a cookbook writer, sets record straight on Indian cuisine.

A brash Montrealer named Duddy Kravitz is facing his big. test in New York this summer, and a lot of Canadian hopes are riding on his success. Richard Dreyfuss, left, and Jack Warden in "The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz," produced in Canada.
Governor Wilson signed into law today a freedom-of-information bill, which he called "a major step forward, not only in this state but also in the nation."

" Songs" is a display vehicle that Alvin Ailey unabashedly designed for the considerable talents of Dudley.Williams. Mr. Williams dances it as if it is the most important piece. that he is to do, and it is a measure of his artistry that he almost convinces us that it is.

The black 48-story skyscraper opened two and a half years ago between 50th and 51st Street on Broadway as one of the initial projects in a revitalization of the Times Square area was acquired yesterday in a foreclosure proceeding by four banks.

The Board of Estimate yesterday approved a special limited commercial district on 86th Street between Park and First Avenues to encourage and preserve the distinctive character of the Yorkville neighborhood.
Government safety investigators said today that a possible defect in about 441,000 Buick and Cadillac cars could cause the accelerator to jam, "creating an unreasonable risk of an accident."

Mrs. Ruth Hardy Crumlish, widow of Judge James C. Crumlish Sr. of the Philadelphia Common Pleas Court, died in Lenox Hill Hospital on Tuesday while visiting a son. She was 84 years old and lived on Schoolhouse Lane in Germantown, Philadelphia.

The city's Department of Investigation disclosed yesterday that it was looking into the situation at the Jordan L. Mott Junior High School 22 in the Bronx where teachers and students have charged that youngsters were punished with beatings.

Mike Hagon ran a mile anchor leg in 4 minutes 10 seconds last night to lead Suffern High of Rockland County to victory in the distance medley over favored Mepham and Power Memorial in the Suffolk County invitation relays at the St. John the Baptist track.

Hearings for the bankruptcy trustee operating the Viatron Computer Systems Corporation, and for a group of Viatron debentures holders will be held on June 12 in Federal Court in Boston, it was announced yesterday.

The American. League formally approved today the sale of 90 per cent of the Texas Rangers by Bob Short to a Fort Worth-Dallas group for an estimated $9-million. The approval by 11 owners culminated negotiations that began before the start of the season and established Brad Corbett, a 36-year-old industrial magnate, as the principal owner.

The following are the results of local school board elections on Long Island and in Westchester County. The tax rates in Nassau and Suffolk are for each $100 of assessed valuation, and in Westchester for each $1,000.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, chairman of the Senate Watergate committee, said today that the bugging scandal would have been over "in 10 minutes" if President Nixon had quickly questioned his campaign managers after the 1972 breakin at the Democratic offices here. Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. speaking to members of National Press Club.

Kenneth Rush was sworn in today as the Nixon Administration's chief economic coordinator. Mr. Rush, 64 years old, became a counselor to the President specializing in economic matters.

Last October this newspaper raised one of many voices critical of the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to Henry A. Kissinger for his part in the Vietnam negotiations. The dubious effectiveness of that "peace" accord, and the cynical bargaining and bombing tactics that led up to it did not seem at the time to justify his inclusion in the ranks of such men of peace as Dag Hammarskjold, Ralph Bunche or Albert Schweitzer.

Nordiska on Fifth Avenue is the kind of place that tempts you to throw out all your old kitchen stuff and start over from scratch. "All merchandise is 40 per cent less than list price," said Liesbeth van der Heijden, coordinator of the seven Nordiska stores, which specialize in Scandinavian kitchen and household items and French porcelain ovenware.

The four Democratic candidates for Governor assailed the state's mental health program yesterday, using such words as "fraud," and "disgrace" as they blamed both Governor Wilson and former Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller.

Moves by the Nixon Administration to set up new energy agencies are "only half the job" of providing the United States with a long-term energy policy, William 0. Doub, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, said here yesterday.
Owners of subcompact cars may one day have to pay more for auto insurance if auto accident statistics compiled on 1974 models begin to show that a trend is developing.

A Federal grand jury has begun investigating allegations that employes of Security National Bank were compelled to contribute to a secret political fund when they were promoted, Justice Department sources said yesterday.
A Trenton bank president testified today that he had been offered $6-million in state deposits if his bank would invest a like amount in securities with a New York City brokerage concern.

The voters of Arkansas embraced the new and rejected the old in the Democratic primary yesterday. They voted by almost 2-to-1 to replace Senator J. W. Fulbright, the 69-year-old chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, with Gov. Dale L. Bumpers, a 48-year-old political whiz kid who was unknown outside of Franklin County, Ask., until four years ago.
During the rush to recognize the Peking Government, members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations have been taking their time about it. Now the first move has been made.

Joseph E. Levine, the movie producer-distributor, yesterday announced his resignation as president of Avco Embassy Pictures Corporation, effective June 30, and said he would become an independent producer. He will be succeeded by William E. Chaikin, Avco Embassy's vice president and director of West Coast operations.
Secretary General Waldheim, welcoming the new Syrian-Israeli disengagement agreement, said today that he already had begun preparing for the United Nations' new role in regard to it.

Franca Somigli, an American soprano who made her debut at the Metropolitan Opera in 1937, died May 16 in Trieste, where her husband, Giuseppe Antonicelli, a former Metropolitan conductor, was general manager of the opera house. She was 66 years old.

The use of torture as a political instrument is an evil beyond justification or compromise, a practice officially condemned by every civilized society. Yet it goes on, in many places around the world, and arousing people's interest in the subject is singularly difficult.

The market for basketball players is apparently tumbling. Player agents, who could virtually name their own terms two years ago, are finding business more difficult to transact. Bob Woolf, players' representative, said, "Both leagues are taking a tougher stand." Mike Storen, A.B.A. commissioner, said, "Before summer is over the agents will be in a panic."
Summations in the conspiracy trial of New York harness drivers drew close to a finish yesterday with the prosecution urging jurors to recognize what is called a "mosaic of corruption."

Under budget cuts proposed by Mayor Beame, the Department of Consumer Affairs stands to loose $557,000 and nearly one-third of its staff and will be virtually unable to function, according to Commissioner Elinor Guggenheimer.

John W. Dean 3d has testified that former Attorney General John N. Mitchell gave him a "go ahead" to impose a condition on James R. Hoffa that would prevent him from seeking the teamsters' union presidency again for 10 years in return for his release from Federal prison.

Harold W. McGraw Jr. has been elected president of McGraw-Hill, Inc., the big publisher of books and magazines. He succeeds Shelton Fisher, who was appointed chairman while continuing as chief executive officer. Harold W. McGraw Jr.

Rioting broke out at a South African gold mine and two miners were killed and five injured, the mine's owner said today. The trouble began after a pay dispute at the Loraine mine in the Orange Free State last night.
Adult New Yorkers who were working or looking for work fell to 54.7 per cent of the adult population in 1973, the fourth consecutive year of decline, while the national rate rose to 60.8 per cent.

Some stockholders of the Northrop Corporation are trying to remove the company's chief executive officer from the board of directors for making alleged illegal contributions to President Nixon's 1972 campaign.

Governor Byrne announced today that the Rutgers-Princeton football game in 1976 would be played as part of the bicentennial celebration in the stadium now under construction in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

Steven A. Weed, who was engaged to marry Patricia Hearst before her abduction in February, said last night that he was now convinced of Miss Hearst's loyalty to her captors and that she had probably not been coerced into joining their cause.

Prompted by a civil-rights mandate, the Legislature tonight approved new legislative and Congressional district lines for Manhattan and Brooklyn amid protests from white and black incumbents and vows of new court challenges. Assemblymen Woodrow Lewis, left, and Harvey L. Strelzin, Brooklyn Democrats, checking their new districts in the Assembly chamber in Albany yesterday.

A prestigious Gandhian organization has fiercely attacked the Government for conducting a nuclear test earlier this month. The Gandhi Peace Foundation, in a letter published in most English-language newspapers here, termed the underground explosion May 18 "a cruel joke on the people of this country."

A special Federal court today was ordered convened to decide a suit challenging the Califorpia law that gives the winner of a Presidential primary all his party's votes at the national convention. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that the challenge raised a "substantial constitutional question."

A $1.2-million suit has been filed by seven antiwar veterans and a supporter against Government prosecutors who tried unsuccessfully to convict them of conspiracy to riot at the 1972 Republican National Convention.

The Arab states, Iran and other oil producing nations have sharply increased the amount of money provided or pledged to the World Bank this year for its lending activities in the underdeveloped world.

Word that India has contracted for 3 million tons of American wheat-roughly two thirds of this nation's pro ejected carryover-sent prices of that grain soaring on Middle Western commodity markets yesterday. Ship loading wheat at Continental Grain Company elevators at Superior, Minn. Wheat prices rose after reports that India had contracted for three million tons of the grain.
Discovery of a hereditary biochemical defect in muscle that kills patients under anesthesia has led to a test that can detect such susceptible individuals before surgery.
South Africa's Prime Minister, John Vorster, and the Rhodesian leader, Ian D. Smith, met in Pretoria today for "candid discussions" about the situation in southern Africa.

The general strike that brought the economy of Northern Ireland almost to a standstill and toppled the coalition government of the province was called off today by its organizers. President Valery Giscard d'Estaing is setting out by necessity as well as conviction to move the half-presidential, half-parliamentary Government of France's Fifth Republic toward an American-style presidential system. France's new chief of state won office with 50.8 per cent of the popular vote; but in the National Assembly electedd last year, his party holds only 11 per cent of the seats and his centrist allies another 7 per cent.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People asked the United States District Court here to order the Cincinnati Board of Education to integrate the city's 108 public schools by Sept. 1.

An 1820 handdrawn goose-neck pumper, a 1916 Ford chemical pumper, a Walt Disney-Donald Duck fire prevention film, slides on the New York City Fire Department, a working modelwhich viewers may operateof the city's Early Report System for turning in fire alarms - all of this plus scores of famous photographs of New York firefighting action are on view in the Kodak Photo Gallery.

The International Red Cross said today that two aircraft were standing by to exchange prisoners taken in the October war between Syria and Israel. Francois Paytot, Swiss chief of the Red Cross in Israel, said his organization was awaiting the go-ahead, A Red Cross DC6, with a medical team, was ready for immediate take-off from Switzerland and a second was standing by in Israel, he said.

The Supreme Court decision yesterday restricting certain kinds of class-action suits is likely to have its strongest impact on consumer suits and on those dealing with corporate liability and violations of Federal securities laws.

If all goes according to plan, the signature of the Treasurer of the United States, appearing at the left bottom corner of paper money, will soon be Mrs. Francine I. Neff. Francine I. Neff practicing her signature yesterday in Albuquerque, N. M., after she was nominated by President Nixon to be Treasurer of the U.S.
The stock market yesterday shrugged off news of an IsraeliSyrian disengagement agreenent and plunged sharply as :he trading pace quickened somewhat.

Dugan, Democrat of Hudson County and the Democratic state chairman, said the party intended to raise the money through a $110-a-plate dinner June 27 in Sea Girt, with Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, as the principal speaker. Governor Byrne has a $126,000
Oilmen offered $1.5-billion to day for new sea-bottom drilling space on the Gulf of Mexico off the Texas coast, but passed up half the 245 seabottom tracts for lease by the Federal Government.
The Food and Drug Administration proposed today permanent warning labels on all microwave ovens but rejected a Consumers Union petition calling for more comprehensive warnings and safety testing.

Three Lila Acheson Wallace Chairs for distinguished teachers have been established at the Juilliard School. The chairs, the first in Juilliard's history, will be en dowed from a special fund that also provides for visiting artists through the school's institute of Special Studies.
The Government reported today that its indicators of future trends in the economy declined in April, primarily because people are putting in shorter work weeks.

Roberts Scott Co., Inc., the only San Diego-based member of the New York and American stock exchanges, announced today that it was going out of business and would close all its 21 brokerage offices in California and Arizona because of "the uncertainty of the general economy and the continuing decline in the securities market."

Republicans have long presided over the rolling, forested, fox-hunting hills that dominate much of the Fifth Congressional District of New Jersey. But after 22 years of representation by Peter H. B. Frelinghuysen, a troubled Republican party on Tuesday will choose a candidate from a group of nonconformist party liberals.

Israel and Syria agreed on an accord to separate their forces on the Golan Heights. Syrian and Israeli military officers are to sign the accord in Geneva tomorrow, the first time the two Governments have formally agreed on anything since the armistice that ended the Israeli war of independence in 1948. Secretary of State Kissinger, who worked out the agreement in a month of intensive personal diplomacy, plans to leave for home today. [1:8.]

The chairman and three directors of the New York Stock Exchange told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that elimination of fixed rates for floor brokerage would jeopardize the operation of an auction market for equity securities and the availability of capital for industry.
William Greenwalt, a 40-yearold Hartsdale lawyer, was selected tonight as the Democratic candidate for the Westchester County Congressional seat held by Peter A. Peyser, a Republican.
Paced by player-coach Tony Roche, the Denver Racquets won the first four sets and then coasted to an easy victory tonight over the New York Sets, 28-18, in World Team Tennis.
Herbert Stanley Keller, a partner in the law firm of Weisman, Celler, Spett, Modlin Wertheimer at 425 Park Avenue, died yesterday at his home, 82 Kingsbury Road in New Rochelle, N.Y. His age was 66.
The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that it was raising its smallbusiness, lending rate to 8 1/2 per cent' from 8 per cent "in response to market conditions."

Vice President Ford, in an apparent shift of views, said here tonight that President Nixon's attitude in resisting demands by a House inquiry for additional material "is proper" at this time. Vice President Ford chatting with the Rev. Billy Graham before their round of golf at the Pro-Am event yesterday at Charlotte, N. C.

American hopes of defeating the great Italian Blue Team and capturing the world team title were disappointed once again yesterday, but not before the Aces gave their great rivals a considerable frieht.

Johnny Guarnieri, who is one of the outstanding contemporary exponents of Fats Waller's stride piano style and was the harpsichordist in Artie Shaw's original Gramercy Five in 1940, is mixing Waller and Shaw at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, where he is playing both as a soloist and with a reconstituted Gramercy Five.

Oregon Democrats set up yesterday a rerun of the 1968 Senate race when former Senator Wayne Morse was chosen to run in November against Senator Robert W. Packwood, the Republican who ousted him from the Senate in 1968. Wayne Morse, who won the Democratic nomination for Senator in Oregon, with some of his cattle yesterday on his farm in Eugene. He lost Senate seat in 1968.
Adolph Shelby Ochs, who retired in 1960 as treasurer and a director of The Chattanooga Times, died yesterday in a Chattanooga hospital. He was 79 years old.
Fourth-seeded Stan Smith led an American contingent into the third round of the $134,000 Italian open tennis championships today with a 6-3, 6-2 victory over Attila Korpas of West Germany.
Dr. Regis J. Leonard, professor of education in the School of Education of Fordham University, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Nutley, N.J. He was 61 years old.

Senator J. W. Fulbright's defeat yesterday in the Arkansas Democratic primary could shuffle next year the leadership of two of the Senate's most important committees--Foreign Relations and Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs. Senator John J. Sparkman Senator J. W. Fulbright with his wife, Betty, at his headquarters in Little Rock, Ark., Tuesday night. He was acknowledging defeat in his bid for renomination for a sixth term on the Democratic ticket.
The House of Representatives voted today to let the Office of Economic Opportunity die June 30 and to transfer most of its few remaining programs to a new Community Action Administration.

These past 32 days have changed the face of the Middle East. In a mood swinging repeatedly from enthusiasm to near-despair, Secretary of State Kissinger has completed a mission of peace and mediation without parallel in the long history of the Arab-Israeli dispute. When the details of this complex negotiation can be made known, it will doubtless rank as a classic example of diplomatic technique.

Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, said today that he would ask for the chairmanship of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee when J. W. Fulbright left that post.

WASHINGTON - Republicans are sounding alarms about a veto-proof Congress, and the Democrats may indeed win the two-to-one House margin they are hoping for in November if things keep up the way they are.

Five South Jamaica residents who live near the lot where Police Officer Thomas Shea shot and killed 10-year-old Clifford Glover on April 28, 1973, testified yesterday at Officer Shea's murder trial in Supreme Court in Queens. All five said they had heard the shots.
The British Government set out today to seek a new answer to the problem of how Northern Ireland can be governed with the consent of both the Protestant and Roman Catholic communities.
The hard-pressed Franklin National Bank continued to lose deposits in the last week, but the drain has slowed, according to the regular weekly report of the New York Clearing House.
Bettors with short memories may look over the field for tomorrow's $96,562.50 Realization Pace at Roosevelt Raceway, see an 8-1 morning line on Valiant At the Bret, and yawn.
Leif Hoegh, founder and chairman of Leif Hoegh Co., shipping company of Oslo, Norway, and former chairman of the Norwegian America Line, died May 23 in Oslo.

Mayor Beame yesterday named Dr. Amelia H. Ashe, a school guidance and counseling authority, and Joseph Monserrat as his two at-large appointees to the new seven- : member Board of Education that will take over on July 1.
As if being in last place in the National League's Eastern Division wasn't bad enough, the problems of the Pittsburgh Pirates and Manager Danny Murtaugh continued to mount yesterday.

Open Eye is a group of actors, dancers, musicians and singers who, on Wednesday at the Exchange Theater, joined their talents to create an event, "Haitian Suite '74", directed by Teiji Ito.

Yugoslav Communists ended their tenth party congress today with the election of President Tito as head of the party for life and with resolutions to strengthen party influence at every level of national life.
Walter Bernard Strauss, was shot and killed during a holdup of his liquor store here early this week. Violence was nothing new to the 52-year-old Mr. Strauss and his wife, Doris,
There are not many American singers who could or would devote an entire recital to music by Polish composers, but Elizabeth Patches did just that at Tully Hall on Wednesday night.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell again yesterday as traders shrugged off the effects of the acceptance of the accord between Israel and Syria reached on Wednesday. Prices in the over-the-counter market closed mixed.

American-controlled multinational corporations won a reprieve today from a House Ways and Means Committee staff proposal to require them to return 50 per cent of their foreign earnings to the United States annually for tax purposes.

DENVER-Ken Monfort, whose Colorado-based company is the world's largest producer of grain-fattened cattle, sold a steer one day recently and instead of making a profit he lost $125.

Ridgeley P. Ware, president of Associated Advisers, Inc., suggested yesterday that real estate investment trusts might begin to stabilize themselves if they adopted a uniform code for accounting, taxes and public reporting.
Joe Bouquin of Danbury, Conn.. and Doug Barrow of Bayside, Queens, scored upset victories today in the Long Island men's tennis championships at the Tower Tennis Club.

President Nixon agreed today to allow two Watergate defendants and their attorneys access to the defendants' personal White House files.

In the wake of the departure of the cellist Mstislav Rostropovich for a two-year stay in Britain, similar travel requests by other renowned Soviet musicians, including the pianist Sviatoslav Richter, have come to light.
South Shore High School won its second consecutive Public Schools Athletic League tennis title yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.
Three times during his grueling month of shuttle diplomacy, Secretary of State Kissinger was close to giving up and returning to Washington without an accord, American officials said today.

The Republican-controlled State Assembly today refused an urgent request from Governor Wilson to amend the new rentcontrol law as its leaders adjourned a two-day special session without allowing the Governor's amendments to come to a vote.

Lawyers for Evonne Goolagong and Jimmy Connors have brought a civil action against the French Tennis Federation demanding that tile two players be allowed to participate in the French open championships that start Monday, court officials said today.

The United States threw its support today to the proposed oil facility in the International Monetary Fund to help nations cope with the adverse impact of the explosion of oil prices on their balances of payments.
Ernest Lynwood Brothers of 5 Manor Road, an interior decorator, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 85 years old.

A 5-year-old boy was attacked and mauled by a stray dog here today as he waited outside his home for the mail, the Suffolk County police reported. The dog ran away after the attack. Joseph B. Williams, the administrator of the city's Model Cities program from 1970 to 1973, was named deputy administrative judge in charge of the city's Family Court yesterday.

Being nude in public is not being lewd in public, state appellate court declared yesterday, cutting through semantics and striking down the 1971 conviction of a woman who went sunbathing in the nude at Indian Head Beach in Amagansett, L.I.

Rear Adm. Joseph P. Canty, U.S.N. retired, who taught mathematics at the University of Maine, died here yesterday. He was 67 years old. Admiral Canty graduated in 1929 from the United States Naval Academy.

A planned exhibition of Asian art owned by the Norton Simon Foundation, Inc., has been suspended at the Metropolitan Museum of Art because of a disagreement between the foundation and Metropolitan officials. The Nataraja, bought by Norton Simon for $1-million in 1972. Indian officials say it was smuggled from country.

Federal mediators stepped into the sluggish negotiations between clothing workers and manufacturers yesterday in an effort to avert a nationwide strike of 110,000 clothing workers set for midnight tonight.

FRUNZE, U.S.S.R.-In a decade or so, the world champion swimmers from America and Australia may wake up one day to find their supremacy unexpectedly challenged by some unknowns from the Frunze agricultural machinery plant out here in Soviet Central Asia. Students are coached at a special swimming school in the Frunze agricultural machinery plant in Frunze, the Soviet Union. Plant concentrates on early development of athletes.

Archibald Cox, the Harvard law professor and former special Watergate prosecutor, told 7,000 Rutgers University graduates, faculty members and friends today that "all-consuming ties" between government and universities posed the chief threat to the pursuit of academic truth. Secretary of State Kissinger ended his month-long Middle East mission and headed home after a stop in Cairo, where he was praised by President Anwar el-Sadat. The Egyptian leader hailed the Nixon Administration's "effective role" as a great power and expressed an advance welcome to President Nixon, who is expected to visit Egypt during a Middle Eastern trip in June. [1:3-4.]
Wheat futures prices declined yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade by as much as 5 cents a bushel at the close for one delivery.

The House of Representatives passed today and sent to the Senate a bill calling for limited audit of the Federal Reserve Board by the General Accounting Office. It was a much weaker bill than sponsors of the measure honed for.

The Treasury Department today auctioned a total of $800.16-million in bills, the so-called "strip" offering consisting of $100-million additions to each of eight outstanding weekly series of bills maturing from Sept. 19 through Nov. 7.
A Senate-House conference committee reached agreement on a bill that will allow automobile emission standards for the 1975 model year to remain in effect through the 1976 model year.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 216.9 from 220.6 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 166.3 on May 29, 1973.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland-A contradiction was built into the very idea of a "power-sharing" government by a coalition of Northern Ireland's Protestant and Catholic political forces. Any such groups willing to form a power-sharing coalition probably could never command enough popular support to govern; while groups with broad-based political appeal are too nearly at opposite extremes to join in a coalition.

The 96-deal final of the world team championship in Venice this week was fully worthy of the occasion. A study of the errors committed suggests that the standard was as high as it has ever been in a Bermuda Bowl final.

The Town of Massena today approved by almost 2 to 1 a bond issue of $4.5-million to buy and operate a municipal electric-power system. The town, which is on the St. Lawrence River, is supplied by the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, which opposed the bond issue.

Phil Howser, for 32 years general manager of the Charlotte Hornets baseball club, died today at Veterans Hospital in nearby Salisbury. He was 63 years old.

The Federal Reserve Bank has not eased monetary policy, figures published yesterday by the central bank showed. Key short-term interest rates moved down this week but the Federal funds rate-a key indicator of monetary policyaveraged a record of 11.54 per cent.

The State Insurance Department yesterday announced the approval of an 18.9 per cent average increase in Blue Shield premiums affecting 2.5 million subscribers. The increase is designed to yield the plan $14-million a year.
Diplomats here today minimized the possibility of a confrontation between Greece and Turkey over their rights to explore for oil in the Aegean Sea.

"Mason Reese was on last week to talk about children's liberation," she says, oblivious to the fact that her drink is slowly trickling onto her floral print blouse.

WASHINGTON-Richard Nixon, the most subpoenaed President in history. Richard Nixon, subpoena fighter. For 10 months he's been at it, battling subpoenas from prosecutors, defendants, Congressional committees, judges. Now he's been told that he may be impeached for it, and he's still at it, claiming executive privilege, insisting he's doing it for the Presidency and the nation, not the man.

Civic leaders in Flatlands, the first area settled by the Dutch in Brooklyn, are preparing to celebrate its 350th birthday in the next few weeks. "We have a lot of history here and it's a shame we can't take advantage of it like we should," said William A. Wells, a lifelong resident of the area and a leader in the Flatlands Chamber of Commerce.

Chowder sounds as American as Indian pudding, but the word actually is French in origin. It is derived from the French word chaudiere, meaning cauldron. This was the vessel in which French immigrants cooked their fish stews when they settled in the coastal areas of America. The chowders on this page represent two of this nation's favorites Manhattan clam chowder and Boston clam chowder.
